28353283.review:
TL;DR -> Even if I recommend you play this game, be aware that it's NOT for everyone. This is a jrpg (and a fairly easy one I'd say) with a visual novel-like narration and very interesting characters, lots of grinding and several "meh" plot twists, so if any of this bothers you, you're probably not gonna enjoy it. Otherwise, go for it. 

There's plenty of things to dislike in FFF: Running into dungeons for hours because Fire Stones aren't spawning. Those stupid plot twists where almighty gods and creatures are inside people and objects. The fact that the boss hit you for 50 damage and the cutscene's like "AW, MAN, HE'S SOOO STRONG, WE NEED TO RUN AWAY". And about this point, the game's too easy. Enemies do very little damage, and if they do, you've plenty of healing magic to deal with them. Also, Fang is in the game. And even if with time he gest a little better, your first impression of him is that he's a patented asshole. Not a good quality for your supposed protagonist, isn't it?

But what FFF does good, it does VERY GOOD.
The music is FANTASTIC.
The fact that everytime you break a seal of the Goddess she loses a shard that covers her, and reveals her voluptuous body, keeps you motivated.
The characters are wonderful, and probably the best aspect of the game. Everyone of them has a fairy companion, so you basically interact with a "couple" instead of a single character. These couples are funny and have very well defined personalities: there's the noble-like girl with her pokemon, the lazy girl with a big bald man that scolds her, a dumb and lovely fellow with her fairymom, and, well, a green cat with a blue afro and a sword through his skull, and his sexy male butler. I couldn't make this up even if I wanted.
The point is, it's a funny bunch. It's lively, it's noisy, and it feels like a real adventuring party where everyone is given a bit of spotlight.
Also Harley is the best thing in the game and so is the fanservice regarding all of the female characters.

The combat is also good. You've got this weird combo system instead of a single attack, you can chain combos between allies and air juggle enemies with the right setup. It's not really intuitive, but as soon as you get it, you're gonna go full Soul Calibur on those bizarre monsters.
You can transform, or Fairize if you'd like, and use super-final abilities. Both of those things feel AWESOME every time you watch them, it really spices up your regular jrpg turn-based combat. So even if you're levelling up or grinding WPs, you're not gonna get bored. Well not immediately at least.
WPs are basically experience points to upgrade your characters. It's fun to have it, but you're soon gonna find yourself in the mental state that "you're gonna unlock everything", so it's not like you can "build" characters. Keep that in mind.

28322295.review:
TL:DR A mediocre JRPG + small doses of PLOT.

I've played a lot of jrpgs in my time but these days I usually don't have the patience for them. That said I did finish the game and even had the intention of playing a NG+. Spent the time to make sure I had everything important maxed. And then I saw the ending (eryn's)... and I lost all motivation. It's not to say it was bad.. just meh. After that I watched the other endings on youtube and imo I got the best of the three. What probably kept me playing was the VN-like vibe to the game. But in the end the game is mediocre across the board. Get it on sale if you want a time waster.

+Random/Area transitions are quick. If you like to grind for some reason you'll appreciate the efficiency.
+There's fan service.. even if there's not a lot of it and gets tired after a while.
+Thank god they kept the Japanese voices. Listening to the other endings in english made my ears bleed.

-Combat lacks any practical depth. Supposedly mobs have weaknesses but you can pretty much mash your way thru. But who buys this for game mechanics?
-The PLOT sucked all of the plot from the story. If you're hoping the game might defy your expectations you'll be disappointed. 
-40 is not equal to 100 furies. Sounds like development ran out of steam or they gave no fairies that the intro goal had no correlation to the ending.
-There are a couple points gathering mats for quests becomes a real pain. If you don't intend to play ng+ save yourself the time and don't even bother with the side quests.

28121679.review:
Bought Fairy Fencer when it was on sale, it had been on my wish list for awhile, but didn't think it'd be good enough to fork out the full amount.

I was wrong. This game was amazing! I bought it and Valkyria Chronicles and Tales of Zesteria all at the same time and planned to play each just an hour to try them all out, and then play them casually over the new few months inbetween League of Legends matches.

I had two days off, and played Fairy Fencer the ENTIRE TIME, I did 20 hours of gameplay in 2 DAYS IF THAT, may of been a day and a half!!! I couldn't stop playing, it's fun, and unique, and runs sooooo smooth.

Pros:
+Interface is terrific, so smooth on PC and it loads so fast that everything is so convenient, a truly well built system.
+Voice Acting was great, the only obnoxious part was how robotic the fairies sound when they are fused. Not quite sure i understand why them fusing turns them into robots?
+Fun combat system, never got bored with it, really enjoyed the music, and it made Fairize mode feel even more amazing when the song would pop up and stay with you until combat was over.
+DLC Adds a lot of fun features, although it may be recommended to NOT use the ultimate armor or weapon accessories,  as it will make you pretty much invincible for 3/4s the game.
+Harley is Waifu Bait for life.
+Very Keyboard Friendly

Mids:
=Story is great, but honestly, you're gonna wanna wait for "Fairy Fencer F: Advent Dark Forces" to come out in 2017 instead of buying this, unless you can't wait, essentially it's the same story, but they are adding a lot more depth to tie off a lot of loose ends with this one.

Cons:
-Not enough Harley, NEEDS MORE HARLEY. (Changing that with Add-on pack?)
-Expansion pack is going to cost roughly the price of buying the game at full cost again (Fairy Fencer F: Advent Dark Forces; just an expansion that adds more story and allows you to use a party of 6 instead of the forced party of 3)
-I didn't play this years ago when it was released for the PS3 because I'm an idiot. 

You'll love this shit. Buy it, or wait for the Fairy Fencer F: Advent Dark Forces and buy that. Either way, play this shit if you like the genre.

27967635.review:
Well.. IF you are a IF (idea Factory) fan you know what this game will be like before you start it.

Compare to all the neptunia game out there this game is just IF's try to create other story worlds.

It's done pretty good with some flaws in the story plots as a lot of story junction feels forced or not very logical...

Graphics is the same top effort of japanese animation styles and all the character designs (good or bad characters) are all very lovable. 

Music is actually one the strong point of this game and it have way better in game music then most neptunia games.(unlock sound gallery pretty earlly in game to listen to the full songs).

Every story script of this game is either plot advancing or trying to be funny. It was really funny some of the time but i couldn't get the joke some times.

There are 3 endings but they can be gotten in one story run as long as u save before trigger the event inside desert santuary. The subevent is in the 5 star inn. 

All the acheivements are very easy to get except that masscure kill count achivement that will require a lot grinding.

7.5/10 as a very enjoyable RPG with less grinding compare to neptunia games.

27370211.review: Fairy Fencer F is a fantastic, mostly light hearted JRPG with an interesting story, despite the unoriginal premise. Influences from other IF/Compa titles is palpable in everything from the combat system to the item synthesis, but the assets and art is a step above their usual fare (and that's coming from a huge IF fan). Having brought on big names for music and concept art seems to have made a difference. This game, though not ground breaking, is just thoroughly entertaining and one of the best offerings I've seen from JRPGs in the past few years.

26790679.review:
This JRPG is a story about a fight between a Goddess and a Vile God who had different points of view : the Goddess wants to protect the world by bringing peace whereas the Vile God wants to take over the world to make chaos. At the end of the fight, the Goddess and the Vile God were sealed because of the furies which were used during the fight.

  A long time later, a young boy Fang who is a normal guy who loves eating. He met Eryn, a fairy who is a part of Fang's sword. Fang became a Fencer and now, he will accomplish his destiny : to collect all the furies in order to ressurect the Goddess who will bring peace to the world. Will he be able to protect the world ? Then, Fang will do a long journey with his friends to grant their common wish. 

Positive points :

- An excellent soundtrack 
- A simple gameplay which is very effective (similar to Neptunia games)
- The boost points
- 60 FPS
- A great character design 
- A game which will take at least 50 hours if you want to earn all the achievements
- The story is original and very interesting 
- The characters are endearing 
- The backgrounds are beautiful
- The CG gallery is excellent

Negative points : 

- The landscapes are repetitive sometimes and the textures can be improved
- The game is a little bit too easy for some gamers maybe

Conclusion : I played this game hundred hours if I add my ps3's stats and I was never bored by it ! I recommend this game to all JRPGs fans without any doubt. By the way, the negative points I mentionned earlier have been improved in the game Fairy Fencer F Advent Dark Force which will be available in 2017 on Steam. Thank you Compile Heart for making great games like Fairy fencer F ! Now I will wait for Fairy Fencer F Advent Dark Force and I already know that this game will be a huge art which will spread you strong feelings.

I haven't finished the game yet, but I'd say it's worth it.

Story is okay, I guess. Pretty much 'average guy gets awesome powers and is initially reluctant but travels the world anyway, picks up companions throughout the journey, becomes hero and saves the world with his harem'. Gameplay is pretty simple, but kinda repetitive at times.

That aside, the characters are likable. I didn't really dig the main character too much, but I liked the other characters. It's lighthearted, and there are funny moments through the game. I like that there's Japanese audio as well as English, and I'd say the sound (both music and voice acting) is pretty good. 26231961.review:
This is a light hearted JRPG. It’s not too long nor too small. It’s perfect to spend some time.
While not particularly groundbreaking in any sense, it’s a very good game. It starts in a very comedic tone, and even when it gets into the main plot it never goes near dark.
The dungeons are somewhat repetitive, but there are no random encounters, you can see the enemies on the screen and avoid them.
The Tower is a very nifty way to take away the grind in dungeons, almost all side quest important items can be found there, and it’s a quick way to gain exp, money.
Don’t try to do everything on the first run. If you try to finish all side quests it might go for about 20h. On NG+ you’ll stomp everything that moves and are finally able to do some other side quests, recruit extra characters, get another ending (there are three different one) and focus on other stuff, like crafting.
It’s a good game. Ig you like the art style and jrpgs, this one is a good one, not the best, but good to relax form others like the Agarest series (80h a game with obligatory battles every move, it’s nuts).



About the DLCs:  the important ones are already included in the game (the tower ones). Some aren't very good (like the bath set) and other just break the game until lvl 30 zones (in first run you'll end up around lvl 40) so it's your call.

Gostei bastante de alguns personagens, em especial a Tiara, Eryn e a Ethel. Quando o jogo parece estar indo para um “caminho comum”, dá uma virada. As dungeons são curtas, em especial para jogatinas rápidas é bom, as dungeons não levam mais que 20 minutos no geral. Fadinhas variadas, desde mechas, “fados” e bem, fadinhas tradicionais hehe. 25863909.review:
I really wanted to love this game. Set in a bright colorful world with just the type of characters I would expect to see.  Cute outfits and stock consumables fill the item shop in the hub city. I really liked the way you could change the story by deciding whether you wanted to release the Goddess or the Devil. The swords being able to change the dungeons was also an interesting idea. All things considered it was just what i was hoping it would be at first.  However the game became a struggle after the first 10 hours due it its restrictive combat system and sluggish leveling.
Before I get into that, there are side missions to help you get additional items, but after the first round you just pick all the ones for the area you will be visiting and you will usually complete them as you travel thru the dungeon. There were a few that had me change the monsters in the dungeon or hunt down something interesting but most were quickly forgotten as soon as I accepted them. 
The combat system in this game places each of your characters facing the enemy in a small circle. For fights with 2 or less it's not a problem, but once you start going against big monsters with a full party you begin to realize just how tight the arena is. It seemed like I could make better use of the small space by increasing the character range but that leads me to my other issue. As you get more experience, each character earns points to increase various stats and buy new abilities. Some abilities are unneccessary but still i never felt i had enough to build my characters like i wanted. I had the DLC weapons on the entire time but I never felt overpowered. I pushed myself to make it about halfway through the story. (current hours 29) The battle system doesn't really get fun until you have at least a 3 move combo. While trying to balance your points between obtaining these moves, magics and other stats you realize that they don't go that far. This is when the game became too much of a grind. and when I couldn't go any further.
If a slow grind doesn't get to you in what is an alright RPG then go right ahead. But I can't reccomend it and I unfortunately will not be playing anymore of the games from Compile Heart as the battle/upgrade system is seen in all the ones I have looked into.

25735589.review:
Surprisingly very good. If you are a fan of the Neptunia series then this is a no brainer. The combat is solid although not as complex as the newer Neptunia games. Game is quite easy if you spend just 1-2 grinding so you are leagues ahead of any boss. With that being said grinding is not required with the buff system.

Pros:
- Amazing characters written with, character!
- Story feels like it's straight out of 12 episode anime series
- Great Story
- Slight Romance (which was welcome)
- Never overstayed it's welcome
- Combat combo system is fun

Cons:
- Skills were not interesting, Auto attacked through the whole game
- Reused dungeon maps in reverse order occasionaly and called it a new dungeon
- Some back tracking through same powered up dungeons required to progress story
- For a Compile Heart/Idea Factory game some extra features were missing 
- Weapon attack skills were plenty, but felt needed better damage variation they all felt similar with the exception of hit counter
- No over the top HDD mode :P

Conclusion:
- Play it for the enjoyable story if you are into shounen anime plots where you save the world and might get the girl in the end. This NEEDs to have a sequal, there is a lot of potential in this series. It is worth a buy!

25231333.review:
Fairy Fencer F... me cago en todo. No es un mal juego, pero no puedo recomendarlo. 

Es un jrpg con cosas buenas y cosas muy malas. Lo primero que hay que destaca es su diseño artístico, pues como aficionado a la animación japonesa debo decir que, aunque sea un diseño genérico y en ocasiones estúpido, sus personajes sueltan ALGO de carisma. El prota es el típico imbécil subnormal que con su buen corazón y su energía espiral se abro paso en un mundo plagado de muchachas adorables. Que sí,que es un juego japo y los japos son muy suyos, tan típicos y conservadores que el día que hagan algo DISTINTO se me caerá el pezón izquierdo. 

En fin, a lo que vamos. Como digo, su diseño artístico lo considero simple pero efectivo. Otra cosa buena : su sistema de combate. Es una mezcla entre combate por turnos y combate táctico. Esto es, que tenemos un escenario por donde nos movemos libremente ( ojo, libremente ) en cada uno de nuestros turnos. Y eso está bien, no es el sistema más maravilloso que encontrarás pero sí que sabe disimular el puto astío que dejan ya los jrpgs basados en turnos. Que no son malos, pero si has jugado ya una cierta cantidad como yo, siempre es algo bueno ver algo "distinto". 

Sigamos. Qué hay más bueno... ? ah sí, la forma de subir a los personajes. Te permite subir literalmente como te dé la puta gana a cada uno de los protagonistas. Ninguno tiene  un rol predeterminado y eso, quieras o no, es una alegría. Estoy hasta el pene de subir a la chica mona de healer o support por que... sea una tía. Ya sabéis, japos y sus costumbres milenarias. 

COSAS MALAS : 


La puta historia. No es que sea mala, pero en ningún momento sientes interés o preocupación por lo que va a ocurrir. Bueno, quizá haya un punto en la aventura que sí captó mi atención pero...luego te das cuenta de que es una  puta mierda. Si lo habéis jugado ya sabréis qué digo. Es una historia muy japo, con ese trasfondo tan épico y serio que se ve contrarestado por el tono desenfadado y KAWAII de los protagonistas, que en casi ningún momento parece que estén en una misión de suma importancia para salvar el mundo. Su puta madre. 

La música. No es mala, pero joder, hay 3 o 4 pistas ? y al final, la mejor canción que hay es la que en un principio me daba una grima importante. 

La narrativa, en general. Cualquiera que haya jugado JRPGS sabe que la narrativa es una cosa importante, pues se quiere explicar una historia. Quizá el primer punto negativo que he puesto se hubiese salvado si la narrativa fuera BUENA. O que existiese. Todo se basa en putos diálogos, con los mismos retratos de los personajes, lo único que salva todo esto es que el juego está doblado en japonés y como mínimo puedes darte cuenta de el tono que tiene cada situación por la actuación de voz de cada uno de los personajes. El caso es que todo ocurre en un mismo sitio, no hay sensación de progreso. El mapa que abres al principio es TODO el juego. Claro, luego hay zonas secretas y su puta madre pero en fin, que no. Se echan en falta cinemáticas, alguna que otra. Como mínimo para ensalzar momentos épicos o situaciones diversas, pero todo corre o bien con el motor del juego ( que es bastante pobre ) o con las ilustraciones, que cada protagonista tiene como 3 o 4 distintas así que ya os podéis imaginar la cantidad de veces que veréis la misma cara. 

Las misiones secundarias. Muy malas, y lo peor es que muchas las haces sin darte cuenta, ya que en cuanto las aceptas muchas ya las puedes entregar. Imagínate, es la primera vez que veo algo así. Aceptas una misión y la puedes completar en el mismo momento, sin salir de ahí. Es de chiste. Aunque hay muchos objetos que necesitarás una cantidad ridícula de dinero para comprarlos así que no deja de ser un medio para ello, un medio muy mal puesto, eso sí. 

La rejugabilidad. El juego te ofrece rejugarlo pues hay distintos finales, pero creedme que una vez acabas al igual tienes ganas de volver a pasar por todo. Y no me vale eso de guardar y cargar, eso es para noobs. 


En fin, Fairy Fencer F NO ES UN MAL JUEGO, pero si ya has jugado a unos cuantos jrpgs, no te lo recomiendo. Si nunca has probado un juego de rol con un espíritu y identidad japonesa  tan elevado y quieres probar cosas nuevas, te lo recomiendo sin duda. 

Para mi es un 6/10. NO es un mal juego, pero hay cosas mejores. Mirad la saga Neptunia, del mismo estudio (que si os digo la verdad, son clavados ) pero derrochan mucha más personalidad y carisma.

25193073.review:
I was pleasantly surprised by this game. Since it's made by the same company as the Neptunia franchise, I wasn't really expecting a [i]good[/i] story but my expectations were wrong.

Let's start off with the positives. The writing is still very anime-y but the story is told like a Visual Novel so it's able to flow nicely and coherently. The characters are pretty likeable (despite the main protagonist being unlikeable at the beginning) and there are a lot of optional skits that help develop some personality in each of them despite being a pretty short JRPG (20-30 hours for the first playthrough).

Combat is standard. If you've played a Neptunia game, it's the same thing: Turn-based in a 3D realm. A different aspect of the whole leveling process is the "Weapon Point" system where you can spend points to obtain new skills or magic in (mostly) any order you like. This lets you see noticeable differences in your strength.

Oh, and the music is pretty great. The game takes a "Tales of Symphonia: Sylvarant -> Tethealla" route with the music where the normal battle and Fairize music change after starting the 2nd half of the game. It's a nice touch that I personally love. The final boss music is fantastic as well. Without it, the final boss would not have been so great.

I noticed a lot of complaints about bland characters. The thing with that is you can easily pile any JRPG or anime character into a single archetype without regarding any of their other traits or back stories. It's just dumb to have that mindset. All of the characters, from the main cast to the villains, are very unique and memorable. One of the secret characters in particular play a great role in developing the main character's motivations which made me actually [i]feel[/i].

Another complaint I've seen is the fact that the game re-uses assets. Without going into spoiler territory, I'll just say that the whole direction of the 2nd half of the game actually played out the way the story intended so that complaint is just moot. I definitely did [u]not[/u] get the feeling that they were just trying to "prolong the game".

Now on to the bad. Combat. It's either way too easy or you have to suddenly start grinding. The difficulty is really...weird in this game. There are no options to select a difficulty so everything is always going to be fixed. Given that info, I'm surprised there was such a weird fluctuation in difficulty since you'd think it would be [i]easier[/i] for the devs to adjust the difficulty with only 1 setting.

Another thing that is a side-effect of the weird difficulty is how some of the fights play out. There are always cutscenes before, during, and after the boss fights which doesn't always match up to how easy/hard the boss was. For example, I completely stomped one of the bosses and right after a cutscene plays where my character is saying "I don't think we can beat him...". It's pretty awkward but it does that to fit the narrative of the story I guess. They could have fixed that by giving different dialogue options (Scene A plays if you win, Scene B plays if you lose/don't kill him in x amount of turns) but I shouldn't expect that much from a low-budget game. Thankfully the final boss' difficulty is [i]just right[/i] and that left me with a great feeling at least. There are a few other minor gripes like the moments of [i]completely[/i] random fan service but it's from the Nep-devs so what else could I expect.

Overall, Fairy Fencer F is a pretty great game with some complaints that can just be forgiven if you just focus on the drive of the story rather than the gameplay. I will give a warning for completionists though as this game is incredibly grindy if you're going after achievements.

24834707.review:
[h1]Score: 6/10[/h1]

[b][u]Similar Games[/u][/b]
Neptunia Rebirth Series

[b][u]Summary[/u][/b]
Enter Fang a guy who instead of wishing for power just wants food. You become a Fencer after pulling out a sword and meeting you new fairy partner Eryn. Soon you join up with Tiara and Cui. The backstory is that the Vile God and the Goddess are both sealed away and by attaining the furies. Eventually there is plot twists, bad guys, and companions.

[b][u]Combat[/u][/b]
The combat is totally uneven. Going into magic is essentially a complete waste of time. You are way better off expanding your physical attack. You should also expand moves per turn right away. There isn't much point in going into any defense systems either. Magic is only good for healing moves. Your gear does matter for creating resistances and increasing attack.

[b][u]Positive[/u][/b]
The combat itself has great pieces to it. The ability to analyze an opponent as a special ability. Fang going into Serious mode. Tiara being used as a healer and using her barrier to make sure the healer doesn't die. If you take down a foe way beyond your level and it was hard fought it feels great. There is plenty of things to do in the game such as increasing your rank in quest and goddess.

[b][u]Negative[/u][/b]
I was nearly 14 levels below what I was intended to be toward the end of the game. Whats worse is the creators seem to have known that was the case. Creating secret character you can only get if your level 40 when I was just level 20. I guess your supposed to grind or do new game +. Well I don't agree with that attitude because it's lazy. Combat felt challenging while I rushed through the game. Then I was forced to grind and suddenly combat was way to easy. If you are to low level enemies will practically one shot you. The quest level up system is also horrible. You have to grind hidden items for hours and for what? Nothing basically. The characters are also even more generic/flat then in Neptunia games and in those they are standard anime characters because they should be for the jokes to work better.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
It's not a horrible game, but god it could have been better then this. The story and characters do get better, but just not descent enough in the end. It came off lame at the end of the day. It has plenty of humor, but just doesn't have enough interesting concepts and scenes to carry it well. The combat is great, but the upgrade system is incredibly uneven. I hate to say it, but maybe if this game had dating sim stuff in it the stories would have been more interesting. The girl whos in love with money is great, but even that gets tired. Honestly for all the people who complain about Neptunia 2 this game is easily not as good as that one.

[b][u]Value[/u][/b]
$5 tops... especially if you like Neptunia games you stand a better shot at liking it.

24794112.review: JRPG creado por Idea Factory y Compile Heart, creadores de la saga Hyperdimension Neptunia. Su historia, aunque en principio bastante genérica, tiene una serie de giros argumentales que hace que se mantenga interesante hasta el final. Si en algo destaca, es en sus personajes, que a pesar de usar los estereotipos comunes en el anime, tienen personalidad y carisma. Emocionalmente, es una obra cargada de humor, pero tiene sus momentos emotivos que consiguen que te involucres sentimentalmente con los personajes. Jugablemente, es bastante similar a la saga Neptunia, pero con algunas diferencias, sobre todo relacionadas con el crecimiento del personaje. Aquí, en lugar de desbloquear nuevos combos y habilidades cuando alcanzas determinados niveles, se te otorgan puntos especiales que puedes invertir en desbloquear los que pienses que más convienen al personaje, siempre que cumplas los requisitos necesarios para poder desbloquearlo. Esto, unido a la mecánica de vincular el personaje a un hada, la cual le otorga unos efectos pasivos determinados, dan bastante flexibilidad a la hora de mejorar a los personajes. En general, la jugabilidad es divertida, aunque no sea muy variada y puede hacerse un tanto repetitiva por el grindeo que en ocasiones exige. La banda sonora es bastante buena, y cuenta con la colaboración de Nobuo Uematsu, compositor principal de la saga Final Fantasy. Del mismo modo, su estilo artístico cuenta con la colaboración de Yoshitaka Amano, artista conceptual de Final Fantasy, aunque los sprites de los personajes y fondos están hechos por la misma gente que la saga Neptunia, lo cual es notorio. Si tuviera que destacar un punto negativo es que, a pesar de tener varios finales, estos no varían demasiado la historia principal, cambiando unicamente la escena post-créditos. Este error, sin embargo, tampoco influye mucho en la calidad del juego, y además, parece haber sido corregido en su remake, Fairy Fencer F: Advent Dark Force, en el que se han añadido varias rutas extra que alteran completamente la historia. En definitiva: es un gran juego, al que siento que le falta algún detalle para poder considerarlo una obra maestra, aunque quizás ese detalle si lo tenga el remake, el cual recomiendo sobre éste.

24722700.review:
Having played for about 70 hours and accomplished almost all the achievements, as far as I’m concerned, it is enough gathering of experiences to write this review, to begin, I hereunder state some pretty evident advantages and weaknesses of in-game features.
[h1]+Pros[/h1]
+Touching story -> 3 endings.
+Well designed characters.
+Varieties in strategy both during and outside any battle.
+Reasonable training and opponents’ strength.
+Moving soundtrack.
+Cute CGs.
+Management of WP, an add-on feature that cannot be found in HDN series.

[h1]-Cons[/h1]
-Little amount of dungeon maps, in response to some achievements which demand players to continuously participate in the same battle with the same performance in plethora, things might get dull.
[spoiler]-the storyline is kind of a repetition of 2 walkthroughs[/spoiler]

For further reference, please watch this review~ [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/esnf3Noire/recommended/353270/]HDN RB3[/url]
Fairy Fencer F (FFF), a tactical role-playing just like Hyperdimension Neptunia (HDN), involves a game style of 3 characters in the frontline while all the other members stay in the rear, players can switch freely between units in the front and in the reserve as long as the character that is going to be replaced is alive. This switching system is what makes planning even more important, so first and foremost, a strategy needs to be fostered in order to be able to face any kinds of situations. Of course, sometimes you will meet enemies who are just too overpowered, in this case, players will have to train their characters until they reach a level which allows them to rival these hostiles.



The reason for which I keep comparing this game to HDN is actually because both games are created by Idea Factory and Compile Heart. This is why Fairy Fencer F is heavily identical to HDN series, although there are still some major changes, for players who have already experienced any rebirths, they will be able to recognize the combat system very soon, the only difference is Weapon point system which is not set in any HDN game. As for the storyline, the game is not related to HDN at all, Fairy Fencer F has a pretty classic tale of fantasy and adventure, anymore of this will spoil the story, so I’ll stop here~.

For items in game, FFF does provide various weapons and other equipments, but it did not inherit the complex ‘’plan’’ system found in HDN, therefore, there are only a handful of dungeons, without the DLC dungeons, I won’t recommend you to aim for the achievements…..it will just take too long. 

The general art design is pretty, so are the soundtracks, although many of them are rather classical, it does make players immerse in the story and in any battle, of course, for some, this feeling only lasts for the early period of game.

Thank you for reading this review, I hope it will prove to be helpful to you as well as giving you a vague concept of the way this game works.~

24415199.review:
Fairy Fencer F is a wonderful game. It is a charming jRPG, with a clear manga/anime flavor. Its strengths consist in the character design, rich and colorful, and an outstanding voice acting (both the Japanese and English version) combined with well-written dialogs containing the right amount of humor. You will truly enjoy each single dialog between the characters! The plot itself, while made up of interesting ideas, is maybe not developed to the highest levels, resulting quite plan and straightforward, nevertheless you will have a lot of fun through the story.

The combat system is dynamic and varied, with each character playing a distinguished role within the party and relying on spells, skills, close combat, transformations, and so on (as to be expected from a jRPG).

An intruiguing trait of the game is that you need to play at least a second run, not only to see other endings, but also to complete the most interesting side quests, and this hence improves the longevity of the game.

In summary, if you are looking for a fun and cheerful jRPG with a fantastic anime-like design, this is the right game for you!

24348271.review:
If you're looking for a quality game to scratch your JRPG itch, you've likely found it. In the vein of games within the "Tales Series", Fairy Fencer F is a solid (though slightly lower quality) version of those games. The story isn't incredible, but it gives you enough of an incentive to continuously engage in the entertaining combat. There is also an entertaining card collecting mechanic which assists in the modification of your characters' leveling and ability acquisition. The combat has some throwbacks to the flash the was present within some older JRPG titles and remained entertaining throughout.

+ Solid graphics
+ Flashy Combat moves
+ Comprehensive combat and controls
- Occasionally annoying characters
- Weak story
+ Great character leveling & ability system
+ Game length via plenty of content
+/- Occasionally awkward fan service

I'd recommend picking this game up if you're a JRPG vet that's played through most of your options on steam. If you can grab this game during a sale and you're really looking for some cool effects within a decent JRPG combat system, you should try this one out!

24299898.review:
I really want to recommend this game, but its flaws are just too egregious to make the plusses worthwhile.

[u]The first problem many people will find with the game is that it uses Direct Input rather than XInput.[/u]
This leads to two major problems:
It is impossible to correctly reconfigure the controls for some generic gamepads without spending an inordinate amount of time looking up code-descriptions and reading through guides in order to figure out how to edit the .ini file and get the camera-control working.
The game uses XBox-pad icons, but these do not correspond to generic button layouts, which means you have to use an image-editing program with *.dds filetype support in order to cut-and-paste the icons around in the keyboard.dds file in order for them to be mapped properly.

This is before you even get into the game itself, and took me hours to fix.  I posted the fixes on the forums, so it's possible that people with identical setups could now have this sorted in minutes if they know what they're looking for, though.

[u]The game has many elements that are simply broken[/u]
Whether its crafting recipes that require ingriedients that do not drop in the game at all (you have to hack the code using a third-party-program like Cheat Engine to make them work), or some that require multiple copies of an ingriedient that is UNIQUE and thus you cannot get more than one of without the aforementioned hacks;
or the "Seize" (steal) skill that seems to have a misplaced decimal in its success-rate, and thus you can spend half-an-hour spamming it against enemies too weak to damage you before it actually works.

And this is before you get to the litany of frankly [b]bizarre design choices[/b].
A "magic" and "skill" system that doesn't scale properly - so instead of choosing the "right tool for the job" you always need to spam the most powerful one for it to deal any damage - even if its a screen-wide AOE and you only want to injure one enemy.
An AOE system that is worthless because each of the abilities "knocks back" the enemies - spreading them out too far for any follow-up AOEs; as well as having inappropriately scaled templates so that often a low-level AOE literally means "one or two enemies only if you're lucky."
"Magic" is largely worthless - the Mana (SP) costs are too high early on for it to be viable for builds; and late-game it's too weak to be useful as anything other than "use the most powerful spell to one-shot trash for quicker clearing".
The elemental resistance system has such a negligible effect as to be worth ignoring.
The "Skill" system is identical to magic, except it uses the same stat (Physical Attack) as your combos, and thus is simply superior - making "Magic" even more redundant.

The weapon-combo system requires an inordinate amount of "Weapon Points" (WP) to fully unlock, which forces you to sit on your hands for ages with lame-duck characters; and because you're neglecting putting WP into the "Fairy Fury" stat, the game's unique selling point (turning into a fairy-powered pseudo-robot) is generally superfluous.  Even if you do put points into it, you're just looking at a 2% buff to your stats for every unit you upgrade.

[u]The game is painfully repetitive.[/u]
It uses a "travel back in time to the start of the game" gimmick to recycle assets and pad the length out - doubling the playtime from 5 hours to 12 hours.  This adds very little to the experience, although it does allow you to enjoy your levelled up characters a bit more and thus get juicier combat.
Unfortunately you then complete it again, and find that the "NG+" mode is essentially just another play through identical to the first; except now the enemies pose no challenge because you can one-hit them all.

Hell, if you equip the overpowered-as-hell DLC equipment the game throws at you from the start, you can have had this "I walk through the game suffering no damage and one-hitting everything" nonsense through your first play-through!

And all-the-while the side-quest system expects you to repeat zones you've already cleared using the "alternate enemies" Fury function, in order to farm those kills and their drops.

[u]The game locks you out of content with no warning or indication.[/u]
Think you've cleared all your side-quests in the Tavern?  Think you've got all the "Find a new Fairy sub-events"?  Double-checked to make sure no-one anywhere is prompting you for more?
Well, must be safe to complete the next event and move on, right?

WRONG.  Several events require you enter a dungeon - and then exit it [b]without completing it[/b] - in order to show up.  No indicators, no warning, no suggestion whatsoever that you should stop doing the only task you currently have issued to you and walk out of the dungeon the very second you walked into it.

The game punishes you for being efficient in how you clear the zones.  And these are MAJOR elements of content.
There's a character you can't unlock if you beat him while you're BELOW a specific level...  Whether you repeat content by grinding out the level; or by playing through the whole game in NG+ from scratch, they expect you to repeat it all again.

[u]The game takes every opportunity to waste your time[/u]
Whether it's a ridiculous drop-rate; or a frustrating crafting (synthesis) system; or sub-quests whose rewards are less than the value of the items they want you to turn in; or forcing you to play through AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN to maybe stumble across whatever you've missed...

[h1]The game comes across as one whose designer understands what elements are required of a JRPG, and has tossed them in with [b]no understanding of why they are there[/b] or [b]what purpose they serve.[/b][/h1]

Which is a shame, as the game has a lot of potential:  The characters are fun, the art-style is cool, the graphics are pretty good.

If it wasn't for the game constantly recycling its own content in order to pad out its length, it would be one I would recommend.

But ultimately there's between five and eight hours of gameplay here, but it has deliberately been padded out to about sixty hours of pointless frustrating unsatisfying and downright miserable busy-work.

[quote=Lola]"I love money! I love it so much I wish I could swin in a pool of cash! You could slap me with wad of bills and it wouldn`t hurt at all!"
 - Fairy Fencer F[/quote]
Fairy Fencer F - JRPG от Compile Heart и во многом похожа на старшую сестру - серию "Hyperdimenstion Neptunia".
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=745853135
[list]
    [*]Порадовал главный герой Фанг. Это не бравый спаситель мира, не ОЯШ, а реальный пофигист, который бездельничает и на начало игры оказывается в тюрьме за кражу еды. Ему буквально на голову падает фея Эрин, которая потеряла память, и наш герой, поворчав для проформы, соглашается ей помочь. И юмор и сюжет тут неплохи, но клишированы.
    [*]Костяк геймплея тут такой же как у Нептуний. Партия сражатся со своими врагами в боях при помощи пошаговой боевой системы, комбо на 3 кнопках, «Fairize» (местная HDD-форма). Дьявол, как всегда, кроется в деталях: кроме экипировки фей самим персонажам, их можно вонзать в карту (каждая фея привязана к своему оружию), что дает бонусы и штрафы в близлежащих подземельях; новые приёмы и заклинания изучаются за специальные Weapon Points, а каждый вид оружия обладает своей особенностью (например, косы часто критуют, а топоры наносят бонусный урон в воздухе - жаль что неплохая задумка убита балансом, можно спокойно пройти игру не замарачиваясь составлением замысловатых комбинаций ударов), а у каждого героя есть свой особый навык (у Фанга, к примеру, это "Serious Face" - да-да, я не опечатался).
    [*]Технически Fairy Fencer F звёзд с неба не хватает. Игра, конечно, выдаёт стабильные 60 FPS, но моделькам не хватает полигонов, а скудный дизайн локаций и врагов внушает уныние.
[/list]
7/10 - достойная JRPG, но, как и все игры от Compile Hearts, требует от вас быть поклонником, или поклонницей, аниме-стилистики и типично японских ролевых игр.
P.S. Отдельно отмечу ачивки. Такого лютого и бессмысленного гринда я давно не встречал.

24063718.review:
Please note - I've not played many JRPGs since I was a child, so this review is heavily based on the core game itself, and contains no comparisons to other games. Thus, avid JRPG fans may have a much different view from mine.

As many other reviews state, the game takes about 20-30 hours to complete your first runthrough of it, and boy is it worth it. The gameplay itself is good enough for what it is, and although the combat isn't anything revolutionary, the strategy in it is solid enough to make it very enjoyable. And as far as the story and characters... that's where the game comes into its own. There are three main characters, and a decently sized supporting cast that the game does a great job of fleshing out, which is surprising for side characters. Be prepared to laugh as well, as the main character's personality is hilarious at times, and the other characters all have their quircks that come out and incite laughter. Another amazing thing that I love about the game is the varied endings. There are three main endings, as well as multiple "secret" characters that you do things to obtain, all of whom affect the dialogue.
~~~
Pros
+ The cutscenes are quite nice, with high quality texture models and animations
+ Fairly in-depth combat, which is easy to grasp but also satisfying later in the game once you learn the ins and outs
+ AMAZING story, which will likely draw some tears at some points, and of course a plethora of laughs
+ The characters are all amazing in their own way, there will be some you despise, some you love, and some you just accept. There also is much development in the characters relationships to one another, and yes - there are love routes you can attain (which are done very tastefully, and this comes from a person who typically despises romance novels, animes, and games)
+ GREAT attack animations, which can actually keep you entertained at times, and I found myself sometimes just letting the animations play out rather than skipping them
+ Well done soundtrack, with over 50 songs that play at various times, and although some of them begin to get old (ESPECIALLY if you choose to grind), it's undeniable that a majority are actually very enjoyable to listen to. If you enjoy them enough, you can also use a converter to extract the soundtrack from the game files (.ogg to .mp3), and listen to them outside of the game.

Good/Bad
~ The main story requires little to no grinding, which I personally am fond of. I normally prefer to not need to bore myself of a game because I'm forced to grind in order to have a chance. If you play through the game with minimal grinding, you'll have some trouble at parts, but IMO that's the fun of it when you have your back to the wall, fighting with all you've got. Some grinding will be fine, especially in the second arc of the game, but DO NOT OVERGRIND! The main story will become very boring to play when you become OP.
~ Some purposely cringeworthy dialogue from the main protagonist, which will make you cringe but also laugh, and the side characters call him out on it.
~ Personally, I'm not a fan of the hilariously oversized weapons, but they do look awesome, and they're a standard characteristic of games of this type.

Bad
- Aside from a few dungeons, most of them are fairly bland, and the textures are often muddled. Of course, it's not the main purpose of the game to look beautiful, but I'd much rather the dungeons be more interesting
- Keyboard is fully playable, but if you have access to a controller I'd recommend you play it with that. However, I did make it through the game on nothing but M&K without changing controls, so it's not the worst I've seen
- Fps drops even on a good rig at times (GTX 970, i7 4790k, 16gb RAM), usually when loading the world map or a new dungeon where enemies are spawning, but it's brief and still only drops to about 30.

24019481.review:
日式奇幻風的回合制RPG

優點:
* 可自行搭配的連段系統
* 配樂不錯 很優雅
* 有些橋段很歡樂
* 精美的事件CG
* 人物配音很不錯
* 角色都蠻好看的不論敵方或我方幾乎都是帥哥美女
* 遊戲的風格是採用可愛的動畫風格 包含怪物敵人都是可愛風

缺點:
* 劇情的發展不合邏輯,也沒什麼分岐事件
* 遊戲需要花不少時間重覆農怪,賺錢買情報
* 故事演出略嫌簡略 有些重要場景甚至只有一張CG
(甚至有些事件遇到怪物 卻沒有怪物的演出只有一些吼聲...)
* 並沒有針對PC的操控特別調整過 操作起來非常彆扭
有些選單的按法真的很反人類 (最好用手把玩)

Fairy Fencer F 是個很純正的日式RPG
不論是玩法上或是劇情上

遊戲中有個年輕的主角,個性散漫,
但到重要時刻就會變成勇者救世主
雖然是個飯桶依然會有很多夥伴自己報上門來想變成夥伴

劇中的反派相當微妙
一分鐘前還很殘暴的想要把所有人弄死 
一分鐘後卻又對主角們手下留情... why?

雖然劇情與遊戲操作上有些瑕疵有點遺憾 

但本作算是那種休閒向的農怪遊戲 (連續攻擊,可以間隔3秒慢慢按都沒差)
幸運色狼或是搞笑的橋段也相當多.逗趣的角色演出常讓人會心一笑
玩起來其實很像在看動畫只是中間穿插了打怪練功過程

畢竟這是個家機的老遊戲 
內容幾乎是原封不動 移植到PC上的作品 (沒多什麼特別的東西)
所以還蠻常特價的(75%+) 不是很心癢癢可以等特價在入手

24007711.review:
The battle system is fast a fluid. The enemies, while repetitive, are quite interesting in both form, concept and art. The story on itself is good. The soundtrack? Oh my God, this is the game strongest forte. The endings, all three of them, are quite a hassle to get, specially since you have to run through this game 3 or 4 times to get every character, every fairy, every secret and every ending. The humor is fucking genious (I'm looking at you Galdo, Lola. XD)!

But there is one single, glaring issue: The characters.

Holy. Shit. Fang, Tiara and Eryn are the only ones you really get to know, but they are overall bland until you reach the second half of the game. Fang is the most developed out of everyone. The stories of Galdo, Ethel and Apollonius are the better parts this game has to offer. The rest? Meh at best. But Sherman? Fuck this guy. I kinda liked him at the start but after the second arc begins...no...just no.

The Grind-Fest for the Shukawhatever tower is pure pain, but you can advance incredibly fast and the rewards are worth it.

The Fairyze forms are great! (WTF is up with Pippin? And why the FUCK must Paiga have the most badass looking Fairyze form out of everyone?)

Anyways, I give this game a 8.5/10. I regret nothing and it was fun to play, what more can I ask for? It's a solid JRPG with more heart than most I've played in these past three years. It has some problems and errors but it's soooo worth it to play it.

23960317.review:
Okay, here's my thoughts on this game.  Value them as you may.

Graphics: 3/5.  Heavy on the polygon side, some of the characters seem to have some hit boxes still rather than a more smooth circle or sphere.  The dungeons look nice, but there aren't that many of them.  I would say that some of the dungeons probably were underdeveloped or potentially rushed.  To be sure, they could have put a tad more thought to it.

Audio: 3/5 The voice acting is solid enough in both English and Japanese.  There are some minor problems with the English characters (a couple of them sound whiny even when they're talking normally, which tended to grate on me).  The music is a little generic, but the songs used for the "speical power" mode do fit nicely.

Battles: 1/5 There's not a lot here.  It's a button smash, where you don't need to use the special abilities.  Almost EVERY fight, including the final boss, can be beatdown with a faceroll.  This detracts heavily from the overall "fun" factor.

Gameplay: 2/5 There isn't a lot of gamplay per se.  You go to a dungeon, of which there are 8 or so, kill the stuff that needs killing and go back to town.  Given all the dungeons are just a matter of moving the cursor and hitting "enter", it's not that hard to find.  There's no real "overworld" like you expect in a RPG, or even some adventure games.  Town options are limited.

Story: 2/5.  It's pretty standard fare: gather X and save the freaking world.  How it goes about it is somewhat different though.

Fun factor: 3/5.  The characters have some great lines between them.  Some of them are unlikable and the ones that ARE likable are ones you can get behind.

DLC: 3/5.  The good news here is that it's CHEAP (I think it's $5 or less for all of it).  The bad news is that the DLC adds in some extra dungeons (mainly rehashes or established ones at higher difficulty levels), and practically unbalances the game.  I mean, you don't need to buy ANYTHING in-game with the weapons the DLC offers.

Overall: It's not a great game by any criteria you can apply to it.  It is an easy enough romp, and stuff you can go through without a guide or instructions.  I'd probably call this a "weekender".  If it's on sale, it'd be worth it.

23924138.review:
I purchased this game on a whim.. I wasnt expecting it to be anything good.
Ohh how wrong I was.

Short version : If you like JRPGs in general this is a good one. PC port is good, has keyboard cues & mouse support.Has English voice overs

Long Version :
But first I should mention that Im already a fan of Animes & JRPGs & other popular Japanese stuff in general even tho im not one. So I dont really find fantasy stories & themes like this awkward as some others do.
I dont usually play games for long stretches unless its a competitive multiplayer game or a really hard game which im tryin to beat but cant(example:dark souls). But occasionally there will be compelling games which you just cant put down because they give u just the right amount of depth & enjoyment.I guess thats what the RPG genre is known for but many RPGs fail in some way & end up being a boring chore. It can be uinteresting characters to unresponsive world.

Fairy Fencer F is not even an open world RPG. Its a typical JRPG,safe city zone where u manage ur party & dungeons for questing & grinding. But even then It kept me going... I just didn't get bored at all, the grind did not feel like boring grind. I cared for the characters & enjoyed the music & combat animations. Its not one thing which makes it good. Its all the little bits that combine & polish this to near perfection. Add to that english voice overs & a PC port which does not disappoint. It even shows keyboard button cues on screen, yes you can play with keyboard & mouse just fine. And just like most JRPGs it has very in-depth(sometimes confusing)Player development(I mean stats.. like buffing up your character in different ways).Although all confusion can be cleared by reading through the mini-teaching sections which pop up everytime you open a new menu or encounter something new.Im not even mentioning the absoulutely hilarious conversations the lazy protagonist has with his companions, which are a treat to listen to everytime.

At last.. this game is a typical JRPG & a good one at that & the fact that its a JRPG so it may not be for everyone, as the title mentions that its a turned based combat game. But if you're into that sort of thing like me, then look no further. 
If you're still in doubt I suggest you buy the game & play it for 1 or 2 hours & then decide whether its your taste or not, you can refund it if you did not spend more than 2 hours  & 15 days on it. The first 2 hours of the game will stand a good judge of the game trust me.. unlike some other games which start off good & fade into boredom.

Now if you'll excuse me.. I'll go back to gathering more Furies or food

PS: I've never played Hyperdimension Neptunia so I cannot compare, but others say its similar so if you like that... you may like this.

23661690.review: I bought this game and it's DLC a few months ago and never played it until a week ago. This game is fantastic. Of course, this game also contains the original Japanese voice acting which is also supurb and is fully subtitled in English. The game has a unique weapon and stat upgrade system; in most RPGs the player would obtain skills and spells as they level up, however Fairy Fencer F has a Weapon Point system where the player gains WP after each battle, and that WP is then used to purchase skills, magic, and other upgrades. I highly recommend this game for those who like Eastern RPGs and for those looking for an entry RPG game.

23408036.review:
Au terme d'une aventure d'une quarantaine d'heures j'entrevois les crédits de fin avec une once de nostalgie. Nous avons là un bon vieux JRPG qui reprend les codes du genre avec ses qualités et ses défauts le tout remis au goût du jour. Un jeu que je conseille sans hésitation car j'ai passé de bons moments dessus, comme d'habitude je vais tenter de décrypter les différents aspects afin d'aider les personnes indécises à l'idée de l'acquérir ou non.


- [b]Graphiquement déjà[/b], car c'est la première chose que l'on voit du jeu, je suis assez partagé on va dire. D'un côté tout le plan 2D avec les artworks des personnages et des décors sont splendides, de l'autre la 3D est vraiment inégale : les personnages sont bien modélisés et dotés de textures très fines alors que les décors dans lesquels on évolue donnent une impression de travail fait en vitesse. Après ça ne me gêne pas tellement mais il est bon de le savoir je trouve. Par ailleurs niveau diversité d'environnements c'est pas non plus la grande joie, on évolue dans des donjons totalement linéaires, il y en a un de glace, un de feu, un dans des plaines, un autre dans un désert, un sur des îles flottantes et d'autres dans des sortes de ruines robotiques. Il y a bien des variantes mais ça ne change vraiment pas grand chose. Donc oui, beaucoup de recyclage dans les environnements en sachant qu'il y a une vingtaine de donjons dans le jeu. En parlant de réemploi les monstres souffrent aussi de ce problème à savoir qu'on croise souvent les mêmes modèles de créatures mais avec des skins différents, c'est assez regrettable je trouve mais pas rédhibitoire non plus.

Mention spéciale aux phases de dialogues entre les personnages : les artworks 2D en plus d'être magnifiques sont animés de façon très naturelle (ils bougent légèrement, clignent des yeux, respirent etc). Je n'avais encore jamais rencontré une telle technique d'animation dans un JRPG et je suis totalement bluffé. 

Par ailleurs les effets visuels en combat sont très réussis.

- [b]D'un point de vue audio[/b], on a accès aux voix japonaises et ça c'est vraiment génial. La plupart des phases de dialogue sont doublées ce qui renforce vraiment l'immersion. Les musiques sont nombreuses, appropriées et agréables, rien à redire à ce niveau.

- [b]Le gameplay maintenant[/b]. C'est du tour par tour où on contrôle 3 personnages simultanément parmi 6 disponibles, on évolue dans une arène en 3D où on les déplace à notre guise (avec une limite de de portée par tour quand même). Après pour le reste c'est du classique niveau JRPG : un mouvement et une attaque par tour. Il y a quand même pas mal de subtilités qui rendent le système combat unique et très agréable. (nos héros peuvent notamment entrer dans un mode ultime pendant un court laps de temps ou encore lancer quelques aptitudes uniques)

D'un point de vue personnalisation les protagonistes montent évidemment en niveau et au fil des combats on peut attribuer des points pour augmenter soit leurs caractéristiques brutes (attaque, défense, portée etc) soit débloquer de nouveaux sorts/attaques. Le jeu dispose d'un système d'enchaînements d'attaques très intéressant. On commence avec une attaque par tour et à la fin du jeu chaque personnage pourra lancer un combo composé de 4 attaques en sachant que l'on peut créer ses propres enchainements à partir de nombreuses techniques de bases qui auront toutes leurs utilités selon la situation.

En plus de ça il y a évidemment un marchand auprès duquel on pourra acheter de nouveaux équipements, on accède également à un système de craft assez rapidement. Chaque personnage peut être lié à une "divinité" qui pourra monter en niveaux et donnera accès à de nombreux bonus passifs.

La progression se fait, comme je l'ai dit au début, par le biais d'une carte du monde dans laquelle on se déplace pour aller dans des donjons. La ville principale sert de lieu d'accueil où on peut trouver des commerces, une taverne et d'autres zones... il y est possible de parler avec nos compagnons mais aussi à pas mal d'habitants pour y récupérer des quêtes secondaires et faire évoluer l'histoire principale.

La difficulté du jeu est assez étrange, la première moitié est très simple mais arrivé à la seconde on se retrouve pas mal dans l'embarras. Ca m'a obligé à farm pendant quelques heures pour me remettre à niveau mais rien de bien affolant, tous les adeptes de JRPG sont habitués à ce genre de pratique. :p

- [b]A présent place au scénario[/b], je l'ai trouvé plutôt intéressant. Pas spécialement original mais les personnages ont tous leur personnalité, ils sont attachants et il y a plusieurs fins possibles. Le tout m'a tenu en halène pendant ces quarante heures sans aucun problème. Attention les sous titres sont uniquement disponibles en anglais, le niveau d'écriture n'est pas forcément très soutenu mais il faut quand même posséder des bases relativement solides pour suivre le scénario avec aisance.

- [b]La durée de vie[/b] du jeu est honorable, on est dans la moyenne des JRPG modernes on va dire. Pas loin de 50 heures pour boucler la quête principale ainsi que les secondaires en sachant que je n'ai pas terminé les DLC et que je n'ai pas cherché à obtenir les 3 fins différentes, ça laisse de quoi faire !

Enfin les DLC ne sont pas utiles pour un sou, ce ne sont que des items cosmétiques ainsi que des objets spéciaux visant à faciliter un peu l'expérience du jeu. Disons qu'au mieux cela économise quelques heures de farm. Un des DLC débloque également 3 zones d'xp de très haut niveau où il est plus simple de trouver certains objets rares. Il faut donc voir ces DLC comme des codes de triches ou des trainers payants, on peut tout à fait s'en passer car ils ne font qu'accélérer la progression pour les joueurs les moins courageux ou ceux désirant uniquement se concentrer sur la trame principale.


Donc voilà, bilan très positif pour le grand amateur de JRPG à l'ancienne que je suis. J'attends avec impatience la suite (Fairy Fencer F : Advent Dark Force) qui est annoncée fin juin sur PS4 en Europe et un peu plus tard sur PC. C'est vraiment chouette que de plus en plus de jeux de rôle japonais sortent sur PC surtout qu'ici le portage est tout à fait satisfaisant, le titre tourne comme un charme en 1080P et je n'ai rencontré aucun bug, ralentissement ou plantage.

23375324.review:
Meh... can't say too much about this. Took about 20 hours to beat but wasn't very difficult to do so. Bosses are pretty easy all the way to the end. I only got one ending  out of three apparently but I'm not feeling too motivated to get the other two. I was really playing for the sake of knowing what happened at the end and it wasnt very satisfying i have to say. Pretty cliche anime-type ending but I wasn't expecting much more than that.

Characters weren't bad but if you are familiar with anime or manga at all they all fit into the typical character types, which is  pretty much a given as soon as you are introduced to the main character. Cliche as they are they are still fun to listen to. 

The sound and music are decent but nothing special at all and you quickly realize there isn't a very large musical score to accompany the game and you'll here the same tunes over and over again.

The areas are pretty small  and there really isn't any exploring. There is an ability to search for inivisible items but I hardly used it because just didnt seem worth it.

There is a "game-plus" mode where you play the game again with what appears to be levels and abililties from your previous clear but honestly not sure why you would do that.

Gameplay was alright, better than FFXIII but that isn't saying much there. 

Overall I wouldn't buy this unless it's on sale. It isn't bad but it won't ever go on my list of favorite games.

I think there is like a sequel but I do not think it's on Steam.

23010218.review:
Jrpg del bueno como cabía esperar de los creadores de Hyperdimension. Este juego es curioso porque tiene un tono general de humor y de no tomarse nada en serio pero luego hay unos giros argumentales y algunos temas que cambian bastante ese tono, te pilla bastante por sorpresa. 
La historia no es que sea lo más original , pero entretiene y deja una base muy buena para avanzar. Los personajes son muy buenos, cada cual con sus peculiaridades y rarezas xD. El diseño de personajes está genial, con chicas para todos los gustos, como tiene que ser! xD. 
En cuanto a gameplay, se parece mucho a los hyperdimension pero con un sistema de combate algo renovado aunque muy parecido, siguiendo el tema de combate por turnos en el que te puedes mover por el campo de batalla y usar ataques que tienen un rango de acción diferente cada uno. Luego tienen las transformaciones especiales que te hacen más fuerte. Todo se evoluciona mediante puntos , tanto para aprender habilidades como para mejorar al personaje. Los ataques especiales de cada personaje son geniales, con animaciones muy curradas y epicas y con fanservice incluido también xD.

El prota del juego también es bastante original ya que no es el típico heroe, más bien solo quiere comer y hacer el vago xD. Pero se irá implicando cada vez más por supuesto, pero es bastante diferente a lo que nos tienen acostumbrados.

En general muy divertido, tanto por el guión como por el juego en si. De lo poco negativo que le veo, a parte de estar en ingles (aunque a mi no me molesta, pero es un impedimiento para muchos otros) ,  es que es bastante repetitivo el desarrollo y además se repiten muchos escenarios porque te hacen revisitar los lugares. Desde luego se han ahorrado modelar escenarios así xD. El final es algo escueto también y esperaba un poco más pero bueno...

En fin, juego que recomiendo a todos los amantes de los jrpg como yo, sobre todo si habeis disfrutado de los hyperdimension neptunia, este seguro que os gusta también. Si no te gustan los juegos de rol... no se que haces leyendo esto xD. Y si, también tiene fanservice, trajes chulos y hasta una loli saca cuartos y una pettanko ninja. Calidad certificada xD.

23000132.review:
Fairy Fencer F is a light hearted and funny "budget" JRPG with lots of charm.  You play as a reluctant hero trying to unite the powers of ancient fairy fueled weapons to save the world or at least score some free food along the way.  The combat is an absolute blast with lots of characters to build, weapons to customize and power ups to manage.  The action is fast paced and satisfying, although a bit easy at times and gets repetitive.  The presentation is the "budget" part unfortunately.  The story is told with 2D cartoony cut scenes, with fantastic voice work and some genuinely funny dialog.  However you never really get to explore the towns, country side or world you are trying to save, just the dungeons.  This lack of interaction results in a fantasy world that lacks any weight to it.  I lost interest about half way thru the experience once I grew tired of the combat and party management strong suites of the game.

If you love JRPG's, especially the combat and character development, then you will enjoy Fairy Fencer.  However the lack of interaction with the story and the out of dungeon world will be a turn off to those looking for a more polished and complete RPG experience.

I'd strongly recommend it to anyone who enjoys JRPGs.

22860967.review:
Eine nette Mischung aus Visual-Novel und leichtem RPG.

[b]Vorab:[/b]
Ich habe Hyperdimension Neptunia noch nicht gespielt, mag aber kitschige Anime-Spiele allgemein sehr gern (z.B. Aura Kingdom, Secret of Mana, Chrono Trigger, Kingdom Hearts). Das Spiel hab ich bisher einmal durchgespielt, und zwar mit Japanischem Ton.

[b]Review:[/b]
Die kitschige Story hat mir gut gefallen (nicht übermäßig gut, aber okay). Das Setting ist insgesamt sehr stimmig und macht gute Laune, teilweise wird es auch sehr dramatisch.

Das Kampfsystem ist ganz nett, aber eher anspruchslos. Es ist eher wenig Strategie oder Geschick nötig, um durch die Kämpfe durchzukommen. Für mich waren die Kämpfe eher angenehme Beilage, der Schwerpunkt lag für mich auf der Story.

Wer Animes lieber mit japanischem Ton schaut, und vielleicht auch etwas Japanisch kann, dem kann ich die japanische Sprachausgabe SEHR empfehlen. Ich selbst kann Japanisch auf fortgeschrittenem Anfänger-Level, und vieles war für mich gut zu verstehen - so konnte ich nebenbei mein Hör-Verstehen trainieren. Die Synchronsprecher haben wirklich tolle Arbeit geleistet, es ist einfach ein Ohrenschmaus den Dialogen zuzuhören. Zur englischen Sprachausgabe kann ich nicht viel sagen, vermutlich bringt diese aber nicht das Feeling so gut rüber wie die japanische.

Auch kann man, wenn man will, einige optionale Ziele im Spiel erreichen. Items sammeln und fusionieren, starke Waffen sammeln und mit verschiedenen Methoden die Stats weiter erhöhen - was am Ende aber nicht viel bringt da die Kämpfe nicht sehr schwierig sind. Trotzdem eine gute Zugabe.

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Nicht uneingeschränkt empfehlbar, aber wenn man keine allzu hohen Ansprüche an das Spiel stellt, dann ist es eigentlich ganz gut.

Am besten kann man das Spiel genießen, wenn man das Augenmerk auf die gute Story/Dialoge legt, und alles andere als nette Beilage betrachtet. Wer gerne auf kleine Details und eine stimmige Atmosphäre achtet wird das Spiel mögen. Fans von kitschigen Animes und Visual-Novels sind hier sehr gut aufgehoben. Action und Anspruch wird man hier eher nicht finden, dafür ist das Spiel nicht gemacht - vielleicht ist das auch ganz gut so, denn so bleibt das Spiel eher leicht und heiter.

Kampfsystem 4/10
Story 6/10
Japanische Visual-Novel 9/10
