22756232.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]

Fairy Fencer F is a turn-based, action, role-playing game loaded with charming characters. The action takes place in a world where a God and Goddess were in a fight to the death. Their terrible struggle left a fantastic assortment of powerful weapons littering the landscape. You will find not everyone who tries has the ability to wield these relics. It is only those who are worthy of them that can pull them free. Fencers wield these weapons with the assistance of the fairy that resides within the weapon. For once, you are not really saving the world. At the beginning, there really is no peril that a hero/heroine must raise to defeat. In fact, the protagonist of this game isn’t even really a hero at all.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game is a mixture of a visual novel and an action role-playing game. The story is driven by discussions the playable characters hold as well as their interactions with the NPCs. During the discussions, a static image of the characters is on screen. To emphasize which character is doing the talking, that particular character will have an animated mouth. Emotions are conveyed through a mixture of symbols and facial expressions. If the characters are having a story based discussion, it will be fully voice acted. If it is a random conversation, it will generally be just text on the screen. This works quite well although I do prefer the voiced sections over the just text sections. 

When in town you simply select between the various options and you enter into the related screen. You do not need to walk to the item shop or inn when you arrive at the town. This is handy because it saves you from having to remember where each place is and having to run back and forth between them constantly, but I still prefer to have explore-able towns. Dungeons are thankfully free to explore when you get to them. The world map is simple to navigate, it shows places you have already opened and explored. It also conveniently has your next destination(s) flagged on the map as well as where any events or sub-events may be taking place. 

Dungeons are where you are going to spend most of your time (outside of dialogues between characters). You are free to roam around as you please. Monsters can be seen wandering around and you have the option to fight them or attempt to avoid them. If you choose to fight them, you can attempt to get a preemptive strike by swinging your weapon right before the battle screen is triggered. If successful, all your characters will get a chance to strike the enemy first. If you fail or if the enemy sneaks up on you, you will be the one ambushed giving the enemies the chance to strike first. Just walking into an enemy will put your characters and enemies in that standard cue to fight. The fight cue is always displayed and lets you know who will get their turn next. When you are controlling a character in combat, you have a movement circle. You can move anywhere in that circle before you take your action. Once you take your action, your turn ends and the next in cue gets to take theirs. Since each weapon type and ability has its own range and effective arcs, it makes for a nice variety when playing.

The game has a lot of customization options available to you. While you can’t change your weapon, you can reconfigure it so it changes into a different type of weapon during combat. You are given free choice of what armor and accessories you want to wear as well as your secondary fairy. To make up for the fact you can’t change your weapon, you are given weapon points after battles. These can be spent on how you want to customize the weapon and your related weapon abilities. If you prefer to do a lot of simple physical attacks, that is great. You can set yourself up that way. Do you prefer getting really high combo scores? Well you can buy new combos too. There are a ton of customizations options and luckily you are not locked into your decisions as taking one of the ability does not preclude you from taking a different one later. With enough grinding, you can max out everything for every character.

Fairies make this game more interesting. They do that in three ways.  The first is the fact that when your Tension gauge fills (fills when you do damage or takes damage, but reduces when you miss or heal yourself), you gain the ability to merge with your weapon’s fairy and become much more powerful. Another way the fairies are interesting is that you can acquire new ones as you play. While you can never swap out your main fairy (fused to your weapon) you can swap out your secondary fairy. You can customize the abilities of the secondary fairy to some degree as well. When you acquire a new one, if you equip it, it will level up and gain new abilities. You can also merge it with one of the sealed weapons found impaling the fallen God and Goddess that I mentioned earlier. By merging it, you gain new abilities for the secondary fairy. The third way they are interesting is the fact that you can stick a fairy imbued weapon into the ground to “shape the world” using the shaping abilities of the fairy. This changes up how dungeons work as well as adds extra levels to a tower in the game. By sticking the shaping weapon into the ground, you will get positive and negative effects that will change how the dungeon will play out. You may get extra experience while doing the dungeon, but you will take more damage from magical attacks. It might even change the enemies in the dungeon making it feel a little different when you go through it.

The story and characters in this game diverge a little from the standard clichés for this type of game as well. Instead of being a band of heroic figures rallying to save the world, you have a band of misfits each doing it for their own personal and selfish reasons. The protagonist of the game doesn’t even want to do it. He just pulled a sword out of the ground because someone told him it would grant him any wish he could think of. All he wanted to wish for was a nice meal. He accidentally became linked to the fairy in the sword who then forced him to go on the quest because she has amnesia and wants the other fairies to help her remember her past. Another Fencer is out for her own personal gains and is really full of herself. Another is just studying fairies… you get the idea. None of them are actually real heroes! That makes this game much more fun than the cliché, “let’s save the world from evil” shticks of other RPG games. 

Overall, it’s another enjoyable Idea Factory game. If you like the story telling, humour and fan service found in their other games, such as the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, you will likely enjoy Fairy Fencer F as well. If you are looking for a fun dungeon crawler style RPG that has zany characters, by all means give Fairy Fencer F a go.

[list]Pros:

[*]It’s long and made longer by having to continue the game in New Game Plus to actually beat the game fully
[*]A lot of customization options including cosmetic changes to the characters
[*]Fun characters that all feel like they do have their own personality. Even the NPCs don’t feel bland or generic
[*]Good use of music
[*]From the drawn visuals of the characters in the discussion scenes to the models used in the dungeons, the game looks good
[*]Not the typical save the world from the bad guy story
[*]Each dungeon feels unique, it isn’t just the same basic enemies and layout rehashed every time

Cons:

[*]DLC make you over-powered if activated too early which might ruin the fun and challenge
[*]Protagonist makes it hard for a person on a diet. (He constantly talks about food)[/list]

22753249.review:
[b]Fairy Fencer F[/b] is a nice little mixture of visual novel and RPG style game mechanics and combat. You play as Fang, a guy who ends up acquiring a Fury without realising the responsabilities that come with it. Furies are swords left on the planet long ago after a battle between the Vile God and the Goddess, and each of them has a fairy inside. The fairy inside your Fury, Eryn, explains to you that the Fury is only able to use to those who are destined to fulfill the wish of its fairy. She then explains to you that she wishes you find 100 Furies in order to awake the Goddess. This is where your journey begins.

[b][u]Gameplay overview:[/u][/b]
We could say that the gameplay of this game is divided into two very different genres. For me, the real meat of the game is the combat, which despite being somewhat repetitive, allows for a lot of different approaches due to the variety of abilities that you can use. Combat is turn based, and in each turn you move your character freely inside a circle and must get within range of the enemy in order to attack. If you get close to this outer circle you can attempt to escape the battle. You’ll be able to to switch between Fencers on the fly, once you have more on your party, but doing so while in combat will end your turn. As you acquire more Furies, you’ll also gain access to more fairies which you can use to increase your stats and get hold of more abilities. Not only that, but acquiring more Furies allow you to start working your way to free the Goddess, or the Vile God if you prefer, and will also enhance your fairy abilities.

The other part of the game plays pretty much like a kinetic visual novel, in which the player has no actual impact on the conversations and outcomes. That said, I find the dialogue to be rather amusing, if somewhat uninspired. If you’re looking for a deep story, great plot and memorable characters you probably won’t find that here. Still, I find the dialogue rather funny with the ocasional joke here and there, and most of the characters behave like teenagers which gives the game a less serious tone. Also, most of the main story dialogue is fully voice acted, while optional conversations are not.

You’ll be spending a lot of your time revisiting [i]Zelwinds[/i] the main city in the game. Here you can go to different places and talk with random people. You’re also able to buy and sell items, get side missions (kill & fetch quests) and acquire information about the whereabouts of the next Fury. Still, the city feels somewhat lifeless since everything happens through a menu screen. There is no depth to the places and to the different people you find there, they are pretty much there just for the sake of being there, and this made me care less about the actual game world.

There is also a world map where you can go to various different locations, such as dungeons. There you’ll battle enemies and find varied items. Inside dungeons you can move freely and see enemies wandering, and if you manage to get in close and attack them you’ll trigger an ambush and the battle will start, thus allowing to attack first. Of course, if the enemy gets the drop on you, you’ll be the one getting ambushed. This is probably where I spent most of my time, grinding in dungeons to level up my characters and fairies, doing side quests, collecting items and selling them so that I could afford potions, etc. If you’re not too fond of grinding, you might have a hard time later on with some enemies.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b][list]
[*]Good looking anime style visuals
[*]Tons of customization and unlockables
[*]Great soundtrack - featuring pieces from different musical genres
[*]Fun turn-based combat - with tons of different abilities
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b][list]
[*]Repetitive dungeons
[*]Lifeless locations & bland NPCs
[/list]

[b][u]Final verdict:[/u][/b]
If you’re looking for a memorable story and unique characters you might want to steer away from this, unless you’re a hardcore fan of the Neptunia games and the likes of Idea Factory. The story might be interesting for some people until a certain point, and most of the character reactions are rather predictable. Still, if you’re looking for a solid RPG experience with a very robust turn-based combat system this might be something right up your alley. There are tons of unlockables for you to track down, and if you’re into completing side quests there are always some for you to do. Thus, revisiting old dungeons will always yield some kind of reward.

[b]Overall, I’m enjoying my time with Fairy Fencer F, despite its flaws. If you’re unsure it is worth the full price, grab it on sale. Chances are, if you’ve read this far, you’ll most likely enjoy it.[/b]

22752127.review: It's been years since an JRPG captivated my attention long enough to make it to the end. Fairy Fencer F follows the usual game mechanics seen in the company's other titles, however, I feel Fencer is a notch above the rest of them. The story feels more structured, the music is pure nostalgia, and every character you encounter is memorable in their own right. The story is the usual JRPG fare, mixed with self-aware jokes that are perfectly timed, and plenty of dialouge to flesh out every character, as any good RPG should do. As someone who grew up playing games like Lunar and its sequal, Fencer felt right at home to me. This title is so enjoyable that even a second playthrough after the credit roll is worth it, just to find, synthesize and collect everything that was missing the first time around. My ONLY con about this game is the FPS, which can be adjusted in the game's .ini file. But honestly, that's a minor nuisance to a game that entertained me from begin to end.

你不是萌豚？对不起，我们友谊的小船翻了。

游戏的战斗系统虽然说没有什么非常惊艳的要素，但是也没啥反人类设定，而且上手简单。各种技能的效果也能说得上华丽，战斗ｂｇｍ的契合度非常棒，变身的ｂｇｍ很不错。不过所有人啥时候都是这首，后期打得多了可能有那么一点厌倦吧···终极大招极度败笔，不仅需要大量的蓝，还要废掉大半血量，然而实际造成的伤害并没有什么一击定乾坤的效果，打杂鱼浪费，打ｂｏｓｓ不痛不痒。
装备系统，合成系统，支线任务更有一种然并卵的感觉···装备最大的用途是给妹子们换装。你要玩奇迹汉子环游世界当然我也没意见。怪物掉落实在太多了，然而并没有啥记忆的需要，因为基本上都是毫无存在感的支线任务相关，打到东西去城里交任务就是了。合成出来的基本也都是各种然并卵的东西。唯一有用的是合成了几个珠子才能开启场景和“副本”，以及如果没有飞行鞋，你在最后一关的地图里将会面对一个极度反人类的极限跳····
剧情的话，基本就是日系萌向ａｃｇ的一贯走势，后期有略微的赶进度之感。日常情节有不少有趣的脑洞与吐槽，好评。主线上，男主角从没心没肺的杀伐果断到开始反思犹豫的过度虽然说很经（ｇｏｕ）典（ｘｕｅ），但是好评的是并没有无脑圣母。对于配角的刻画，谁是捡来的简直一目了然，归根到底，这是一个萌豚向游戏····

本作的反人类要素主要都体现在那个刷刷刷上了，如果你是成就党我倒真不敢推荐···无脑刷只会破坏你对游戏的印象的。

The lead character, Fang, starts out aggressively annoying and Tiara is only a little better at the beginning as well. Fortunately, the two have character arcs and they do grow and get a lot more engaging. Some of the achievements are way too grindy and if you don't have the DLC dungeons, then it could take days to get 100,000,000 gold. The same is true of many of the challenges, but fortunately, you don't need to complete any of the challenges to have powerful characters.

22241918.review:
Fairy Fencer F is a JRPG that ticks most of the right boxes, and carries a certain amount of charm with it. However, it has a lot of untapped potential that bears mentioning-- potential that other games made by the same company might fulfill better.

The premise of the game is somewhat bland-- there's a good deity and an evil deity, they hate each other, and mortals want them revived. They can do this by collecting Furies, which are magic weapons scattered around the world. Mostly by accident, the main character Fang gets wrapped up in the plot because he unseals a Fury by accident.

The story is lighthearted for the most part, barely dipping into troubled territory later on. Expect a lot of self-referential humor and Anime Silliness sprinkled throughout, and enough fanservice to bear mentioning, but not enough to feel egregious. I got the feeling that the story was played very safely, barely deviating from several common anime tropes. While it was certainly done well enough, it wasn't really the strongest part of the game overall, especially later on when you must repeat several areas of the game.

Locations are greatly varied, but none of them really stuck out to me, and the enemy design and overall art direction was also pretty standard anime fare. Expect a lot of reskinned enemies and common thematic areas-- the fire zone, ice zone, desert zone, windy zone, etc.. Overall, the setting works for the game, but like the plot it feels like it was just playing it safe. The best part of the locales is the World Shaping ability, which allows players to give unique effects to areas like increasing EXP gains and drop rates in return for losing HP gain or silencing spells.

The combat is the standout part of the game. You command a group of three Fury-wielding fighters, and take turns against your enemies on a 3D map. Characters can move within a circle around them and attack within a smaller range around them. If you've upgraded a Fury to do so, basic attacks can combo together for more damage overall, and since Furies are magical, they can shift their form to several different weapons. Most monsters have specific weaknesses to certain weapon types, and attacking these can chain together even more attacks from allies nearby. Attack animations are quick and flashy, with big effects and pronounced swings. Skills and Magic are also available, and are even flashier, with full-screen animations. However, while each character's skills and attack spells are unique, characters have at most 9 different skills and attack spells. Since some spells and skills are stronger than others, I found myself seeing the animations for the stronger skills (like Fang's Eruption Edge) over and over again later on, which made a flashy, cool animation somewhat mundane.

Characters can also Fairize, a transformation power that combines them and their weapon for more power. It's very flashy and changes the music, as well as making almost every encounter laughably easy. It also unlocks the use of an HP draining ultimate ability, but I rarely used these. Strangely, the devs decided to give every character a skill that they can use while not transformed that's more powerful and cheaper than the ultimate skill. This added up to more viewings of Eruption Edge, and more frustration. Characters also have a special ability, but to be honest, I never used these. They take a turn to toggle or use, and I usually felt that it was better to just deal damage.

However, the combat is marred by its sheer volume. While it's easy to get from story point to story point, since characters join the party with effectively no training, if you get a new character you like, you have to stop and grind. Even with World Shaping to take the edge off, the grind will take up many hours of a standard playtime.

At a discount, Fairy Fencer F is a good purchase for JRPG fans. There's even DLC to raise the level cap by 900 levels for some reason (???).

Opening this game after a few months and already feeling the nostalgia.

I bought this game the moment it came out. I don't regret it cause was very easy and a pleasure to play for a noob such as me. Really, you could be the worst player in the world who lost to Punchbag Bob, but you can't go wrong in Fairy Fencer F. I realised I may as well have been playing some kind of a nuzlocke because none of my party ever got KOd.

I HATE farming, but in this game it wasn't so bad. Characters get 'Weapon Points' for each battle you win, these WP are used to unlock attacks/skills and you can spend them to unlock whatever you want in ANY order. It's quite liberating and as killing enemies wasnt too hard either, unlocking all those skills felt achievable once I saw how much WP I was getting. "Next...Next...Neext....Neeeext!!" I didn't get it until I started farming like this haha.

I enjoyed playing through the story. I enjoyed the farming. I want to play more games like this...

21849841.review:
Ich hatte das Spiel schon länger im Blick, der Preis schreckte mich aber immer wieder ab. Als es dann im Angebot war, schlug ich zu und bereue den Kauf in keiner Form!

~Vorsicht! Diese Review ist in einigen Punkten mit Spoilern übersät~


- Story -
Was ist denn so schwer daran, Furies, Schwerter mit magischen Kräften versehend, zu sammeln, mithilfe dessen die Göttin wiederzubeleben und dabei den Weltfrieden wiederherzustellen? Nun, Fang, der Protagonist, kam halbverhungert in einer Stadt an und bekam von Dorfbewohnern zu Ohren, dass wenn er dieses eine Schwert namens Fury aus dem Boden zieht, bekommt er einen Wunsch erfüllt. Diese Chance lässt er sich nicht entgehen, dennoch als er es herauszieht erscheint Eryn, eine Fairy, die den Fang zum Fencer erklärt. Dieser jedoch will nur seinen Wunsch erfüllt bekommen: essen, essen und essen.

Ein richtiger Müßiggänger und halbherzig darauf interessiert, was seine Aufgaben und Pflichten eines Fencers sind, zogen beide los nach Sol Plains, wo sich eine Fury aufhalten soll. Unterwegs begegnen sie Tiara, ein Mädchen, welches mit ihrem Tee Fang kurzzeitig lähmt und es sich herausstellt, dass auch sie eine Fencer ist und hinter dem Fury her ist.

Nach einiger Zeit stoßen immer mehr eher merkwürdige als auch epische Charaktere in deine Party als auch auf einige interessante Feinde wie z.B. Paiga von der Dorfa Company; ein Waschlappen, wie er im Buche steht.

Die Wiederbelebung der Göttin war so gut wie vollzogen, doch ein Kampf brach mit Soldaten der Dorfa Company aus und in diesem Durcheinander passierte es: Tiara wurde umgebracht. Wut staute sich in Fang an und als die Göttin schließlich wiederbelebt wurde, sprach er nur einen Wunsch aus: er will Tiara wiedersehen!

Ein kleiner Lichtblitz erfolgte und...

__________________________

- Charaktere -
Mir ist immer wichtig, dass Charaktere ihre eigenen Macken haben und sich auch sehr unterscheiden. Denn nur so ist das perfekte Chaos vorprogrammiert. Fang mit seinen unstillbaren Hunger, die masochistische Tiara, welche doch im Kerne ein nettes und liebes Mädchen zu sein scheint, Harley mit ihrer "Schlampigkeit" und Pippin. Achja, Galdo, welcher sich ein Vorbild an Fang angenommen hat und Ethel, eine ehemalige Assasine, welche es dank Fang geschafft hat, mehr als nur "Kill" zu sagen.
Eine recht durchgemischte und dennoch gut abgewägte Gruppe, das muss man mal so sagen.
(Ich weiß, ich vergaß eventuell Charaktere, aber ich habe diese noch nicht freigespielt.) 

- Musik -
The Carefree Man. Mehr muss man echt nicht sagen, ist einfach großartig, der gesamte Soundtrack.

- Grafik, Optik -
Alles ist schön anzusehen, auch die Cutscenes sind wunderbar dargestellt, erinnert mich schon leicht an die Cutscenes aus Tales Of Symphonia DotNW. Schade nur, dass sich manche Dungeons so ein bisschen öfter wiederholen (same here, Nep-Nep...), aber trotzdem optisch sehr sehenswert.

- Gameplay -
Dass man sich Combos, Spezialtechniken und Magie durch sogenannte "Weapon Points" freischalten muss, ist eine sehr gute und schicke Idee. Gefällt mir sehr gut, auch die Idee mit der "Transformierung" und dass die Spezialtechniken daraus HP kosten, auch nett.

- Wiederspielwert -
Auf jeden fall! Auch wenn man die Story kennt, die Unterhaltungen zwischen den Charakteren sind Dinge des Spiels, die dazu anregen, es ruhig öfter mal wieder zu spielen und vor allem zu genießen.


Rund um gibt es für mich nicht viel zu meckern, das Ending war auch toll und vor allem die Kämpfe dorthin waren jetzt nicht zu schwer, als dass man sofort einen One-Hit-Kill abbekommt oder so.
Auch wenn das Spiel schoooon etwas länger hätte sein können, kurz und knackig hat aber auch was, ne?

21779018.review:
Ich kann nicht sagen, dass dies eines der besseren JRPGs auf Steam ist, da die Brücke jrpg Spieler in ihren Spielen ein gewisses Maß an Tiefe und Charakter-Entwicklung fordern, aber dennoch würde ich es noch empfehlen.

Es ist ein sehr gut gestaltetes Spiel, daß alle Kunst, Animationen, Menüs und Anpassungen sind gut poliert. Die meisten Leute, die mich fangen spielen denke, es ist es wirklich cool aussieht, und man bekommt das Gefühl, während es zu spielen. Der Dialog ist oft lustig und die Charaktere werden Sie auch überraschen, aber es ist immer noch als Ganzes und kind've Hohl Erfahrung.

Es ist leicht, überwältigt zu werden, die Monster und Umgebungen nicht sehr unterschiedlich sind, ist die Geschichte ziemlich allgemein ohne wirkliche Offenbarungen oder Herausforderungen, und manchmal sind die Zeichen scheinen gelangweilt und frivol über alles, was um geht, nicht die bösen Jungs zu erwähnen aren ' t sehr interessant oder einschüchternd. Tiefe ist sicherlich nicht die Spiele forte, aber ich habe nicht am Ende es zu viel zu kümmern.

Es ist eigentlich ganz nett manchmal nichts investiert haben, die Charaktere scheinen fast bewusst, dass sie in einem dummen jrpg sind und die Entwickler in viel missables / Schleifen / Extras für Leute, die eine größere Herausforderung der Hoffnung setzen. Es gibt so viel Spaß Sachen in kleinen verpackt, wie alle 39 der Furien Sie sammeln können, etwas über aktuelle Ereignisse zu sagen haben oder Rauen / abschwächen Bereichen effizienter zu schleifen. Viele coole Ideen mit dem Kampfsystem, obwohl es meist nicht, da man alles egal im Hauptspiel nach Level 40. Auch wenn die Zeichen werden nicht alle komplexen Probleme oder Gefühle haben kann wegblasen, sind sie alle bunt und angenehm, endete ich jeden Geschmack und eine harte Zeit der Wahl meiner Party.

Wenn Sie wirklich spielen RPGs graben und nicht ein bisschen repetivieness und Greifen Plotpunkte dagegen, es ist ein wirklich lustiges Spiel. Ich fühle mich wie negativ waren, aber ich liebte es ziemlich viel wirklich (natürlich ... wir Stunden)! Ich hörte nur zu schreiben, eine positive Bilanz zu spielen, und jetzt bin ich immer zurück, um es ...

21642884.review:
Fairy Fencer F is quite relaxing when you have the DLC with it. 
But I think the DLC isn't a bother even if its made easier to play, what matters to me was the storyline. This JRPG was especially better to me than the Neptunia series because it's amazing how each character has their own unique background already.

Art : I actually been in love with the artist for a while, but the models of the weapons actually brings my attention more because damn, it looks cool.

Story : Overall the story was good, but the endings weren't as exciting to be honest. 

Characters : Characters are the ones that made me feel like the game was special. With their own characteristics, and their fairy makes them exciting.

Gameplay System : What disturbs me the most on the battle system was the same looking attack animation each time (I only did same combos because of the damage output). Nonetheless, the skills, magics etc were actually quite cool to use, but I also like the idea of the fury effect. It somehow made it easier to farm WP + Levels.

Bonus : Sequel? I seen the trailer but seriously, 6 people in one battle party? Would be nice to display more but I am more concerned to watch every single one of them. But it makes me wonder how the story would go.

21525281.review:
So, here we are again, another jrpg game...

Now before I go into detail about certain game elements, I want to tell you that the recommandation is completely biased and you should try to decide for yourself if the game is worth the money or not. Also, you might've noticed I played this game for over 40 hours but I'm not reccomending it, and well, the reasons for that are explained below, if you want to read them.

First of all let's start with the gameplay, it's the usual IF dungeon turn-based combat in which you have certain characters to select from and you make a party of maxium 3 and go beating up monsters and leveling, and all those other elements you'd expect to usually find in a rpg. The combat is alright, and the controls aren't that bad either, considering the guys that made neptunia made this it's bound to be good right...

Next let's talk a little about the story and characters. The story is so blend it makes me puke, it's the usual bullshit there's an evil God and a good Goddess and you must revive the goddess and stop the guys who want to ressurect the God, and all that nonsense, seriously, the plot is also a mess, and they try to squeeze in all these elements inside just to cover up for certain plot holes. The easiest element that can do this for you: time travel... And the ending is exactly what you'd expect it to be if you have this kind of stories.

Well, you might be thinking, okay, if the story is bad, maybe the characters might help. Well, the characters are so typical, and tehy're the sterotypes of anime, which is what I hate the most about games such as this, unoriginal character concept is seriously a turnaway. You've got a typical lazy mc who wants to do nothing, two main love interests a tsundere and a yandere, the usual loli, the big boobed chick that's there for fanservice and don't get me started on the fact that there's a cat that talks or whatever that thing is. Now, don't get me wrong, the characters are what they are but there is certain plot development.

Next, let's go in detail about the music and voice acting. The voice acting is decent, I would say good, but that's still not enough to sell this game for what it is, considering the music feels repetitive and every song feels like the other, seriously I'd rather listen to my own songs than to the ingame music at some points.

The final element I'd like to talk about are the achievements, and how insensitive some of them are. Now don't get me wrong, getting the achievements is not a matter of skill but rather a matter of time in this game, with that being said there are a couple of achievements which are if not impossible, then they would take about a couple hundreds of grinding without using any dlc. And even with the dlc they would still take tens of hours to achieve.

Pluses:
-decent gameplay
-well implemented turn based combat
-good voice acting
-skippable animations
Minuses
-overused plot
-stereotypical anime characters
-repetitive music
-mindless grinding

All in all Fairy Fencer F is not a bad game, neither a good one, it's in the middle and everyone can have an opinion about it. Seriously if not for the story and characters this would be a game to remember, but as it is of now, it's all about the grind, and even if you are to finish grinding you would still feel like you achieved nothing...

21500299.review:
黑夜给了我黑色的脑洞，我用它来写游戏评测。

英雄

昨日的英雄将成明日的暴君，除非他今日便是将＂自己＂钉上十字架。
——《千面英雄》

凡戈又做噩梦了。
他突然跳下床，对着空气做出拔剑的动作。
睡在他身旁的提亚拉被他惊醒，看着面带恐惧的凡戈，叹了口气，起身抱住他。
“都过去了，凡戈，都过去了。”
凡戈抱着妻子，大口喘着气，放松了身体。
“我又梦到...”
“艾琳会保佑我们的，凡戈。”提亚拉打断了他的话，揽着他坐回床上，“现在你不是剑士了，你是英雄。”
“对，我是英雄...是英雄！”

...

“F.F.公司总裁，拯救世界的英雄——凡戈先生！”
“传说中的最强剑士，打败的魔王的英雄！”
“好帅！如果我是凡戈先生的爱人...”
“快往前挤挤，等会凡戈先生会给前面的观众签名！”
凡戈打量着台下狂热的年轻人们，想起了打败魔王后的那段时光。

在道法公司的罪行被揭穿后，提亚拉借助她家族的力量，以“救世英雄”的名义将道法公司的资产全盘接收，成立了Fairy Fencer Inc.，并让自己的丈夫，英雄凡戈出任总裁。
“英雄总裁，这是最好的广告！”凡戈想起提亚拉眉飞色舞地向他描述公司的未来发展的情景，“中年人会出于感恩购买我们的产品，年轻人们会崇拜你，并在未来成为我们的忠实用户！”
“那有什么用啊...能吃饱就好嘛...”当时的他是这样回答的。
“那怎么行！”提亚拉一脸恨铁不成钢地看着趴在床上毫无干劲的他，思考了一会儿，叹了口气 。
“好吧，你只要偶尔给人们讲讲打败道法、战胜魔王的事，就可以天天吃大餐，好不好？”

...

夜半，提亚拉留在公司总部处理公务。
她在浏览一份业务报告。
家族…越来越心急了。
她这样想着，用魔力将这份提案销毁。

凡戈在书房中抚摸着剑匣。
埃塞刚才来过，留下了一份文件，一言不发地离开了。
她似乎又恢复了最初的冷漠，不再是那个对世界好奇的大孩子了。
过去的伙伴们都变了。
哈菈因为没有研究成果，终日纵欲酗酒。
皮平失踪了。
埃塞选择当一个刀口舔血的雇佣兵。
卡尔德跟着自己，提亚拉给他安排了保卫部长的职务。
提亚拉…也变了。
自己呢？

凡戈抱着剑匣，
来到陈列装备的收藏室，
绑好勇气头巾，
身穿天使半铠，
带上勇者拳戒，
正如冒险之时。

艾琳已经不在身边，
狂怒不过是一把锋利一些的长剑。
“我没有变，我依然是英雄！”
他用狂怒击碎水晶玻璃，离开了大宅。

书房的桌子上留有一份文件，
和提亚拉毁掉的那份一模一样。
标题是：《妖精能源中和魔王封印能力测试报告》

…

F.F.企业通讯头条：
《救世英雄竟成杀人狂魔 公司边陲矿场血流成河》
本社讯：我司原总裁，曾经的救世英雄凡戈在昨日袭击我司旗下东北矿场，并残忍地将矿场内所有员工杀死。原董事长、凡戈的妻子提亚拉现已被警方控制，目前公司运营正常。

据知情人士透露，凡戈患有严重的精神疾病，经常无故殴打妻子以及公司其他员工。事故发生后我司紧急调取现场录像，发现当时他正试图打破女神布下的魔王封印。我们有充足的理由相信，曾经的英雄可能早已被魔王影响，成为了可悲的傀儡。

…

“凡戈！你到底在干什么！”卡尔德抱着伤痕累累的凡戈，愤怒地吼到。

“我…是英雄…
我要…消灭邪恶…
我要…拯救世界…”

“那你为什么要杀那些人！那些人是无辜的平民啊！”
“照顾好…提亚拉…”
凡戈已无力多言。
他在心里自嘲着：没想到自己会死在自己收集到的狂怒手里。
以凡人之躯，击败魔王血脉镇守在研究基地的妖精剑士们，他已经耗尽所有力量。
无辜的平民？
那些邪神家族的爪牙，
尝试解剖妖精剑士以图破解魔王封印。
他们马上要成功了。
哈菈发现了线索，在调查过程中被玩废了。
皮平…已经成为一具残破的尸体。
至于提亚拉和卡尔德…
他不敢去想更多。

他也不需要再去想更多了
凡戈仿佛回到了天国阶梯
他的搭档，艾琳来接他了
没有人为了他向女神祈愿
包括他用生命换来的妻子
英雄凡戈，狂怒的执掌者
死了。

唯留传说与恶名。


一个简单的小脑洞，不是很完善，别吐槽。

下面是游戏评价：
+一二周目的剧情设置
+妖精系统的多样性
+不错的支线文本
-儿戏一般的战斗动画
-谜一样的装备系统
-怪物种类单一


综合评分：6.5，一款在RPG和GAL之间摇摆不定、尚可一玩的日式游戏。
据说有续作，如果出PC版就支持一下。

21475002.review:
I enjoyed this more than I expected.

Pros:
+ Combat follows a basic turn-based mechanic, but there are a few twists here and there which make it interesting enough.
+ Story, while chock-full of tropes, is surprisingly engaging.
+ Humor. I found some parts really funny.

Cons:
- Progression system isn't something to write home about. It's tolerable, but not very engaging
- Some game mechanics, while giving the impression of being related to story, really don't affect anything plot-related at all. [spoiler]Godly Revival, I'm looking at you[/spoiler]
- Most of the characters are cardboard cutouts.
- There is a fair amount of grind. Depending on how you look at it, it might be good or bad. But it's there all right.
- Blatant map re-use. [spoiler]Halfway through the game, it makes you run through the whole thing all over again, albeit on higher difficulty level[/spoiler]

This looks like a lot of cons and very little pros. But for some reason, I enjoyed my time with it. So this gets a begrudging thumbs-up from me.

21469875.review: 之前有过玩重生的经验，所以上手还算轻松，但上手之后慢慢就感到不对了，一周目的时候也没看任何攻略，差不多是玩一步看一步，不知道其他人怎么样，我反正觉得药材价格确实偏贵（特别是蓝），辛辛苦苦打一阵子买不了几瓶药，打怪掉的钱只能说勉勉强强，但由于范围技能几乎都是后期才学，前期也没什么特别方便的赚钱方法，只有刷那个塔。所幸前期boss也不强（还tm比不过一些狂怒守护）。但后期药贵的的诟病就出来了，怪不鶸了，基本我过一次关身上钱几乎就全买药了，而且和重生不同，人物升级不回血，尼玛我尝试刷点怪在不用血瓶的情况下打两次就得出地图回血，打boss经常恶心到我，打了一半说点话立马满血复活，而我方从来没这种待遇（连怒气值都不给你加），直接一朝回到解放前，导致一周目我基本就只能推推剧情。还有一个东西真恶心，就是跳跃。这我不多说，你自己试了就知道。综上这游戏对我们这种手残菜鸟不怎么友好，但没办法，谁叫他有萝莉呢，剧情确实不错，所以还是好评( ´_ゝ｀)

21441469.review:
Fun game, but there is no difficulty slider and eventually you end up just playing it for the story and not for the gameplay.

Exploring dungeons is pointless, there's nothing to look at (graphics are console/outdated), nothing to explore too. You're better off going in a straight line to the objective in every dungeon instead of looking for loot/monsters to kill. Side quests are practically worthless, rewards are ok but when you literally stomp every enemy your level (and then some) you don't really need to be careful when playing. For perspective, I had to play against enemies 2x my level to even get a sort of challenge, since I couldn't roflstomp enemy mobs then. So don't buy it for the gameplay.

Story wise though it was fun. Funny to play through, has funny little bits of trivia that you can pick up while you're in town by other civilians, though those interactions are just going to a menu (kinda) and selecting characters to talk to.
Ignoring the side stories, the main storyline is quite enjoyable. Only "problem" would be that it's not particularly deep in terms of character development, but that's irrelevant since it's pretty much a casual game to enjoy for say... 14 hours or so. 

Characters also have weird challenges that you could grind if you wanted to, but those seem to be put in for those who wish to punish themselves. Like "jump 10, 50, 100, 2000, 5000 times in a dungeon with <x> character". And the reward for completing more and more jumps/attacks/whatever doesn't stack well, so eh. 

7/10, worth getting on sale. Not sure about full price though, since I'm fine with spending 7.99 for what I got, but full price of $30 is a bit much. I really would've liked a bit more depth to gameplay/story for more fun, but it's ok as it is.

Buy on sale (like all games), grab the additional dlcs (get the ultimate armor pack to enjoy the OP playstyle faster), could skip the cosmetic sets though.

21431734.review:
Writing this review right after I finished one of the 3 endings. 

Fairy Fencer F is a really pleasant experience. 
The story will drag you in, make you play trough all of it and after you finish it it will leave you asking for more.
I must admit that there was not a single moment where i got bored while playing this game. The story was a truly wonderful experience.

The combat aspect in this game is rather challenging if you didn't use the weapons/armor provided by the DLC ( and if you waste your money on cosmetics and not potions or equipment, like i did ) 
But in most dungeons you will end up spamming basic attacks and heals, at least when fighting against low-tier mobs. 
The Boss fights were challenging most of the time and made me think of actually using some sort of strategy and forced me to even prepare for those battles beforehand. 

The visuals in this game are what you would expect from a decent JRPG so nothing bad or special to comment on that.

And the last thing to comment on was the character design and development. No one of the characters seemed boring and they each contributed to the story in their own way, which i liked. There weren't any useless party members that you just ignored and never made use of. 

Overall this game was a really pleasant experience and I will definitely try to complete the two other endings.

21420841.review:
When you were a child, did you ever wonder about how your adult life would be? Having grand aspirations on becoming something more than your  parents were, following your own path in life and trying to enjoy yourself within the best of your ability. You would run around at recess playing basketball or playing in the fake metal castle and jungle bars that you gotten hurt from time and time again. Coming home to a warm dinner and greeting your parent or parents and having them ask about your day. The polar opposite could occur, you could have been that weird kid that everyone use to avoid and the teachers didn't know what to do with, you would sit recursively in the corner of the cafeteria, and talk to yourself inside of your head. You would pack a lunch that you made yourself, or if you had lunch tickets that would have to satiate your appetite until the next day, because your family was too poor to offer you any type of sustenance.

No when you came home, it was usually to a house of yelling and throwing things, your mom could have been a junkie your dad an alcoholic and the many brothers and sisters you have, were all so fuck up beyond belief, they were never home. Your mom could have various men over to feed her habit, and sometimes these men would molest you, and so would your father after a stupor. This type of child had no chance in life. These children are brought into the world to do nothing but suffer. They play escapism in their minds to ease the pain that they are in. The only remedy for them would be to take them out of that hostile environment and place them with a truly kind family.

Child 1 would exhibit some issues, but for the most part he would live a pretty decent life, giving the fact he/she would have the social skills and the support that they need to push on through. If not brought up properly they would proceed to become entitled and have this persisting narcissistic personality disorder. Nothing would ever be enough and everything that bad ever happened would be others fault.  So while both children would have these things in their minds growing up, child 1 for the most part would be extremely more likely to succeed instead of child 2, who would developed a multitude of mental illnesses, where they couldn't cope with for the rest of their lives. 

I have witnessed both of these things growing up, while attending school. You could always tell the children who were damaged and the children that had a pretty much life of leisure. I fall somewhere between child 1 and child 2, a mixture of real bad shit, and real good shit. A loving home, but also a broken home. A sheltered childhood, rampant with violence and chaos outside, filled with children growing up way to fast, and running dope on the street, like it's some sort of normalcy for them. My house was filled with a lot of fighting, arguing and general malignancy from many family members. A loving mother, grandmother and aunt, protecting me from the harms of the real world and the neighborhood. I spent most of my childhood indoors in front of the TV playing video games that my mom or grandmother would rent for me at blockbuster, I had a five dollar a week allowance that I could spend on whatever I wanted.

We were very poor, but we always had the lights on, food on the table, and a roof over our heads. My mother and grandmother would buy me the latest consoles even if I had to wait a bit, they would put layaway's and surprise me at birthdays and Christmas, my mom would write little sayings in my book bag for valentines day saying how much she loved me, and my grandmother would always cooked what I wanted for thanksgiving and Christmas. I had many good memories and many bad memories, but these three women always tried within the best of their ability to always make sure that I was always taking care of. I always had new clothes throughout the school year, and I always use to go to parks with my aunt because as said earlier the neighborhood was too bad to venture outside. I was hated throughout elementary school because I wasn't like most children. I use to get terrorized on the bus and made fun of because my hobbies included listening to music and playing video games. I was picked on for being overweight, and for being to proper and respectful.  Teachers were always antagonistic towards me, because I was the kid always questioning things, as to make them feel like it's more work for them, as oppose to enlightening a young mind.

I would go through middle school and high school pretending to be something I am not. I would dress in my own style that consisted over various name brand clothing, I would always get the latest shoes  and colognes and I would put of this mask of someone who is wealthy and happy. I gave my mom and grandmother a lot of stress during this time, we didn't have the money to keep up this image and I would get into fights with them about it. I was popular, I hung out with people who made quadruple my mothers income, they would ride around in Mercedes and BMW, while my mom had this rinkydink Buick from the late 80s. I was ashamed of her jobs that she took to support me, and ashamed of where I lived and the cars that my family had. I tried everything to the best of my ability to make sure no one found out. I was loved, people knew who I was, they wanted to be me, they wanted to be able to be what I was. Girls were actually intimidated by me, come to find out later on, the reason I had such a hard time dating was because of the fact that these girls didn't think I would take it seriously and feared rejection.

I'm not tooting my own horn, I began to hate what I have become, what I was, what I was turning into. It was fake, I was a fraud, I was everything every kid wanted to be in middle school and high school, but I was horribly depressed. Until one day I couldn't take it anymore, and It caught up to me. In the middle of high school I had an immunity disorder, for some unknown reason I would get sick every week. I missed more than a 120 days of school. I had bronchitis, mono, flu, strep, pulled groin, dislocated knee, walking pneumonia, I had it fucking all. During this time my grades were awful, I mean they always were terrible, but they really tanked. A little after summer, and after 9/11 I didn't attend school, I was majorly depressed and wouldn't leave my room, by this time I moved into a better neighborhood and things were a bit different. Like I said though, I stayed in my room all day and finally I was expelled for missing too many days. That was it, it was over, my so called friends forgot about me, and my popularity meant jackshit. I would suffer from this for an obscene amount of time.

From that point on things didn't get better they just got worse and worse. At the end of 2011 I was hoping for a better year, I've been reclusive and working the job I still work at till this day that I hate, but at the end of 2011 I was hoping that I would finally have a good year, that this is the year that I would make a change. 2012 comes in, off to the same start as any other year, my grandmother had her 75th birthday, and I was as close as ever to her, till late March, where she got sick, she was hospitalized and had two mini strokes and passed away, 2013 would come and my uncle would be hospitalized with the same issues my grandmother had, he would last one more years and die in October of 2014. Every year since 2012 had been the worst years of my life, 2013 was particular horrible, but that's a bit too personal to get into, so lets just say it was just purely awful.

It's 2016 right now, and I am terribly unhappy, and have difficulty living each day. My heart is broken to a million pieces because I miss my grandmother and uncle so fucking much. So take it from me, just live life the best you can and share it with others who cherish and deserve your love.

21355240.review: Fairy Fencer F is a fun RPG and adventure game. With a unique story and characters, and great artwork the game is fun and left me captivated for hours to play through. It is held back slightly by the lack of variety in gameplay. however, as each dungeon is the same besides style and monster type; no puzzles or requirements are necessarily needed to complete them; just brute force. The graphics are great (and run decently well on my potato laptop), and with full controller support and a compelling story, this game is definitely a nice little jewel to enjoy and thrive in.

21338831.review:
I have played plenty of JRPGs that I can't see too much difference between this game and the others.

Pros : 
- Distinct, unique cast of characters, with nice interactions between each character
- Plenty of character's customization such as weapon upgrade, skill upgrade, costumes, etc
- Good combat animation makes the battles less boring
- Good overall soundtrack
- Japanese-English voice option
- Skippable conversation, pretty convenient for those who want to retry the game in NG+ for achievements
- Consistent 60fps 

Cons :
- Somehow, the world felt really small. 1 city and 14 different dungeons (not including DLCs). Most dungeons only consist of 2-3 floors/stages. You can easily explore the whole dungeon in just a few minutes
- Boring, uninspired dungeons
- Lack of challenge in combat
- Pretty common, forgettable, short storyline 

If you are looking for games where you can enjoy the story and character's interaction, you will enjoy this game. 
Overall, I give this game 7/10. It's not the best for its genre, but it's still enjoyable.

21337210.review:
This is one of the best Idea Factory RPGs I've ever played since Chaos Wars and Blazing Souls.

I have to admit: Idea Factory's earlier RPGs were enjoyable too, but had too many flaws and unpolished features so that I couldn't recommend any of them as a stand-alone game of a genre. Fairy Fencer F is different in my opinion.

It's a turn-based rpg with a combat similar to Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth series and Mugen Souls. If you played those games you'll probably notice many familiar things. 
Fairy Fencer actually has a lot more useful and polished features compared to Neptunia Rebirth series. While the game starts off simple, its core gameplay gradually gains more and more stuff. And I'm not talking about just crafting feature or sub-quests. There are unlockable combos, enemy weaknesses, team-attack system, character-unique actions, fairy card bonuses, etc.

Sure there is still quite a few in-game stuff which makes you wonder 'This could've been so much better if you added X', or 'Why did they not exploit this further?', or even 'This system doesn't make much sense.'
But all in all I wouldn't call it a wasted potential. 

The game is not the best, but a very solid and enjoyable JRPG in my opinion. I would definitely recommend trying it out.
I also have to mention that Fairy Fencer F has a really good optimization. It runs on my pre-historic dualcore like a charm.

21330164.review:
打折时花20多块钱购入（玩时掉了张闪卡卖了12块钱，lucky），一个周目一个结局，用时30+。一周目初见应该完成的都完成了（如果不刷任务，应该只需要20+小时）
非常正统的日式RPG。宣传时说的是天野喜孝美术原案（excuse me?），植松伸夫作曲，游戏的简称是FFF……这宣传，感觉各种跟最终幻想擦个边儿……然并卵，虽然质量也算是对得起它这价格，但是说实话离一款真正值得叫好的作品还差了一段距离。

下面详细说说各方面的优缺点：

[h1]1、画面[/h1]
就是大家印象里日系商业RPG应该有的画面。2D图精美漂亮，3D模型略挫但贴图好看，并且在游戏中大量运用远景，所以大大地弥补了许多模型上的硬伤，日本游戏美工的黑科技。大部分的剧情是电子小说的形式，立绘有微小动态，另有少量的3D即时演算剧情过场动画。
城镇和大地图移动是类似《世界树迷宫》的纯UI式，迷宫探索和战斗则是全3D画面。战斗是站位回合制。
角色画风很GAL，好坏则是仁者见仁了，个人很喜欢，觉得看起来很舒服。
总体来说，“超震撼”画面在这游戏里应该是不存在的，视觉冲击也基本是没有，更多的是让人觉得“漂亮”“华丽”“有趣”这类的体验。

[h1]2、音乐[/h1]
植松伸夫是保证，无需多说。

[h1]3、游戏系统[/h1]
基本上所有觉得应该会有RPG系统这游戏都有：打怪掉钱升级，技能点加技能树，支线任务，收集素材合成道具，偷东西、地图寻素材，斗技场爬塔，养宠练宠。
除此之外，还有几个比较有特点的系统：每个角色有五种武器，可以战前搭配出三条路线的平砍方案，然后在实战时可以根据敌人特性不同任意排列组合。怒气很易集，一回合就可集满变身。得到的兵器（相当于宠物）除了能装备加属性还可以插在大地图上给迷宫也加上特效。
游戏系统如此繁多，就很考验策划的功底了，如何能把这些要素有机地结合在一起很重要，不然就成了鸡肋系统的机械堆积。但是可惜的是，这游戏的策划非常糟糕，后面再详细表。

[h1]4、剧情和演出[/h1]
这个剧情框架，简直就是那种最俗套烂大街的日式RPG剧情的框架。背景一定要是暗神光神相争啊然后被封印啊，女主角不是光神转世就是邪神后裔啊，反派一定要有三大或者四大天王一个比一个更装逼啊，主角方或反派方一定要有那种长得很帅但是背负了沉重过去苦衷讲起来能绕地球好几圈的人啊，反正那种20年前就已经让玩家们审美疲劳到爆的日式剧情接二连三地往你脸上狂呼。尽管如此，我还是开心地吃了，因为写剧本的人真的很拼，硬把一个烂俗要死的剧情框架给努力地写出了花儿，人物虽然一样套路化很严重，但却把他们用得非常恰到好处，他们各有自我风格的风趣的对白，给原本俗套的剧情增添大量的生机。脱线的男主、日常撕逼的双女主，撑起了欢乐的一片天，虽然剧情因此“史诗性”大辐降低，但是乐趣却大辐上升，想给剧本师一个小赞
这游戏的演出并不理想，游戏的节奏过于快了，空有电子小说的形式，但对白少得可怜，有的重要剧情对白居然只有两三句话，未免太惜字如金……另外就是，虽然很少，但是确实有3D即时演算的剧情演出，不如删了都换成静态的CG，因为各种3D模型特写挫得简直不忍直视，动作和特效也是傻得飞起出戏出到千里之外。用3D即时演算代替静态CG应该是制作方对某段剧情很重视的结果，但是却没有起到重视的效果，让人痛心。

[h1]5、策划[/h1]
一般评游戏我觉得不太会特意提策划，因为策划跟程序是一样的，一般如果游戏在这方面做的很好，玩家是感觉不到他们的存在的，表扬时也不会特地去提他们，但如果游戏在这方面做的很糟糕（比如程序全是BUG），玩家则一定会指着他们喷个不停。这游戏的策划，想不提都不行，因为真是太恐怖了！烂得突破天际！我觉得策划要对这个游戏收到的90%的负面评价负责，能在商业游戏里看到业余到如此程度的，真是少见。
所有的迷宫毫无设计性，无脑到爆炸。居然还有跳跃功能，甚至还可合成的特殊道具让角色跳得更高，请问这功能真的有意义吗，有多少地方是需要跳更高功能才能到的？数来数去不超过5处！一般游戏越到后期迷宫最复杂，这游戏越到后期迷宫越懒得去做，各种明显拿贴图调个颜色或者翻转一下模型直接重用，太糊弄了。迷宫里的宝箱超级没用。
战斗方面，首先这游戏的普通攻击比任何一个必杀的时间都长，男主角的五连击一套全打下来都要半分钟以上，太浮夸，还好按RT可以跳过，玩这游戏RT键快被我撸断了。怒气积攒超快，通常一回合后全员即可合体变身，也许此游戏的风格就是想大家多多变身，但能不能别每次变身后都放同一首BGM，太出戏了！植松伸夫给BOSS做了那么多风格不同的战斗曲，结果往往播不到半分钟，就切换成了变身BGM，游戏全程都在听那两首变身后BGM，都快被洗脑了，对除此之外的战斗曲毫无印象，策划同志，你对得起你们游戏的作曲吗？
这游戏的数值简直是个笑话，相比之下上面的问题都不算事。
技能加点加在魔法和特技上根本是浪费，所有的特技和魔法都没普攻性价比高。用大量技能点学到一个终结技能，敌伤10000，普攻敌伤9700，你在逗我？魔法更是毫无意义，伤害感人。
BOSS数值逗比非常，许多BOSS一上来被主角一个普攻削掉大半的血，然后剧情强行说“哇，这个BOSS真是太强了，打不过”，你们这演技我给负分。最终的BOSS在残血时发了一个动画酷炫的终极大必杀，动画过后主角才伤了700血（主角每回合会自动回600血），当时就被逗笑了。
支线任务太报复社会，刷各种罕见素材刷到脑溢血，要在反复不断鬼畜进出同个迷宫找隐藏素材，连续搞上半个小时后就会开始思考人生：我是谁，我在哪，我活着的意义是什么，我为什么要玩这种辣鸡游戏。而且这些费心费力做的任务其实并没有什么卵用，伤怀（萝拉支线貌似是唯一有用的，但特别容易错过）。
加兰多的偷窃技能，此游戏的殇之顶点，随便google一下fairy fencer f seize，怎样一个哀鸿遍野的景象。这游戏偷成功的概率，比玩卡牌手游抽到UR的概率还低，而且偷窃一次消耗高达100MP（加兰多总MP才1000），满MP耗尽什么也没偷到是非常有可能的，试问这么没有职业素养的盗贼，在哪个RPG里见过？


总之游戏虽然有许多制作精良、优秀的地方，但是基本全都被策划给毁完了，使这个游戏没办法底气满满堂而皇之地站在“好游戏”的台面上，越到后期给人感觉越像是一个赶工的作品，建议策划赶紧辞职回家，别再祸祸其他游戏了。大家如果真心想买想玩而不是想喜+1，首先你得像我一样真的很喜欢日式RPG和这个游戏的人设，其次你得对各种糟心雷人的数值做好充足的心理准备，另外就是提前告诉大家加点要加普通攻击、支线任务完全可以不做（除非你想搞全成就），可以节省好多好多好多完全没有必要的时间付出然后去玩玩其他更有意思的游戏。

21315113.review:
Conceptually, Fairy Fencer F would seem to be a return to the roots of the JRPG genre: a traditionally-styled game with a distinctly Japanese story and aesthetic. Consider the alliteration in Fairy Fencer F’s title, which calls Final Fantasy to mind, or the game’s development team, which includes composer Nobuo Uematsu and artist Yoshitaka Amano, both of Final Fantasy fame. How unfortunate, then, that Fairy Fencer F is no glorious return to the heyday of the JRPG, but rather a strange, distorted effort, terrifically fun in bursts but plagued by unfortunate technical issues.

Fairy Fencer F is the story of young warrior Fang and his fairy partner, Eryn. Fang's excessively cynical and derogatory attitude is likely to grate within mere minutes of starting the game, in which he constantly complains about his new path in life. You see, as the game begins, Fang is told by a shopkeeper that if he is capable of pulling out a strange sword embedded in a rock, he will be granted any wish he desires. All he wants is tasty food (a running obsession that becomes unfunny almost instantly), but, upon yanking out the sword, he is greeted by semi-amnesiac Eryn, told he is a legendary fencer, and asked to free the world's Goddess from her stasis by finding and using Furies, fairies trapped in mythical weapons. Fang’s annoyance at having such a burden suddenly dropped on him is understandable, but his continued whininess and apathy is exceptionally irksome. Eryn is more likeable, though the moment another female appears on the scene she goes into (similarly unfunny) jealous-possessive-angry mode.

Fairy Fencer F's least irritating character.
I soon met Tiara, a stuck-up, bratty fencer who harbors a genre-standard terrible secret. She also doubles as an exposition machine, teaching you about the plane beyond reality where the Goddess and evil deity are sealed and giving you a free inn to recover at--when she's not being bossy and condescending. Notice a theme here? The majority of Fairy Fencer F's cast was ripped straight from the pages of Anime Character Tropes You Can Implement Easily. Suffice to say, it takes a fair amount of time before a truly likeable character joins the troupe. Certain party members become more tolerable as time goes on, but it's hard to shake those awful first impressions.

Layers of Fear Announcement Trailer
Check out this new psychedelic horror game from the Polish developer Bloober Team.
Saddled with a party of people I would have liked to punch in the face given the opportunity, I ventured out into the exploration portion of Fairy Fencer F. Much to my relief, exploration and combat are a fair bit more energizing than watching barely-animated character cutouts complain to each other. Combat is turn-based with positioning elements: You and your enemies move around a small field and trade blows with each other, launching area-of-effect spells and utilizing strategic positioning to your advantage. The basics aren't tough to grasp, and as you earn more weapon points in battle, you can customize your stat boosts and add multi-hitting combo capabilities to your characters' strikes.

This kind of cringe-worthy dialogue is par for the course.
The majority of Fairy Fencer F's cast was ripped straight from the pages of Anime Character Tropes You Can Implement Easily.
A neat addition to the formula is the tension gauge: as characters attack and use skills, their tension increases and multiplies the damage they deal. Once tension reaches a certain point, characters can "fairize," transforming into quasi-robot-armored fighters with access to special, super-damaging techniques. However, playing overly defensively--using lots of healing items and spells, retreating from enemies, running away from battle--reduces the tension, and if it dips below a certain point, your combat efficacy will suffer. It's a neat system that makes the combat considerably more engaging. It's quite fast-paced, as well--the handy L2 button allows you to skip a lot of long-winded combat animations.

You can find new dungeons to explore at set points in the story, where you'll find some Furies to collect (along with the fairies that inhabit them and/or possibly another fencer). Once you've got a Fury/fairy combo, you can summon the pair to remove one of the binding blades sealing the Goddess and the Vile God. Doing so upgrades the abilities of the fairy, who can then either be assigned to one of your party members or to a dungeon via a process called "world shaping." While the stat bonuses fairies can provide to party members are nothing to be sneezed at (and they also level up through combat), world shaping is particularly cool: by assigning a fairy to a dungeon, you also get persistent effects throughout that dungeon, i.e. an experience boost when defeating enemies. This helps make sub-questing less of an out-and-out grind, as it helps tailor some dungeon settings to your liking. The dungeon romping itself is also more engaging than developer Compile Heart's previous endeavors, with multi-level layouts and traps.

This still frame is only a little slower than the game's average frame rate.
As much as I enjoyed the fundamental combat and dungeon-crawling, it was sometimes difficult for me to enjoy them. In many of the dungeons, Fairy Fencer F suffers from an atrocious and varying framerate, frequently dipping into the sub-20 frames-per-second range. Compile Heart games tend to suffer from this problem, even though the visuals aren't terribly complex, but Fairy Fencer F is particularly awful, to the point where dungeon crawls can lead to motion sickness and headaches.

The irritating cast and miserable framerate dips aside, you must also contend with sudden difficulty spikes, recycled environments, and an inconsistent art style. Even the much-touted Yoshitaka Amano and Nobuo Uematsu’s contributions are disappointing. Amano's contributions are a handful of art concepts, while Uematsu's--or more specifically, Uematsu's team of musicians, the Earthbound Papas’--music is uneven; some tracks are absolutely fantastic, while others are entirely unmemorable. Yet there are glimpses of a game that could have been consistently entertaining: combat, when it's not running like a slideshow, is satisfying; there's a lot of customization available to the player; and that butt-rock theme that plays during fairizing is rousing in much the same way Uematsu's Blue Dragon boss music was.

Fairy Fencer F has its bright spots, but it's not a game I can heartily recommend--there's too much detritus to dig through in order to get to the fun bits. Compile Heart has announced a sequel, so here's to hoping the move to more recent hardware will solve their games’ lingering technical problems--and here's to hoping the resulting games will be better as a result.

Did you enjoy this review?

Fairy Fencer F
Fairy Fencer F / PC

THE GOOD
 Fun combat with a good amount of depth
 Lots of customization options to play with

THE BAD
 Motion-sickness-inducing framerate fluctuations
 Profoundly irritating characters

21290444.review:
Not the most in-depth jrpg on steam or anything, but it's worth checking it out.

The game is very repetitive(I know, it's a rpg, but that one's even more repetitive than the personas). You clear a level, go back to town, chat, clear a level go back to town and chat, all the way through the end.

The game is very easy and my god please play with the japanese voices, english ones will make you cringe every time you battle.

What I really liked with this game is how fast the battles can be, since you can skip every single animations. In fact you can also skip every scenes. I made one playthrough(newgame+) and skipped most battles and every scenes and it took me 45 minutes to make it, lol.

The game has some really good ideas done right, but it just gets boring very fast, even though I personally enjoyed it. The battles lack some strategy and some better weakness/resist system, as well as the character developpement is meh; once you're mid-late game it kinda halts there. Music is all right and the level design is a joke.

Late game; the characters are pretty much identical since they nearly got all the same stats, the only difference is the main character having some slight extras, and a few different spells here and there between the characters.

Fairy Fencer F also has plenty of side-quests and stuff, but it's really boring and pretty much identical to what you do in the storyline.

When I first saw the battle system i thought: Wow it's like Grandia/chrono trigger! But it easily fell appart once you fully understand it. It's still decent though. But it lacks strategy.

For my experience, I'd rate it an 8 since jrpgs are my favorite genre of games, but I EASILY understand the metacritic score of 66. The game feels empty and unpolished.

Also crashed on a few occasions.

If I were you, I wouldn't pay more than 10$ for it.

21173719.review:
Great character development, story, and interesting combat (see the Neptunia games for gameplay, they're almost practically the same in that regard). About a 20-25 hour playthrough. Lots of touching moments, plot twists, and other stuff that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Worth the 8.99 I spent on it, and wouldn't mind paying $30 for it. I'll be picking up Advent Dark Force for PS4 at full price when it releases. I doubt it will get one, but I really hope this game gets a (true) sequel, ADF is just a remake with some added content and endings, similar to how Neptunia has the the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth remakes. Also, its much more well optimized compared to Re;Birth 1, whereas that game I get a framerate all over the place (on my laptop, haven't tried either of these on my desktop, due to some issues that will hopefully be resolved soon) FFF I usually get a constant 30 FPS. Controller support is great, played the entire game with a Steam Controller. 

+Overall story
+Characters you'll love and get attatched to
+Well optimized port, as well as controller support
+Fantastic Dub, never switched to JP voices

-Some moments in the story are a little silly, or should be explained better in my opinion
-Certain area in the game where I had to grind for awhile, this could be the fact that I was underleveled prior to a boss, or the game just had a weird difficulty spike
-Don't like to complain about the length, but I really wish this game was longer. 20-25 hours is a pretty decent amount of time for a game, especially today, but the devs should take this complaint as a compliment being that I loved every moment so much I wish it could just be a little longer.

Overall, I would give this game 8.75/10. I'm sure I'll be doing another playthrough before I know it, somewhere in the near future. Thank you IFI for releasing this on PC, don't think I would have picked it up on my PS3. Again, I bought this game on sale, but I would easily pay full price for it, on PC or PS3. I'll pay $60 for Advent Dark Force on PS4 when that comes out too. I'm glad I played this game, just goes to show what masterpieces JRPGs can be. Even if this game doesn't have as much of a budget as your Final Fantasy, Persona, whatever you like, its such a different experience from other games I've played and I might even put it up there as one of my Top 20 games. This review was all over the place due to me forcing myself to write it at 4 AM, right after completing the game, but thanks for reading. Hope I convinced you to purchase it, because this game certainly deserves all the money it can get.

21139511.review:
Do you recommend this game?

Yes.
And no.

Basically, what that means is, I had fun with it but I know why.

If you aren't used to JRPG style turn based and/or don't particularly enjoy the whole 'anime' vibe, you probably won't get huge amounts from this game.

Having not really played any previous JRPG games, the turn based combat was something it took me a while to get used to but it's not the worst.

There's depth but the game clearly hasn't had a huge budget as seen from repetetive level designs re-using assets, constant repeating of levels for side-quests and monsters that are hilariously out-of-place at times.

I had fun with it though. It's not awful, it's just not something I think I'd play again though the time I spent was fun.

It does get significantly easier once you throw your character with tons of AOE a Fairy that gives SP regeneration though. That and the double damage modifier.

Try it. It's got fun characters. Otherwise Akiba's Trip is the better game.

The only thing that this game has against itself is that the battling can and will get repetitive and tiresome after a while, but aside from that it's one of the best RPGs I've played in a good while, and without thinking twice, the best cast of characters I've seen in a videogame.

21103594.review:
This is one of those games where you wish you could forget, just so you can experience it first-hand again.

I've ever rarely played J-RPGs, but when I played this game, I was truly in love with it. If you're a fan of J-RPGs and romance anime, you'll surely love this game. TL;DR down below.

Throughout the entire game, you are given a good amount of characters to choose from with more in the later parts of the game. As you progress further into the story, a bit of farming may be needed as enemies become more and more tough to deal with, but as a J-RPG it was already expected. The mechanics of the game maybe a bit tacky and confusing at first, but eventually it becomes easier as you continue to play. 

Now, the story was probably one of the best stories I've ever experienced in video games. Each part of the dialogue does its job well, when you need to be happy or laugh, you are met with corny jokes and ridiculous events, but when you need to feel for the characters in the game, you will without a doubt feel the sadness they show. Honestly, as you continue playing the story, you will become immersed and will develop a love for each and every character you play as. Hell, maybe you'll love some characters who you don't even play as. 

Next, the replayability potential is high as there are four different routes you may choose from and because there is also a new game+ type system where your stats from your previous run will be brought over to your next run and don't worry, the enemies won't get easy because of this. 

Finally, if you actually read all the way here, I give my thanks for doing so and for considering to buy this beautiful, funny and amazing game. I was truly surprised by how much I loved playing this game and regretted for not getting it sooner. As a gamer, I know that some people are out here to buy only one game and that there are many games to choose from. Believe me, I had high doubts when I first bought it since I was entirely new to the J-RPG genre in general. But, this game has been a blast to play through and I wish more people could experience it. Idea Factory truly have outdone themselves with this game.

As it stands, I have finished this game and no longer have a purpose to play it once more. Not having a reason to see my favorite characters again, truly made me sad. But, their sequel is coming and I hope it will live up to its predecessor.
I, as an avid gamer, am looking forward to the next sequel Idea Factory is releasing and hope to see my favorite characters once more.

tl;dr: Beautiful, amazing and funny. What more could you ask for?

21063850.review:
It might be unfair to say that this game existed just because the devs wanted to experiment new ways to improve the franchise's gameplay experience...

At least, that's what I thought during the first hours of the game. However, as time passed, I realized something....

Of course, core gameplay has been improved a lot. Combat is fast and snappy, and many other things...

And while the characters might not be as memorable as Neps, the story is actually deep this time around. There are evidences of character development, and the final scenes towards the end is actually quite touching. (Although I still have to say that it's quite cliché.) 

Some of the franchise's core problems still remain though. For instance, excessive recycling of assets. Story inconsistencies in some cutscenes when incorporated with optional content, bad voice recording and mixing in some parts, and so on.

Nevertheless, it's still a decent game with tons of rooms for improvement (FFF:ADF?). Overall worth buying.

21059777.review:
Sempre fui amante de jogos no estilo Final Fantasy, nada melhor para resumir Fairy Fencer F.
Foco para a trilha sonora, muito bem feita e parece que foi escolhida à dedo para cada momento do jogo. A jogabilidade não apresenta nada complicado ou muito diferente, combates por turnos. Achei que faltou mais detalhamento no mapa, você percorre pequenas distâncias aonde não há muito para se ver, apenas alguns inimigos espalhados.

O jogo está todo em inglês apesar de ter um traço bem oriental. A história é bem recheada, porém muito simples. Por pior que seja seu entendimento em inglês, você acabará entendendo os diálogos e os tutoriais. O jogo tem todo um ar de anime, durante o decorrer das missões você se depara com intros que me lembraram bastante Sword Art Online.

10/10 - Enredo bem estruturado mas ao mesmo simples. Trilha sonora incrível e jogabilidade suave. Sobre as DLCs do jogo, não valem ser compradas fora de promoção, não adicionam nada essencial ao jogo.

21045260.review: This is, by far, is the best RPG game I've played in awhile, and that's saying something. Before I bought this game, I did some research, watched a few gameplays, poked about on information here and there and wasn't able to really gain much interest into wanting to play/ let alone buy it. However, during that time, I was quite bored and wasn't able to acquire or find the entertainment I was seeking in the games I played prior to this one. Thus I decided to give this game a chance, after all, I believe that you can't simply take the viewpoint or words of another and deduce instantly what the game itself holds or has in store for yourself. This game did not disappoint. The compelling storyline and diverse characters were what really captivated my interest throughout the game, and I cannot simply forget the complex fighting schematics involved. Regardless of how the combat might become quite repetitive after awhile, It simply never became a problem for me, I never tired nor grew old of viewing the same skill sets, nor felt weary of farming for a little while on some dungeon for a few minutes to an hour. I just played the game as it was, and was happy for how it is. Sure some of the graphics could have been better, or whatever else people would talk about afterwards, but I found this game to be good precisely how it was made, and am happy to have spent my X hours playing this game. I give this game a good 9.8/10 for captivating me in every turn, and making me feel and care about the characters in the story, to feel the same emotions they felt as they progressed through the story.

*Vague Spoilers*
My Pros:

- Lots of unlock and skills to collect/upgrade

- Reminded me of Kingdom Hearts at first glance
- Get stabbed to unlock your power

- Simple, so you don't have to think so hard about playing this. Give the gamer brain a break

My Cons:
- Some characters are extremely irritating. 
- Lots of dialogue scenes (skip became my best friend) 
- 3D camera felt awkward at times, either hovering too high or too low behind the character, Wish it was a tad further back to have a wider range of view
- Hooking up my PS4 controller was annoying. Might not be a game problem but it interrupts the game flow when the controls get 'stuck'. I've read that other people have this problem too. Sucks right? 
- Very simple, so don't get this for the challenge

Mix:
- After playing Skyrim, the turn-based combat was irritiating for a long while. Also, as with most turn-based combat, it can get stale and repetitive. Luckily, it's pretty. 

As my second Anime game, it's far more enjoyable that the first one I ever played. I want to get stronger, unlock more, collect all the furies, and free the lady. So that's a good thing right? It makes me want to do those things and keep playing. 

(PS I did get this game on Sale with all the DLCs so that may have sweetened my attitude towards it)

20914909.review:
This is a fun JRPG with a great soundtrack, loveable characters, and a healthy dosage of "Really, Japan?" If you thought Hyperdimension Neptunia was fun, but a little over the top, this may just be for you.  Gameplay is nearly identical - running around maps which you can alter, collecting hidden items for quests, smacking monsters to battle them, and jumping for absolutely no reason other than to gain those stats!  The storyline is more serious though - and that's a good thing!

Your story follows Fang as he tries to collect fairies known as "Furies" to unseal the Goddess before the Vile God awakens.  You meet various other characters with Furies along the way, and come together to stop the inevitable other faction which wants the Vile God to awaken.  The story takes a fantastic turn which really lengthens gameplay and gives you an appreciation for the characters.  I highly recommend this game!

20907190.review:
[b]THE WAIFU WARS
PART 03:[/b] FAIRY FENCER F

The exams are over. You breathe a sigh of relief
as you close your eyes on the couch, with the
erratic weather outside  shifting from rainy to 
sunny, as if in sync with Summer-Rain's own
name and temperament. You glance over to your 
phone and thumb through, seeing Mrs. Novocaine's
message from the time of Melody's Escape.

Wondering why she wanted to talk suddenly, you
open and see a long message about how so much
has changed for her and she wishes to try to
reconnect with you, and that she might have made
a terrible mistake. You turn off your phone's screen,
disgusted. Booting up your computer, something
greets you on the store page with petticoats,anime
and swords.

[b]FAIRY FENCER F.[/b]

Raising an eyebrow, you click [i]'buy'[/i]. Minutes later,
you're in a land of sword-and-sorcery with a vague
hint of technology, and as you progress through the
surprisingly riveting and engaging story, guides and
walkthroughs describe how Fairy Fencer F has links
to the [i]Hyperdimension Neptunia[/i] games. 

The story, in all its bright technicolor anime glory,
is more than serviceable, with a healthy selection of
waifus who serve as weapon upgrades (!), so much
so that you find yourself lost in the semi-open world
as well. You explore the world as the selfish slacker
[b]Fang[/b], 'duped' to become a [i]Fencer[/i], a warrior using
waifu-weapons, such as his Fairy-weapon-waifu [b]Eryn[/b].

Along the way, you meet the stunning, highbrow, 
gothic-lolita [b]Tiara[/b], another Fencer who is manipulative,
cunning and a closet sadomasochist, together with the
buxom [b]Harley[/b] and the mysterious, mecha-commanding
[b]Galdo[/b]. The quest is a simple one where the story takes
unexpected turns- the Fairies need to be collected and
their power harnessed to reawake a Goddess chained 
after an apocalyptic battle, but things might be more
than they seem.

You fall asleep as you pull out the sixth Fairy sword 
from the Goddess's body in the underground vault,
before waking up to what you realize is your head
on two soft thighs and the strong scent of 
strawberries.

[i]"...Summer... I can explain..."[/i] You stir, before seeing
Summer-Rain's perfume bottle on the table in front
of you. You stop dead in your sentence, knowing
that she doesn't make it a point to show off things
like Tiara or Ms. Novoc-

[i]"Morning."[/i] The soft voice says while you turn in her
lap, the burnished afterscent of cigarrettes being
masked by the strawberry perfume. Your face turns
into one of intense indignation. [i]"Novocaine."[/i]

[i]"Starboy. I... We need to talk."[/i]

[i]"YOU need to talk, but not me."[/i] You are about to
leap out, but at that instant, Summer-Rain walks in
the living room, busy with a box of cake and a tub
of ice cream to celebrate the end of the term. Your
blood runs cold, and Mrs. Novocaine looks livid.

Summer-Rain stares at the both of you, having
dropped everything. [i]"...Starboy....?!"[/i] Summer-Rain
begins, her lip shaking and her eyes filling with tears.

[i]"Summer...! I was playing Fairy Fencer F, and- and- 
I can explain!"[/i] Mrs. Novocaine looks at the both of
you before she grabs your arm, snuggling up to you
and giving Summer-Rain a bitchy look. [i]"Yes...! DO
explain, hun!"[/i] Your blood turns to block ice when
you hear the pet name that Ms. Novocaine used to
call you. 

[i]"You have ten seconds to explain yourself!"[/i] 
Summer-Rain demands, shaking. You realize the
situation is delicate, especially after all that has
transpired these last few days. Novocaine wanting
you back. Summer-Rain by your side. The universe
is still turning somehow, despite these two living
Goddesses vying for power over you and your
heart. Your two Fairies.

[i]"I was playing Fairy Fencer F and fell asleep from
the exhaustion of the exams when I woke up to
find my head in Ms.- I mean Mrs. - Novocaine's
lap, and I was about to tell her to get out when
you came in!"[/i] You blubber, as Summer-Rain burns
holes through you with her death stare.

[i]"No hun! Didn't you enjoy our little reunion after
all this time...?! Didn't you like playing with-"[/i]

Summer-Rain screamed then, and screamed all
kinds of profanities that you never thought she,
or any other woman would even utter. All this
vitriol and bile she had was built up over the
years, and now she was letting Mrs. Novocaine
really have it. Mrs. Novocaine fell silent and
when it was finally over, she left without a word,
clicking the door shut behind her, leaving both
you and Summer-Rain looking at each other in
stunned silence.

[i]"I thought you'd never believe me..."[/i] You say,
breaking the silence after finally meeting her
eyes. Both of you are close to crying, realizing
how much you truly love one another.

[i]"I'm not her, Starboy."[/i] She says, reminding
you of how Ms. Novocaine always gave you
trouble when it came to faith. [i]"Ice cream's
melting. Gimme some help-"[/i] You ignore 
Summer-Rain's deadpan way of trying to gloss
over the situation and rush to give her a hug.

[i]"I love you, Summer."[/i] You whisper. She hugs
you back tighter, not wanting to let go.

[i]"I know, Starboy. I know."[/i]

[b]FAIRY FENCER F.[/b]

20882597.review:
So here's the thing about Fairy Fencer F. Its one of many modern Jrpgs that focuses more on style than substance. The two minute long video on the store page is testament to this. Its not a game for everybody, but those who like this sort of thing will probably enjoy Fairy Fencer F.

Here's a pro/con list of some things I noticed while playing the game.

Pro:
-The battle system can be very flashy and exciting
-There is lots in the way of equipment, items to keep you scouring the game
-The female characters are pretty hot (Yes its a video game but the characters adequetly represent the image of beauty by which they were designed)

Con:
-The dialogue is terrible. Its just bad. I suppose you might enjoy it if you're a diehard anime fan or teenager. But as someone who prefers dialgue that is both well-written and engaging I found this to be unbearable.
-The main character is on-par with the most annoying characters in Jrpg history (right up there with Squall and Tidus)
-There is little in the way of exploration or engaging interaction with the world. You pick an area, go into a dungeon, deal with random cutscenes filled with nonsequitor dialogue then head back to the hub screen. There are no towns, no npcs living in the world, no depth or quirkiness to establish the world as anything more than the 2D backdrop for all the fluff and nonsense this game calls a story.

I'd keep playing this game if I had nothing else to play ONLY because the combat can be mildly enjoyable in short bursts. It is ABSOLUTELY not worth the retail price. Even at 70% off (8.99) I'm hesitant to recomment a purchase. I'd say get this ONLY if you're a wild fan of the waifu anime girls, 14 years old, and struggle getting into games with deep and engaging plotlines.
