20799594.review:
A solid JRPG that's a nice way to unwind after a hard day at work/school/being a rich bastage and swimming in a vault of good coins.

It's kinda hard to describe what makes this game such a joy because it's really just a matter of a polished gestalt. Every bit of design - art, music, animation, game designs - is INTELLIGENT and comes together sensibly. To give an easy example, you know how in some JRPGs, the animation times for your most powerful attacks can sometimes get tiresome because it just makes the battle TAKE SO LONG!? Well in Fairy Fencer, nearly all of them feel quick and snappy. With some notable exceptions, the game treats your time with respect. Dungeons never overstay their welcome and fights are quick and to the point, perhaps even too easy. Additionally, the voice acting is surprisingly solid, the dialogue is rather witty, and visuals are colorful and eye-catching. The characters may be heavily based on anime & RPG tropes, but they're all likeable in their own way (and the ones who aren't turn out to be villains har de har).

So I do thoroughly recommend this game, but with a couple pieces of advice. There's some "quests" that require rather onerous item grinding and there's a character that can only be unlocked if you're a certain level which requires some more grinding. I'm a bit of a reluctant completionist and so ended up doing these. In hindsight, I wish I hadn't. They don't appreciably advance the story and, in fact, make the game too easy. The result was that I finished with less excitement and joy than I otherwise would have. Unless you plan on beating the game 2x, I'd avoid the grinding. But then if you're gonna beat it 2x anyway, why worry about the grind the first time?

20655562.review:
[b]História[/b]

A história começa com Fang, [strike] um jovem que busca poder e quer destruir o mundo [/strike] um jovem que acaba escutando rumores sobre um tipo de "Fury", que são como são chamadas as "Almas" que na verdade são meio que fadas. Fang acaba encontrando uma Fury que estava selada na floresta, e ela resolve contar o objetivo de um Fencer, que irá mudar o futuro do mundo.

[b]Sobre o jogo[/b]

[i]Dificuldades de inicio?[/i]

Dificuldade é alguém ter! O jogo possui diversos tutoriais, que podem ser acessados a hora que quiser caso estiver meio... "perdido".
Em uma das telas principais, tem uma opção de "Enemy info", que são basicamentes a lista dos inimigos que você derrotou, de inicio pode parecer "sem utilidade", mas futuramente mostrará sua verdadeira utilidade.
Fora que também tem alguns personagens secretos, que precisam cumprir certas etapas extras para serem desbloqueados.
Bem, não vá pensando também que o jogo é fácil, depois de você avançar um pouco as coisas começam a complicar e se prepare para o rage. Good Luck!
Depois de você obter um certo progresso [i]In-game[/i] aparecerá diversas side-quest e funções (tanto em combate, como fora).
A Jogabilidade é fácil de se aprender e entender, possui também um sistema que é um pouco simples de Combo e possui uma ótima trilha sonora!
E o melhor de tudo é a personalidade dos personagens. 
O jogo também possui 3 finais.

Depois que zerar você simplesmente tem a opção de "continuar", só que começaria uma nova Playthrough.
Depois que tiver iniciado essa nova Playtrough você ainda irá ter os mesmos itens, leveis e etc... da sua primeira Playthrough, a diferença é em que os membros da sua Party você terá que conseguir denovo ao longo do jogo, só que com o mesmo level, itens e etc...

O objetivo é encontrar todas as Furys e reviver a "Goddess" que no seu passado teve uma batalha mortal com o "Vile God" e acabaram sendo os 2 selados pelas Furys, basicamente: Goddess = Trazer a paz / Vile God = Lado negro da força

[b]DLCs[/b]

O jogo possui DLCs, eu não comprei todas mas até onde sei elas são bem "OPs";

[b]Segue a lista das DLCs:[/b]

[b]• Hot Springs  e Swiwear Set  [/b]

Adiciona somente novas "outfits" para os personagens.
Possui também um aumento em defesa mágica/ataque mágico.
(Matar o boss final com toalha de banho, QUEM NUNCA? XD)

[b] • Weapon Change Acessory Pack [/b]

Adiciona novas skins (para ser mais exato 3) para cada membro de sua Party.
Cada skin possui seu bônus que por sinal (pelo menos de inicio...) "apelões" 

[b]• Additional Fairy Pack [/b]

Adiciona novas fadas Rank C, com status equivalente a uma A, ou bem maior... 

[b]• Surpass Your Limits Set [/b]

Essa DLC permite você upar seus personagens até o nivel... 999! SIM, 999! O-O
E adiciona 3 novas áreas para você upar.

[b] • Ultimate Armor Pack [/b]

Adiciona novas armaduras, que aumentam signitivamente também o seu Status.

Cada DLC está por 2.20
(Sinceramente, eu achei razoavel o preço).

[b]Nota final:[/b] 10/10!

20617555.review:
I could write a long review, but I'll try to keep this kind of short. Besides, I'm biased.

I will try to keep this spoiler-free. Put simply, Fairy Fencer F might not be for everyone, but if you like turn-based JRPGs, lots of customization, or VN-styled cutscenes, it's perfect. Plus there are waifus. And husbandos, if you like that.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Runs very smoothly, even on my toaster computer (you can change resolutions too)
+ Tons of customization with World Shaping/Furies and the WP system
+ Cute art, cool designs, and likable characters, with character development!
+ Not your typical battle system - action yet turn-based, tension gauge which you use to 'Fairize' aka power up
+ Cool skills, and you can also skip them and make battles go much faster by holding down the Next button
+ Fully voiced in Japanese! Even the fairies are voiced!!
+ Multiple endings and subevents in a kinetic visual novel style; multiple playthroughs available/needed
+ Harley and Ethel

[b]YMMV[/b]
* Very easy without any way to change the difficulty
* Difficulty also doesn't change on next playthrough, though makes the playthrough much faster
* Synthesizing/alchemy and quest system, but don't have any real impact or incentives
* Some of the OST is memorable, but others are just typical RPG fare (I like the second Fairize song best)
* Dungeons and 3D look alright, but are reused and are fairly short
* Plot twist is only somewhat predictable, but a little frustrating

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Pretty bland setup with some stereotypes and a cliche JRPG backstory (two deities fought, good vs. evil, wish-granting)
- Characters might seem annoying at first (Fang was awful at the beginning, but even he matures by the end)
- No Harley or Ethel route [Edit: Looks like this was improved in Advent Dark Force, so get that!]
- Godly Revival has no effect on actual story (you'll see what I mean)

Basically, get it because Tiara is best girl.

20542533.review:
Before we start, keep in mind that I will make a lot of comparisons with Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2, that I will call from now on R2. I've made a review of that game too, so if you're curious go to my profile and read it.
Fairy Fencer F was a game that I bought shortly after R2, and paid full price. At first, I thought it was just a simplified copy of R2 and I left the game on the side for months. A week ago, I chose to give a chance to the game, and I'm really glad that I did, because it was a unexpected awesome journey.
Let's talk about the combat first: It's a turn-based JRPG, but you can move in your turn. Each character has a different attack range, and you move in your turn to reach the enemies to attack.  You can attack normally, use skills, magics, itens, escape, activate each characters special condition or Fairize. This last command can be activated when your tension gauge is full and it lets your character make a fusion with your fairy, making you temporally stronger and activating some special skills.
The normal attacks, unlike R2, only hit one enemy, despite the range of the weapon. Speaking of weapon, since your fairy is your weapon, you can boost the atributes and unlock skills, magics and normal attacks. For example, you can raise the amount of normal attacks you can perform in your turn, unlike R2 where all characters can attack 4 times and there is no ''skill tree'' to unlock.
You will collect more than 20 fairies in the game, and you can equip them to each character to make a resonance effect, and create some new abilities or boost some attributes in the equipped character. Since the story of the game talks about the battle of the Evil God vs the Godless, you can go to a certain shrine where both are pierced by many swords of different ranks, and you can use fairies of the matching rank to take away that sword in a battle and create a shaping effect on your fairy. This shapping effect will buff or debuff certain attributes or skills in the dungeons and some even change the enemies of those dungeons. 
Each character has some kind of achievement to complete, like ''Walk 1000m as the leader'' or ''Win 10 battles without taking damage''. Those achievements will raise stats like Agi, Str, HP, SP, etc. It's something that it's not present on R2 but it's now present on R3.
Leaving the combat mechanics behind, let's talk a little about the story and character development. Since Fairy Fencer F it's from the same creator as Hyperdimension Neptunia, and Neptunia it's a game with a lot of jokes, without taking itself too seriously (except if you take a specific route in R2 that it's dark as fuck), I was expecting the same here, and when the main character first appeared, I thought this game would be a bad copy of Neptunia. At first, Fang is basically an idiot and I wasn't liking the character in the first hours.
But the game managed to surprise me with one thing: character development. Soon, Fang starts to get more mature and the events around him force him to change. This is another crucial difference from R2: the story is way more serious. There will be blood, deaths and regrets. As the story progresses, even the way Fang talks change, reflecting his own change. There are three endings: the Normal End and two endings, one for each girl. I will not tell who they are. I've only got ''A girl ending'' but the romance felt convincing and I really cared if they would manage to stay together in the end, which is a surprise, giving that most games have bad developed character interactions and romances. Unfortunately, not all characters are developed and I didn't care about some of them in the end. There's one in specific that I think it's very stupid (Pippin), and ironically you can use him as a weapon in R2. 
Oh, there is another surprise too: the OST. The songs are awesome. Check them out on youtube.
But there are a few bad things, for example. there's just little world customization compared to R2, and less endings too compared to R2. The enemies are repetitive, only changing colors as they grow stronger, and some dungeons are repetitive too. Those are the same problems of R2, but I felt that there's only a few original enemies in Fairy Fencer F compared to R2. I missed some events and characters, but I don't feel like playing it again to complete what I missed, unlike R2 where I beat the game 3 times. 
That said, with it's great story, character development, combat mechanics and progression and an awesome OST, Fairy Fancer F is worth full price, and it's a game that I will always remember with care. If you like this genre, go ahead and buy it. You will not regret it.

+ I especially liked the the storyline, even though some parts were expectable/predictable (or partly expectable) it didn't make me hate the story or be like: I knew that, so this, and this, and this will happen so why should I finish the game... I just watch the ending annnnd yes as expected.. There is no spoon (*bad jokes are bad*)
+ Fighting animations and system are both on point (obviously fanservice is there)
+ Loveable characters (except Galdo and Pipin.... I hate them so much), voice acting (yes the English one aswell) and great dialogs with some humor in it :D 
+ Not too hard fighting to hate the game for being difficult, but enough hard to don't put it down for being too easy (boss fight are pretty balanced aswell)
+ Clever ideas in the game ( You will see I won't  spoil it to you... :) )

[u]Neutral:[/u]

~ Fanservice maybe ... (Actually I don't like fanservice but this my opinion, everyone have his/her own right to love or hate things so that's why I have put it here)
~ Similar fights, what I mean that there's not very much variety in the fights, but I still loved it so its kinda bad and good

[u]Negatives:[/u]

- Soooooo much grinding

so

much

grinding

- You have to replay the game 2 more times if you want to see all the endings (Which I really don't bother I liked this game I'll give it another shot :) )
- Achievment Struggle (I will explain later)
- Lola's greedines, but also she is my spirit animal. I looooooooove money <3 (Which brings us back to the grinding problem)
- Jumping system (the feeling when you have to kill the same enemies 10x more, because you missed a jump and have to use more items therefor you have to spend more money what you should give to Lola to get more quests, and so on, and so on .....*unrepeatable*.... there are still parts where I couldn't get cause the jumping)

[u]EDIT:[/u]

Yeah I said I tried to be as non-emotial as I could....  I failed as I see

[u]Emotional part:[/u]

Ah where should I start..

At first I thought: "This will be a basic like RPG storyline nothing to be so amazed about" but luckily I was wrong and I can totally understand that ~92% positive rating. The charatcers were the basics: The funny one, The hero, The need to be saved one, etc.. but they something plus which I can't put in words. The story as I mentioned were great but I won't pin-point it out because that would be a spoiler and rule #1 no big spoilers in reviews ;) It stars as you would expect to start but It becomes better turst me. So just wait and see ;)

As I played this game I never felt like I should put this down. Something always moved me to go back and fight and play this game.There were some "WTF?! Are you serious?!" moments in both meanings and some "Oh ffs" in both meanings aswell :D . Maybe these were the ones that kept me moving, because maybe I couldn't belive they were seriously about that. But as I played more and more I eventually finished this game (for once atleast) and I feel sad.... There's no more... It's over... Althought the ending is great, It's still over. It was a great journey I want to relive it again like I played it for the first time.

You can ask my friends, 90% of it (who know me well) will say that I'm not that emotional type of guy who cry on every death or etc. I'm the exact opposite, you can almost say I'm dead inside emotionally, but this game made me "feel" on some points...( Not like crying or etc. , but you can figure out what I mean. )

I COULD write more stuff like this, but I WON'T it would take a novel and you are here a review. (And it would get akward... :D )

[u]In short:[/u]
Great game, great story, great characters and DEFIENETLY worth the money (DLC not necessary to the game it just plus items and dungeon, but you won't get more in the story if you don't buy them) 9/10 because of the small bugs and problems, but one of the best games I played so far. Love it <3 CAN'T WAIT TO SEE THE NEW GAME COMING OUT

[u]BEGINNER'S GUIDE:[/u]
1. When you get a character use your points for the LEARNING skill. Trust me I had to struggle without it AND it will help alot in the late game. No spoilers :)
2. Upgrade your teammates aswell in both skills and items (SPOILER [spoiler] Expect Lord Sherman, trust me... Ok No more spoilers [/spoiler]
3. I suggest to you to focus on the main storyline, because you can acidentally trigger an alternative ending. (Like I did -.-+ )
You can find further help [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545335863]HERE[/url] , but it includes some spoilers (and also an achievement guide) , so finish the game first atleast once ;)
4. The cards: I like them but I don't suggest to go further then Level 2 in the badges, only IF you especially love one character. The Foil cards: yeahhh now thats a different story..... In overall they cost 12 or more dollars and the game cost app. the same. If you REALLY REALLY intend to get it or you just really liek that character I won't stop you but you won't get you mony back. Backgrounds: Simple clean, great. If you hit the jackpot you get a 3 dollar background which is the best in my opinion and also MONEYYYY $$$$$, Emote icons: Well you decide
More info [url=www.steamcardexchange.net/index.php?gamepage-appid-347830]HERE[/url]

Well that's it folks :) If you read it through I would appreciate a rating cause this is my very first long review :)

20518227.review:
典型的日式RPG，剧情方面还是不错的？不过PC版并不全。
说一下日式RPG和欧美RPG的区别，首先日式RPG的自由度很低，就像游戏中主角并不能掌握反派的生杀大权，一切都是设定好的，要是能让玩家选择就更好了（楷模或叛逆，道德点什么的），相反欧美RPG的自由度相对较大;不过背包和技能点设定我还是喜欢日式的，欧美RPG技能基本是点不全的，日式几乎都可以点满。还有欧美RPG的背包太小，虽然说为了写实。
话说1亿的成就真难做，还有普通结局那个成就是怎么回事，总有被牛头人的感觉。
要我来说游戏还是只得一玩的，就是谈话什么的能有选项就更好了。

20489074.review:
I thoroughly enjoyed Fairy Fencer F as is apparent by my play time. The game play is very similar to Hyper-dimension Neptunia and take the role of a third person turn based RPG. The level grinding in the game never got to tedious and each battle did require some strategy and the characters equipment and move customisation took quite a lot of thinking, you could also put certain effects on the dungeons which put even more thought into what to do. The story is overall very engaging a throws some unexpected curve balls that even I, an avid anime fan and RPG player didn't see coming, which should be commended. The humour in Fairy Fencer F should also be praised, it had me laughing quite a few times. The characters are one of the best parts of the game, the main character, Fang's character development was really incredible as he retains his attitude but at the same time turns into an empathetic character who genuinely cares about his friends. The other characters such as Tiara and Eryn get little to no character development (excluding Ethel, best girl) but are still funny, admirable and relatable, you really do come to care about these characters. The music was also overall good though some tracks did start to lose some appeal after a while they still remained decent to listen to. There is also a fair amount of stuff to do after you finish the game and is impossible to do everything in one play through. Okay I've talked this game up enough time to delve into it's flaws.

First of all the difficulty, in my first play through I completed the game in about 32 hours during that time I died twice. For clarification one of those times was because I wasn't paying attention to the game and did one battle too many while EXP grinding. As long as you aren't a complete idiot and pay attention this games difficulty isn't that high and overall isn't the most challenging though I'm an RPG veteran. Secondly, there was a point where they say you have to pull all the swords out of goddess to unseal them and then they completely forget about it and it has no impact on the ending. Thirdly, the ridiculous hidden characters/fairies, as an RPG I understand secret characters are going to be difficult to unlock but Lola's requirements are really unforgiving as you need to complete all of her side quests, which are really easy to miss. For the two S-rank fairies I have no issue but one particular A-rank fairy, Dohn, is completely asinine much worse than Lola. To unlock him you need to do a  pub request that only appears when you haven't completed a certain dungeon and you have to complete it immediately and you get it after you complete the dungeon. Now you might think that's not so bad but allow me to provide some context, you get given no signs that you get this fairy after completing this request, the quest is only available for a short while when you haven't completed a dungeon so you are viable to miss it. Adding onto the chance of missing it is the fact that pub requests barely offer any good rewards for completing them and most of the time you won't have requests high up on your priorities. All of this culminates in a fairy that even harder to get than the S-ranks.

I think that this game is for casual gamers who haven't got all the time in the world but can spare a couple hours a week to play this game. It's funny, engaging and entertaining.
Overall, a good game.

20480565.review:
For anyone on the fence about this game, it's your typical RPG-turn style fight kind of game with the ability to modify dungeons a little bit.  EXP boosts, Weapon upgrades, Drop increases and the like are all able to be modified a little bit.

The game has some cheesy lines, some pretty good references if you can spot them, and is overall fun to play. While the replayability is kind of low in my opinion (the 2nd playthrough thing is completely useless) and some of the secrets you won't even have a chance to think about unless you knew it was coming, but the characters are fun, the skits are really funny and of course, the Fan-Service isn't too bad. Multiple endings mean you'll have to play the game at LEAST 3 times before you see everything, but it's still a fun game.

If there was one thing I really didn't like about the game, it's the amount of time you have a particular party member in your group for. I know there are games where you lose your party members if you're not careful, like in most Fire Emblem games, but this was a little ridiculous.

Other than that, it's a fun game. Plenty of impelling plot-twists (some cliche others not so much) but all in all, a fine game.

20464855.review:
Excelente jogo. Une o melhor das tradicionais visual novels japonesas durante as cenas de história (onde são mostrados os personagens e o background do ambiente) e um sistema de exploração e batalha que lembra um pouco o sistema da série Tales. As batalhas são por turno mas você pode, em sua vez, mover o personagem com bastante liberdade no campo de batalha. A história não é nada do outro mundo mas tem suas revelações e consegue entreter por conta do carisma de alguns personagens. 

Pontos altos: Sistema de batalha interessante e consistente, fator replay enorme (impossível platinar em uma gameplay pois alguns itens só podem ser adquiridos em new game+), customização da aparência dos personagens, amplas possibilidades de building para cada personagem (considerando as diversas fairys que podem ser equipadas - cada uma altera de forma específica os status e as habilidades do personagem), clássica arte em anime com belas animações de golpes especiais e transformações.

Pontos fracos: A história poderia ser um pouco mais complexa/elaborada, algumas partes dos menus poderiam ser mais simplificadas (mas você se acostuma rápido).

Fica a sugestão para, em uma possível sequência, implantarem um modo versus online; colocar mais opções de trajes para alterar a aparência dos personagens; colocar diálogos em que o jogador tenha que optar por respostas específicas que possam mudar o curso da história e o relacionamento com cada personagem, dar maior espaço para as fadas, inclusive durante as batalhas. Talvez cada uma pudesse ser invocada limitadamente para usar um poder e sumir, tipo final fantasy

20452753.review:
🕹️- Fairy Fencer F é um joguinho de JRPG \ Fantasia bem interessante e bem diferenciado dos demais populares. Fairy Fencer F conta a história de um jovem chamado Fang, que esta destinado a conhecer e finalizar uma batalha que aconteceu contra 2 Deuses em um passado distante. Após o ocorrido, ele acidentalmente se torna um esgrimista de uma fada chamada Eryn. Com isso, Fang parte para a sua jornada que será libertar um dos Deuses que estão selados, e tentar saber mais sobre a fada Eryn.

🕹️- A história do game não é de muito destaque, pois ela é extremamente focada nos ocorridos com as fadas, nas descobras relacionadas aos Deuses e nas ações rápidas e conclusivas que o game te proporciona. Porem tem uma história com muitas reviravoltas e novidades inesperadas.

🕹️- O game contêm uma gama interessante de personagens, e isso faz com que o jogador utilize e varie os personagens de forma constante. Cada um desses personagens tem a sua personalidade diferenciada e muitas vezes bastante inusitadas, causando uma série de ações e reações inesperadas durante o gameplay.

🕹️- As fadas são um complemento extremamente inovador do game. Elas são na sua maioria de forma humana e se habita nos personagens de forma elementar. Cada fada tem o seu elemento terrestre e esse poder elementar é chamado de fury, com isso as fadas adicionam esse poder internamente, após se unirem aos personagens. Abaixo estará mais informações sobre o gameplay do game

[h1]Positivos[/h1]

🕹️- A história é precisa e muito objetiva, te proporcionando um gameplay de facil entendimento e seguimento.

🕹️- O sistema de batalha é em turnos e com muita praticidade, não causando nenhuma dificuldade de adaptação ao jogador  

🕹️- As técnicas e habilidades especias dos personagens são todas animadas, e isso causa um conforto visual para o jogador, e ainda contêm o modo fury, que é a adição e a união do poder das fadas para os personagens. 

🕹️- O game trás consigo, uma variedade enorme de fadas variadas, espalhadas pelo gameplay. Essas fadas podem ser utilizadas equipando elas nos personagens, e isso proporcionará um aumento no status de cada personagem.

🕹️- A trilha sonora do game é bastante diferenciada e muito agradável, destaque para a trilha sonora nas uniões das fadas com os seus esgrimistas.
 
[h1]Negativos[/h1]

🕹️- O game contêm uma opção chamada challenger no inventário de cada personagem. O que ela faz? ela te da uma série de objeções para serem feitas com cada personagem indivídualmente [u]EX: pule 1000 vezes[/u] 

🕹️- Fazendo esses challengers, voçê aumenta um pouco o seu ataque, sua defesa, o seu status em geral. Porem essa opção é completamente inútil e extremamente demorada, pois a dificuldade do game não demanda a obrigação dessa opção, ela é totalmente descartável do game. 

🕹️- O game é consistido de uma única cidade habitável e de inúmeras dungeons, e isso acaba causando um cansaço enorme no jogador, pois o mesmo terá que ir e voltar inúmeras vezes nos mesmos locais e sem nenhuma inovação, pois só muda a entrada ou o lado das dungeons.
  
🕹️- O game também contêm uma vasta gama de quests para serem feitos, onde as recompensas são até valiosas. Porem a maioria dos quests são extremamente mal explicados, causando uma dificuldade enorme para o jogador entender a explicação do quest e como finalizar o mesmo.

🕹️- O game tem uma dungeon chamada Shukesoo's Tower, da qual o jogador passará por alguns andares no decorrer do gameplay. Porem não tem como finalizar essa dungeon futuramente, sem estar comprando um conteúdo adicional do game. E isso é totalmente frustrante, obrigando o jogador a  comprar todos os itens adicionais do game.

[h1]No geral é um ótimo game para o jogador que busca um Rpg bem diferenciado e muito carismático.

Nota - 9 \ 10

同时选择艾琳结局或者分手结局

讲讲我认为难的成就攻略：

4.一个妖精武器MAX：所有项目全部解锁才行，包括所有招式

20351211.review:
Ho sentito parlare di giochi come Hyperdimension Neptunia, ma non ho mai avuto il piacere di giocarli.

Quando ho comprato questo gioco pensavo di ritrovarmi qualcosa alla Final Fantasy ma con uno stile diverso e non sono rimasto deluso, nonostante lo consideri il primo J-RPG che ho giocato per intero.

Il gioco vi terrà occupati molte ore, soprattutto se volete completarlo tutto e scovare tutti i segreti, facendovelo rigiocare anche 2-3 volte. Un combat system che ho apprezzato, non c'era un singolo personaggio che odiassi (beh a parte 1), e la storia era carina.
L'idea della fata che risiede nell'arma mi ricordava leggermente l'anime Soul Eater, anche se il concetto è diverso, in quanto la fata non si trasforma in arma ma può risiedere al suo interno, anche per potenziare il possessore dell'arma stessa.

Le uniche cose che secondo me si potevano migliorare sono: 

- Il sistema di raccolta di minerali, in quanto molti non verranno mai droppati dai nemici e dovrete cercare i tesori nascosti usando l'abilità del radar. Il problema è che c'è solo un tesoro nascosto per area, il che vi farà fare dentro-fuori dai dungeon molte volte, se volete craftare certe cose, la cosa sicuramente giova per quelli che vogliono farmare un po' di livelli ma dopo un po' ti assale la stanchezza.

- Il fatto che ricominciando la partita in New Game +, i nemici non diventeranno più forti rispetto alla partita precendente, perciò nei primi momenti molti nemici saranno un 1-shot-city.

Detto questo, se sapete l'inglese, vi consiglio questo gioco assolutamente, sia che abbiate giocato ad altri J-RPG sia che sia la vostra prima esperienza.

20261684.review:
[h1]Vorwort:[/h1]
Zu allererst einmal möchte ich an dieser Stelle erwähnen, dass dies mein erstes Review bzgl. eines Steamgames ist und ich dementsprechend eventuell ein wenig von der Norm abweichen werde bzw. meine Bewertungskriterien anders gestaffelt sein werden. Aber nun gut, fangen wir an.

[h1]Genre:[/h1]
Fairy Fencer F ist mit Sicherheit ein klassisches Beispiel des JRPG Genre. Wir lesen recht viel Dialog, machen einzelne Missionen und lesen noch mehr Dialog. Man könnte es schon glatt als Visual Novel durchgehen lassen, gäbe es nicht das Kampfsystem.
Wer bis dato keine Erfahrungen in dieser Richtung gemacht hat, wird mit Fairy Fencer F [b]sicherlich nicht glücklich[/b] und sollte hier aufhören zu Lesen. Es gibt andere Spiele, die deutlich besser zum Einstieg geeignet sind, wenn man sich mit dem Genre JRPG oder Visual Novel befassen möchte.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
Ich würde behaupten, dass die Story bei Fairy Fencer F sehr generisch gehalten ist.
Vor Urzeiten, bekriegten sich die Göttin, die alles Gute verkörpert und der finstere Herrscher, der alles Nöse verkörpert aufs Äußerste. Dabei benutzen sie die sogenannten Furys, (Eigenname für Schwerter) und letztendlich haben sie sich gegenseitig aufgespießt und versiegelt. Einige Furys verfehlten ihr Ziel jedoch und landeten auf der Erde, wo sie fortan darauf warten von der richtigen Person gefunden zu werden.
Nun wechselt die Story von diesem dramatischen Hintergrund, auf unseren künftigen Protagonisten Fang der durch die Straßen schlendert und Hunger hat. Ein einfacher Stadtbewohner sagt im Scherz, dass wenn er das Fury Schwert dort hinten ziehen kann, ihm die dort drin gefangene Fairy jeden Wunsch erfüllen kann. Er zieht das Schwert natürlich ohne Probleme und so kommt es zum schicksalshaften Treffen zwischen Eryn und Fang, die nach einer kleinen "Zusammenrauf" - Phase losziehen, um alle verbleibenden Furys zu Sammeln und die Göttin wiederzuerwecken.

Erst ab Mitte des Spiels hat man dabei einen gewissen Plottwist, der sich aber eher auf die Charaktere auswirkt, als auf die Story.

Ist die Story deswegen schlecht ? Nein. Nur wie gesagt ist sie eben auch nichts Besonderes. Es ist einfach eine "normale" Story, für das Genre.

[h1]Charaktere:[/h1]
Diese sind allesamt, wie aus einem Anime herausgeschnitten. 

[list]
    [*]Fang - faul,gefräßig / besitzt aber ein gutes Herz und ist ernst, wenn es darauf ankommt
    [*]Eryn - pflichtbewusst und ständig Fang am Kritisieren, weil er kein "guter" Fencer ist
    [*]Tiara - die masochiste, verzogene Prinzessin mit tragischer Vergangenheit
    [*]Harley - der "Plot" in diesem Spiel und ist diese zerstreute und sorgenfreie Forscherin
    [*] - - - Ich will nicht mehr vorweg nehmen, aber diese Charaktere sind einfach nichts Neues
[/list]

Erst ab dem bereits angesprochenen Plottwist, ändert sich Fang etwas und wird ernsthafter und reflektiert sein Handeln etwas. Die anderen Charaktere allerdings nicht. Lediglich ein weiterer Charakter ändert sich massiv, aber das wäre Spoilern der Story.

Die Charaktere waren nicht schlecht, aber irgendetwas fehlte, was sie halt etwas gepusht hätte. So weiß man beispielsweise selbst am Ende der Story Nix über Fangs Vergangenheit.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Das wird wohl die Meisten interessieren. Fairy Fencer F, setzt hierbei auf viel Dialog und Kampf. Sprich ihr geht in die Stadt, dort geschehen ein paar Events und habt ihr die alle durch, rückt eure Gruppe wieder aus um die Welt zu retten (Furys zu Sammeln).
Die Dialoge sind vorgegeben und man hat keine Möglichkeiten darauf Einfluss zu Nehmen. Es gibt lediglich 2 Schlüsselsituationen oder Events, die zu unterschiedlichen Enden führen. Ziemlich mau, wie ich finde.

Ein recht gutes System ist das Worldshaping. Dort könnt ihr eure Fairys dazu benutzen einem Dungeon gewisse (De)buffs zu verabreichen und somit zum Beispiel euren Schaden oder EXP erhöhen. War ein nettes Feature.

Das Kampfsystem hingegen war gut. Es ist klassischerweise ein Rundenbasiertes und ermöglicht auch das Benutzen von Combos, sowie dem Setzen von Schwerpunkten bei den Charakteren.
Nur ist es nie so schwer, dass ich tatsächlich ins Schwitzen gekommen wäre. Die einzige Herausforderung waren Bosse, aber auch die konnte man im Zweifelsfall nach ein paar Grinding Einheiten, bequem in die Pfanne hauen.
Das Spiel bietet also die Möglichkeit des taktischen Tiefgangs, aber setzt es nicht voraus. Da war "The Last Remnant" deutlich anstrengender, wo ich minuziös meine Taktiken planen musste um zB eine Belagerung zu schaffen.

Und damit kommen wir zum Grinding. Ja, ich habe es gehasst. Einige Charaktere die sich im weiteren Spielverlauf anschließen, erfordern das der Charakter ein bestimmtes Level erreicht und somit habe ich 2 ganze Stunden damit verbracht im gleichen Dungeon Monster zu töten und es hätte mich noch mehr Zeit gekostet, hätte ich nicht einen +90% EXP Boost via World Shaping auf den Dungeon gesetzt. Das ist kein gutes Gamedesign !

[h1]Soundtrack:[/h1]
War gut. Einige davon waren recht passend und hängen mir noch im Ohr. Gerade die Kampfmusik die ich viel zu oft Hören durfte... Ein wenig Vielfalt hätte hier nicht geschadet

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Fairy Fencer F ist ein sehr generisches und klassiches JRPG. Viel Text, solide Kampfaction und wenig Bedarf an Taktik. Ich bin da recht schnell durchgekommen, aber die multiplen Enden konnten mich noch nicht reizen, es erneut durchzuspielen. Eventuell hole ich dies irgendwann nach.
Den Vollpreis ist mir dieses Spiel übrigens nicht wert. Ich denke bis ca 15€ ist Alles in Ordnung, aber die 27.99€ sollte keiner freiwillig Zahlen.

Ich kann dieses Spiel also bedingt Empfehlen. Wer schon einmal in der Richtung etwas gespielt hat, wird gut mit dem Spiel zurechtkommen und es wahrscheinlich mögen. An alle Neueinsteiger - lasst es besser und kauft euch einen FF-Teil dafür.

20232148.review:
The game so far has some good and bad stuff that makes you think it's a good game, yet makes you want to stop playing it. The DLCs improve the game a bit in case you need some help or looking for some little costumes. The game has some good soundtracks along with characters that will make you love/hate as the story progresses.

I won't recommend this game because it's missing some stuff that makes me frustrated at it each time I face an enemies.
1.) When going into dungeons, you assume the monsters will be a certain element depending on the dungeon, but most of monsters you fight are neutral or have no element which makes using Magic spells for elemental weakness pointless.
2.) The explanation about stats is NEED and MANADATORY at the beginning of the game, nowhere in the Help section gives a brief summary about what each stats improves. You have to assume that the stats in this game is similar or exactly like other RPG games you played.

Like I said, I haven't beaten the game, but these are some stuff that should've been added in the game for people that are new to JRPG.

20226752.review:
g-SCORE: [1.8]

Fairy Fencer F turned out to be a fun title, but did not have enough pull for me. I liked the Anime style comedy and dialogue, but the combat and progression just didn't keep me interested.

g-Rating Categories: 

>>gameplay [1] 
The game is basically dialogue and combat. There is no exploration really. You unlock different areas of the map as you progress, but they are stand-alone dungeons. The dialogue was great as was the Anime-style humor, but I couldn't get into the combat. It's turn-based inside an "encounter" arena that lets you move around to position before attacking or performing some other action. I think a more traditional turn-based RPG encounter mechanic would have been better (no movement) because the camera got in the way and honestly I didn't find the positioning to offer much variety from a strategic perspective. It was basically move >> attack, move >> attack.  

>>graphics [2] 
The dungeons were very bland and generic, but the cutscenes and character art were awesome. 

>>gui [2] 
I played with a keyboard mostly. Although there were times when I had to use the mouse because sometimes keys were not mapped to some actions (like selecting a character to heal).

>>glitches [3] 
Solid. No bugs.

>>gasp [1]
I'd rather watch an Anime.

Best possible score is a [3.2].

20223304.review:
When I got gifted this game, I had about 0 expectations for it. I expected it to be some anime bullshit that I might find amusing and I was curious about the combat. What it actually ended up being was possibly my GOTY 2015 and that’s not even a joke.

Initially, Fairy Fencer F seems like it’s pretty much stupid bullshit that gets by on being moderately amusing and has really anime jokes that are tired and obnoxious- a refined woman who’s slightly masochistic, a busty blond who’s too casual about nudity, the same shit you’ve rolled your eyes at a thousand times if you like anime. And at the start of the game, the combat’s nothing special either, as like most RPGs it has the terrible habit of not giving you many tools other than “press attack, maybe cast a spell if you’re feeling saucy” for the first hour of the game.

What made me keep playing was the UTTER goofiness of Fairize (a sort of super mode you get) and the music that comes with it. Full Contact starts with the lines METAPHORPHOSIZE YOUR HEART, UNLEASH THE HELL INSIDE and doesn’t get any less ridiculous from there, and every time you Fairize there’s a (skippable, something I was grateful for by hour 20) magical girl transformation cutscene where you impale yourself with your weapon. The other thing was the ridiculousness of the protagonist Fang, who starts off as a lazy hedonist who’s only glimmer of a better nature is agreeing to help his fairy partner when she reveals that she’s lost her memory. The writing is genuinely enjoyable too, although early on is marred by the previously mentioned anime staple “jokes”.

However, it only gets better. The battle system opens up, and while disappointingly I never felt challenged to prove my mastery of the combat system, it was still interesting and engaging to learn and improve at. The game’s one real flaw to me (aside from fanservice, especially with Harley) is it’s just too easy- a flaw that’s only noticeable because the battle system is so good you can feel that there’s room for real challenge outside of “my numbers are higher”. The story and characters meanwhile, skyrocket in quality, with everyone quickly becoming likeable, the main character having a real and noticeable character arc, and the tone seamlessly and naturally escalating in scope and gravity without ever having a jarring “when did the comedy end” moment. Even some of the tired jokes get used in actually funny ways, and the rest fade into the background or simply vanish.

Fairy Fencer F is legitimately a great game, which is the absolute last thing I expected it to be. I highly advise anyone who has any interest in RPGs or anime-y games to pick it up.

Also, it has accessories like in a Tales game, and that’s awesome. They’re also reflected in the transformation cutscene, as are alternate costumes (of which there are very few)

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=587697879]Look at that goofy little plush.[/url] Buy this game, seriously, it’s good.

Good game, but may not suit everyone. 

It deserves at least 6/10 if not 7/10

Pros:
-Great Stort
-Great, believeable characters
-fluid and strategic combat, although turn based - not everyone likes this system, I do.
-Animations are great.
-Models and graphic are on a very good level.

Cons:
-Dungeons don't offer that much, except enemies and some teasures + they are rather short.
-You don't really choose any decisions most of the time, so it is not an RPG like let's say Fallout New Vegas. BUT, it is still great, since the story is amazing.
-A bit Grindy.
-Doesn't have much replayability.

If you are into strategic RPGs and you like anime characters, they you are going to enjoy it. However I advise you to wait for a Advent Dark Force, which will be better most likely.

PS: I had more fun with this game than with Fallout 4 :)

19891026.review:
I'm going to preface this review by stating that it has spoilers for some intricate game mechanics as well as light "plot" spoilers. If you're against spoiling at all, you'll more likely not want to read this, otherwise read-on. There's plenty to talk about. 

I think the best way to describe my dissappointment with this game is to talk about all of my gripes with it, starting with grinding. First of all, I'm the type of person who doesn't mind grinding in games, heck I might even say I enjoy it and don't find any trouble in throwing countless hours doing the same repetitive actions when I want to. My troubles are with how the game handles it - poorly.

For starters, it makes no sense to invest anything in magic. The game has this system named "Shaping Effect", which allows you to change how the dungeon is going to be played. They have lots of effects, and some are really beneficial, like raising EXP gotten, or WP (points gained in battle to upgrade characters' skills and spells), but they all come with negative effects (unless you have an S rank Shaping Effect). These EXP and WP modifiers come with negative effects like raising SP consumption to twice as much, making you take twice as much damage or just straight up Silencing and Sealing you so you cannot make use of spells or skills - since you're going to be grinding a good deal, it makes such Shaping Effects relatively useful. Couple that with how slow it is to select spells in the menus and how many commands you'd have to input, grinding becomes considerably more efficient with just regular attacks. You can literally set up the game to "autobattle" and just pressing X to end encounters within seconds if you're building your characters with Silence and Seal in mind, which trivializes pretty much everything. If you plan on grinding for the DLC areas, you're going to be spending a lot of time battling the same monsters just to get to the DLC and then battle the same monsters reskinned in the DLC area, just considerably more difficult, which feels very lazy and isn't really worth your time or money (wasn't worth mine at the least).

And even then, this game is pretty easy even without exploiting any clearly unbalanced mechanics, and it's not really a problem in itself, especially if you're not a very big fan of grinding, Fang (the main character) is just straight up broken, all other character are exchangeable among themselves. That is... until the game 'forces' you to grind ~10+ levels to get to Lv. 40 at a specific point in the story just to get a missable party member - which doesn't even make any sense - as the game does not explain why you have to be Lv. 40 to even get him (mind you, they didn't even reference it in the game, you'd have to look this up online), which is just very frustrating. What's the point of making a game easy if you're just going to force players to grind to attain their coveted 100% completion? Sure thing, you can just wait and unlock him on New Game Plus, but hey, that's a party member, why would I have to wait him to join me if I can just make him join me now?

Speaking of skills being useless, the game gives you access to a whole load of buffs / debuffs early on for fairly cheap WP and that made me think the game would be pretty awesome, with lots of choices in playstyle and whatnot. Sure, buffs are useful if you want to make use of them, but they're completely unnecessary - now debuffs are pretty much worthless. They'll work on regular mobs, which could be pretty good since they last for quite long, but more often than not do not work on bosses - the kind of encounters you'd actually want to debuff and buff yourself for - which is a major flaw. I mean, what'd be the point of using them in random battles if they're just going to end very quickly and waste your SP that could potentially be used for healing?

The game also has a wide varity of items in it, and they're mostly pretty nice but since you can just ignore all the SP restoring ones and you'll likely be overlevelled for most of it (enemies will barely be able to touch you) you'll likely not have any use for them (Aside from: Return Wings, the 'escape dungeon' item; Dimensional Clocks, the 'respawn all enemies item'). And when it comes to collectible items, quests can be really annoying. Some of them require you to steal from countless, specific monsters to get an arbritary number of non-droppable (or low rate drop) items, whose only way to acquire otherwise is to hope for them in RNG chests (which you really should not, as stealing is a lot quicker). Not to mention the highest-chance Steal skill has been bugged since the game first released on consoles and was never fixed, which just adds to frustration. Keep in mind the rewards for these quests are often not worth it.

The story is fairly cliché, although I don't mind it much. I just feel they could have invested and fleshed out more the secondary characters, especially Ethel and Pippin. There just isn't much to connect to, so you end up not caring much about most of them. The story also feels a bit lazy, and will often make you revisit areas due to it. You'll go 'back in time' and they'll be slightly different, having some new monsters and reskins here and there, but it's pretty much the same. It also adds insult to injury that a lot of dungeon layouts might as well be the exact same. I don't mind if you're trying to save costs and reuse some of the graphics, but you know something's wrong when your Final Dungeon is a carbon-copy of another place you've already been to.

As a conclusion, this isn't the worst JRPG I've played but it's sure as hell dissappointing - I really wanted to like it.
It has a lot of things going on for it, like pretty anime graphics and a great soundtrack (which by itself was amazing, but along the game gets oversaturated by repetition), but that alone isn't enough to offset the numerous poor game design choices they've made all throughout it. The game developers really dropped the ball on this. At the end I wasn't enjoying myself and just had to rush it to put the game to a close. I'll also likely not be touching New Game Plus, as I see no point in skimming through the game to see the missable content I've already screwed myself from getting my hands on. This game does not compel you to replay it through.

Such disappointing game. I wish I could refund it.

19888175.review: Although it plays slightly differently than its relative HyperDimension Neptunia, Fairy Fencer F has a lot of the fun and goofy quirkiness that you'd come to expect from the companies involved with the game. However unlike the HyperDimension series Fairy Fencer F takes on a slightly more serious approach to their story. The game's combat is a bit repetitive and that's the only complaint I have with the game (its combat system is quite similar to that of the HyperDimension series), however what really drew me in to this game are the whacky characters, particularly the lazy main character Fang. There are some good laughs to be had here and if you love the HyperDimension series then I can HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to you. If you're not a fan of those games however then honestly you may not like this one either, unless it was the characters in HyperDimension that turned you off. Either way, if you're in, then bear those fangs (pun-intended) and JUST DO IT.

19885708.review:
Enjoyed the game for a good playthrough at a good price even when the game is not discounted. This review is partially written as if one plays RPGs, but may not necessarily have played comparable games such as Hyper Dimension Neptunia Re;birth. Noting some points, whether they are pluses for some, minuses for others or neutral.

* Anime-styled 3D world with mid-to-low polygon count for adventuring characters
* Detailed animating dialogue portraits and occasional cut scene art
* Mostly smooth frame rate on a moderately powered computer up to 60 FPS
* Max resolution of 1920x1080
* Can be controlled with built-in game pad support or keyboard + mouse
* Can skip dialogue, events and fast forward combat to shorten repetitious or familiar content
* Multiple ways to alter a character's performance (expounded later) 
* Multiple endings and some missable content, but an option for New Game Plus to carry over much
* Optional side quest system that involves either killing X monsters, collecting Y number of materials or both for monetary rewards and frequently an item
* Optional crafting system that can provide more equipment options and recovery items when invested
* Some limited appearance customization options in-game with accessories and some costumes
* New Game Plus option if you want to try it all again
* Optional Tower and free Tower DLC to test your devotion to battle
* Up to 99 save slots in-game

Aspects I enjoyed and/or are more opinionated:
* Great English voice acting if you have an ear for it and if you don't, then there's Japanese voice with English subs
* Overall good soundtrack with some orchestrated tracks
* Great English localization
* Overall good character development of the main cast
* Game story and optional dialogue leans toward light-hearted comedy with several serious situations and dark themes

Combat:
* Takes place with up to three party members with the ability to swap inactive characters
* When your ally takes a turn, they can move around on the field, aim their attack(s) and spell(s) to hit one or more enemies
* Different enemies are vulnerable to different weapons and elements, with customizable combos allowing you to exploit these weaknesses (e.g. using a bow against flying enemies, having a sword handy for enemies vulnerable to slashing)
* The possibilities of combat were enjoyable before finding a combination of options that would clear most encounters before the enemy could act

Expounding on Character Advancement:
* Characters can improve stats through mini-achievements such as taking X amount of damage increasing max HP (health), running Y distance increases max AGI (turn order) or defeating Z amount of enemies increases STR (physical damage)
* Characters can discover and equip fairies with different foci and level them up, where one fairy may enhance your physical damage and sword skills, another fairy may improve your fire resistance and fire spells in exchange of making you vulnerable to another element
* Fairies can receive additional customization by adding traits to enhance their strengths, make up for their shortcomings or vary their play style such as improved weapon proficiency, reduced SP costs or increased elemental resistance
* Characters earn points after battle that can be used to improve stats such as strength, magic, attack range, etc. as well as be used to unlock new abilities, spells or combo attacks with different weapon styles
* Fairies can be deployed to change adventuring conditions such as increased money, but reduced defenses or increased experience, but inability to recover HP - these can be compiled for increased rewards and risk
* Gear is a mix of horizontal and vertical growth, allowing for specialized defenses, balanced defense or enhanced offensive capabilities

ESRB/Content Advisory:
* Frequent animations that bounce breasts both in low polygon combat and in high-detailed portrait dialogue
* Few instances of near nude anime women with no nipples - e.g. strategically covered by hair, shirt being removed or holy armor)
* Camera angle easily adjusted for pantie access and doesn't need to be adjusted once optional swimsuits are purchased
* Some bare chested anime men taking baths and one mostly bare-chested man fairy
* One odd elderly man warrior who joins the party while being fully nude, but has no genitalia or butt defined
* Some violence-based blood depicted on portraits and cut scene(s), as opposed to sexy nosebleeds
* Some violent NPCs who harm elderly, women, children and innocents in text depictions
* Some text depicted gore of an NPC
* Occasional language such as b*tch and sh*t

19871732.review:
This is a difficult one. I played this game for only 1.5 hours - and I got bored to death already! ^^ Obviously, Anime fans seem to like it. And I can see why. But to me, what I saw so far was not very appealing. Dialogue is presented in visual novel style, with solid voice actors. What I disliked about it is how absolutely not serious it is. They try to be funny all the time. They try to be cute. And it has this childish/family friendly touch. This is just not what I want from a RPG. I am not an Anime fan, but I am open to it. There were a few Animes I enjoyed. But I like the more serious ones. Not the cute ones. The story might have been interesting to me, but I just don't like how it is presented in this game. The gameplay doesn't seem to be very special. Standard JRPG turn-based combat, as far as I can tell. It's not bad, but it's also not enough to keep me playing despite the mentioned things I dislike about the game. So while I can see that it's probably a nice game for others, it's just not for me. Even after this short amount of time, I am pretty sure I won't play any more of it.

And I am completely aware, that I will most likely get downvoted like crazy here. ^^ But that's ok. The review should reflect my personal opinion. And my opinion is that I just don't enjoy the game. And I am sure there are people out there who would feel the same. So that's why I have to give it a thumbs down. I am sure the game can stand one thumb down, with otherwise 93% positive reviews. ;)

19777308.review:
Fairy Fencer F is a lazy game, with a weak plot, that can be pretty fun if you catch it on sale.  I'm a little caught on whether to upvote or downvote, the flaws are SO numerous with this game, but it is still pretty enjoyable.  I'll tell you now, the game is very much average in my book (50-55% or 70-75% depending on what you consider "average").  

First I'll address my "lazy" comment: why is the game lazy?  First, the battle system is just a tweaked version of what you may very well have seen five or six times before in the company's "Neptunia" series.  If it ain't broke, I'm certainly not going to tell them to fix it, though, because they might make something decidedly less inobtrusive.  As it stands, the battle system is fairly enjoyable, you're given some freedom in picking which Persona *cough* I mean, Fairy to use, which augments your stats and grants you certain bonuses and debuffs that might effect your adventure through a dungeon, like an exp bonus at the expense of having lower defense, more money but harder enemies spawn, etc.  As you earn experience, you also earn secondary exp referred to as "WP," which you can apply to the stats of your choice (if by choice, you mean adding extra attacks in battle through leveling Combo!).  Battle play out very....slowly...as characters have played out attack animations and the game requires a lot of loot farming to finish missions, luckily, this is rendered much less annoying by the fast forward button they let you use to skip animations.  Of course, a fast forward button is a bandaid solution to the greater problem that battles take very little strategy and the whole gameplay rythm relies on a lot of menial drudgery.  

Side quests are lazy too.  Most of the missions in the game are shoved into a quest board with scant flavor text that is only really worth reading for the location and enemy information that it might (emphasis *might*, the times when it doesn't give you useful information are always on the rarest, most difficult-to-find items) provide.  

Dungeon design is also...you get it by now.  Mostly corridors, with minimal interactibles except for the odd enemy or treasure...floating cube thing that very thoroughly fails to blend in with ANY scenery you happen to find it in.  Locales you visit have no real significance.  Go here for that MacGuffin, then go here for the next one, etc etc.  You could have flipped the order of most of the dungeons in the game and it wouldn't have really changed anything.

The plot is weak for a few reasons: the world, the characters, and the pacing.  First, the world is very shallow.  You have one hub town, and it's just a bunch of menus (Neptunia players will not be surprised by this).  There are NPC talk events that come up regularly, but most of them are either useless random comments about really nothing, like a drunk passing by or something, or vaguely silly scenes where an NPC does something weird and your character reacts to it.  World building is pretty much non-existant, except to further drive home the heavy-handed and simplistic world the main plot already sets up.  Main plot establishes really quickly: evil corporation appears good, but is really doing bad stuff!  Side NPCs occasionally: we love the evil corporation so much because they throw money at us, etc.  
Second, the characters.  The characters for the most part sit very comfortably in shallow archetypes that they don't venture out of very often.  Even with fairly frequent talk topics after major plot developments, you never really see how the group becomes the True Companions that are willing to die for the main character despite his less than stellar charisma and lazy attitude for most of the game.  It doesn't help that the game resets about half way through, resetting character development for everyone except the main character in the process, and further shortening the character arcs (if you can even call them that) of the party members.  
Third is the game's issue with pacing.  The fact that the timeline resets mid-game reeks as an excuse to reuse the already minimal-effort dungeons.  Indeed, after that mid-game reset, the game introduces about a handful of new dungeons, that might as well be reskins of the existing ones anyway.  This move also resets character development for most of the cast, turning the focus on the main character as he tries to convince them he isn't crazy and really IS from an alternate timeline.  If their motivations for joining the party weren't ALREADY flimsy (pervy researcher girl wants to come along so she can perv on your party's female fairies), they become seriously flimsy after the reset (hey, this crazy guy claims he's from the future, might as well tag along and perv on his fairies while I watch this play out).

Positives and Negatives Breakdown:
+Great port: Borderless windowed option, runs smooth even at high resolutions and at max detail.  No crashes, no save issues, works competently on keyboard+mouse, but best on a controller.  
+Fun, if mindless dungeon crawling: the gameplay is fine.  The story can't really stand on its own, and there's little narrative or lore motivation to doing sidequests, but if you enjoy the gameplay, it's an alright treadmill to get on for a few hours.
+Good art--CGs in story events and character side-events are well done, frequently putting characters in pervy situations if that's your thing.
+/- Music--there are a few standout tracks, but it's mostly very bland and forgettable.  
-Weak story
--Weak pacing
-Weak Characters
-Weak world-building
-Recycled dungeons out the wazoo

19731240.review:
Fairy Fencer F is a turn-based action RPG with a combat system that's very similar to games like Grandia 2, Resonance of Fate and Eternal Sonata. And much like Resonance of Fate, it takes a very minimalist approach to it's game world (instead of towns to explore and NPCs to talk to, it's all menu-based).

Fairy Fencer F is one of those JRPGs that, despite having generic enemies, cheap dungeon designs as well as a somewhat generic plot (which revolves around getting magical swords to help revive a Goddess somehow...), elevates itself above the rest by having fun characters, witty banter and a flashy combat system.

With a story as generic as this one, character interaction between the main cast is what helps a game move along and FFF accomplishes that with a colorful cast of odd and goofy characters. Like Fang, our main hero, who is almost a bizarre parody of the average emo-fueled character. He's lazy, uninterested in the actual quest and will resort to any excuse to get out of dodge. Basically the half-hearted, reluctant hero who is the source of some of the game's best comedic bits.

Same with characters like Tiara, Galdo, Pippin and Harley who provide playfull banter and are themselves fully fleshed out characters despite fitting into stereotypes (the character who is a massive eater, miss wardrobe malfunction, the seeimgly perfect ladies man and weird character with a sword shoved into the top of it's head).

The combat system and the clever way in which you plunge swords into the dungeons themselves to boost stats such as aquire more money, experience and items make it fun as well as grind-level friendly.

19724763.review:
*NOTE IN HERE FOR ANYONE FACING A CRASH WITH A 'VideoCard.cpp (279) : DXFAIL : E_FAIL' WARNING*
Before I say anything, let me say that there is a simple way to fix the above issue. I have Windows 7 and every time I ran the game, shortly after I start playing, I received a warning that said "VideoCard.cpp (279) : DXFAIL : E_FAIL" and the game would automatically close. After looking at the forums, I found that by going to the local files and changing the game file compatiblity to 'Windows XP Service Pack 3' that issue disappeared immediately! To even prove it to myself I played it for an hour just now and it never appeared!
As for the game, I DEFINITELY recommend it to ANYONE who loves a good anime sword fighting game! The graphics are AMAZING! The story is EPIC! The characters are BAD@$$! 19544762.review:
Fairy Fencer f was beautiful. This is going to be a long review, so if you don't like reading, then the first sentence sums it up.

I've played many RPG and JRPG games through my life, and most of them were pretty spectacular. Golden Sun, Persona 3 and 4, Pokemon (if that counts), Chrono Trigger, Fire Emblem: Awakening, and Skyrim, to name a few. So I'd like so think that I've seen all the odd's and ends of what RPG/JRPG games should feel like. 

Fairy Fencer f had every good thing RPG's have to offer. The story, the art, the music, the characters, the combat system, the customization, the grind (maybe not good to some people), and most importantly for me, a DYNAMIC main character. I'll be going into details, trying to avoid spoilers since I always hover over them anyways.

[b]Story:[/b]
FF's story seems basic at first. Two deity's, the benevolent Goddess and the vile Vile God, each fighting to take over the world. They both get sealed away, and the world is left alone all normal. Your quest is to collect Furies (sealed fairies) in order to revive the Goddess and get your wish granted. Seems prety run-of-the-mill, right? But then you meet your two protagonists, the unlikeable Fang and the sarcastic Eryn, and you quickly get pulled in by Compile Heart's signature comedic dialogue. And in classic JRPG form, a TON of twists happen throughout the game that make you upset, confused or heartbroken. They come fast and strike hard, leaving you devastated or driven enough to keep playing; to solve whatever just happened. The story is far from basic. It's a wonderful tale of treachery, love, heroism, justice and cookies. Oh and Pippin I guess...

[b]Art & Music:[/b]
Everything in this game was gorgeous. The landscapes, the cutscences, the characters, even the menu's were well designed and easy to use. The music gave emotions to the dungeons and aligned with events in the story; mystery, excitement, regret etc. I will say that you'll be sick of hearing the word "Metamorphosize" halfway through the game, since it's the first word of the theme song that plays when you Fairize.
I figure I should also mention Voice Acting since that was pretty great too. I used the English voices because I knew Christine Marie Cabanos was in the cast. There was plenty of emotion, and none of the voices were painful to listen to like Compa from HD (Except Pippin)

[b]The Character's:[/b] 
I'm as much of a fan of your "Tsundere" or  "Onee-Chan" trope characters as the next guy. Heck, I played through Hyperdimension and found it enjoyable. For those of you who don't know, basically a trope is a stereotype, for example the "Rich girl with the annoying laugh". But there were only three characters I can think of that fit into a solid trope: Soji, Apollonius and (maybe) Zenke. 
All the characters were so completely diverse, and their chemistry was amazing. You had the "Tsundo-masochist", "Jarl Ulfric the Baker", "Kill, Kill, Kill", and the "Japanadian". All the characters had interesting backstories, and you really felt like you were growing with them on their journey. Just not Pippin though.

[b]Combat/Customization/Grinding:[/b]
The game consists of an Overworld, a single Town, Goddess Revival and Dungeons (Shukesoo's Tower included). Similar to most RPG's, the dungeons are filled with non-random enemy encounters that trigger a battle sequence. You can gain the advantage outside of battle by hitting the enemy first (akin to Paper Mario). 
The combat system is almost identical to Hyperdimension; turn-based strategy. You can customize your team in many, many ways. You can change combos, armor, Fairies, stats, formation, members, partners, accessories and even fighting styles (Turning a brawler into a gunner, for example). The only thing I was disappointed with in terms of customizations is that [b] there are only two costumes per character [/b]. Everyone gets a default costume and a bath towel/bathing suit (DLC, by the way), with the exception of Ethel, who has three.
I love grinding in RPG's. Shoot me, I'm weird. But this game was special in that it was actually fun to grind. You can upgrade each character individually using points earned from battle. Tiara can either be an all-out magic user or a Glavie wielder, or a swordsman, or an archer etc. It's very fun to play around with different strategies. I never used Pippin though, so I can't give analysis on that...

[b]Fang:[/b] 
Fang get's his own section because I hated him at the beginning. If you've ever watched a Romance/ Slice of Life anime before, you've met Fang; Lazy, undecided and unworthy of the ladies he's surrounded by. But oh my word. That is all I'll say. Let him annoy you, allow him to get at you and then you will feel all the emotion I felt through this game. Amazeballs.

In conclusion!
Story: 9/10 - Draws you in. Makes you think, work and FEEL. I got the ending I didn't want, so maybe I'll edit this later.

Gameplay: 10/10 - I love the mechanics. Dungeons, shopping for armor, grinding. The whole RPG shindig.

Character's: 10/10 - Individualistic, lovable, and well defined. But Pippin...

Music: 9/10 - Electronic? Orchestra? J-pop? Rock? Yup, and it's all great. But one over repetitive song robs this of a 10.

Replay Value: 10/10 - Hard Achievements, three endings I'm dying to see, and ridiculous character customization.

Overall: 9.5/10
This game truly deserves to be among the great RPG games out there. Where Hyperdimension is niche and weird, Fairy Fencer f is a beautifully crafted masterpiece of a game that I would kill to play again for the first time. I highly recommend this game if you are a casual, hardcore or die-hard fan of RPG, JRPG or Anime games.

19402959.review:
Habe mir das Spiel im Sale geholt, und ich muss sagen es macht es gefällt mir.

Was aber einige Reviewer hier verfassen, dass es wäre so als würde man einen Anime schauen, DAS erschließt sich mir überhaupt nicht, da die Geschichte wie in einem Visual Novel erzählt wird und die kämpfe völlig seperat dazu in einer 3D - Umgebung stattfinden.


Nun kommen wir zum Review:

[b] Positive Punkte	[/b]

+ die Charakter sind sehr schön gezeichnet

+ die Vertonung ist super gelungen

+ die Geschichte wird lustig erzählt, sodass man immer wissen möchte wie es nun endlich weitergeht

+ die Kampfmusik nachdem man "Fairize"ausgeführt, hat mich immer wieder zum grinsen gebracht :) 



[b] negative Punkte	[/b]

- es gibt keine Animationen die Interaktionen zwischen den Charakteren während der Dialoge veranschaulichen

- angenommen Quests aus der Taverne wurden meiner Meinung nicht ausfürlich genug Beschrieben, sodass ich nicht ohne hilfe des Internetz keine Chance hatte weiterzukommen

- der Shwierigkeitsgrad ist zu niedrig angesetzt, ich hab das Spiel ohne Schwierigkeiten durchgespielt. Bei mir sind insgesamt nur 2 Charaktere je ein mal gestorben. Ganz zu schweigen von irgendeiner Taktik die ich bei kämpfen anwenden musste.


[b]Fazit	[/b]

Mich hat selten ein Spiel Aufgrund seiner Story und der guten Vertonung so lange gefesselt, ich habe mich immer wieder gefreut wenn es eine neue "Unterhaltung/Zwischensequenz". Allerdings ist wie schon Aufgeführt der Schwierigkeitsgrad viel zu niedrig sodass man in den Kämpfen einfach eine Haudrauf-Taktik anwendet die meist kurz durch Heilzauber/-items unterbrochen wird. Wer auf Animes / Mangas steht kann hier getrost zugreifen, allerdings auch nur wenn man den Erzählstil von Visual Novels mag.

Noch ein paar abschließende Worte zum Kampfsystem, diese gelten allerdings nur denen, die b]keinerlei[/b] Erfahrung mit J-RPGs haben.
Die kämpfe werden hier sehr schnell repetetiv, da man sich hier (dank des zu niedrigen Schwierigkeitgrades) auf ein paar Aktionen beschränkt und diese dann mit sehr geringen Abweichungen wiederholt.

19373555.review: Bought it on sale for about $10, mostly because IF and Compa were responsible for it. I played the Hyperdimension Neptunia games and loved them, and this looked similar. In terms of the bare basics, it's kind've similar, you have your overworld map, go to dungeons to beat baddies and get loot, go to town to talk to people, and buy stuff. I'm only an hour in, and it seems much more complex than Hyperdimension. First is the weapon boost system, which allows you to allocate "Weapon Points", gained through battle, to increase your combo, learn new skills, and upgrade stats. You also get "Fairies", which you can equip and level up for cool benefits that start off with little benefits such as "Ice Support +3", but they also seem to be able to give you additional skills. Your weapon also apparently changes when you equip different kinds of combos, at least that's what the game tells me. The Main Characters (Fang and Eryn) are hilarious, Fang manages to pull off being a total Jerk, while being funny at the same time, which is good, otherwise he'd be unlikable. If you like Hyperdimension Neptunia, you'll like this. If you haven't played Hyperdimension, I'd say play this if you enjoy RPGs that will suck away all your time, and then play Hyperdimension, because this is a tad more serious (and by a tad, I mean a LOT) than Hyperdimension, which throws you head first into anime and video game references, this at least so far has kept it light on the video game trope references.

19332242.review:
相当正统的日式RPG，RPG该有的系统基本上都有了，没有惊喜，但也不会失望。
1、画风。画风十分不错，人设由人气日本插画家Tsunako担任，在游戏角色立绘身上基本上都可以找到一些近期热门动漫角色的影子。厂商捏3D人物的水平尚可，违和感不强，在这方面比FALCOM的闪轨要好多了。
2、系统。系统分为日常、迷宫及战斗三部分。（1）日常以TRPG触发QUEST的形式呈现，简单直接，剧情QUEST基本上都用2D角色立绘呈现，最大限度避免了3D角色表情木讷死板的弊端，也可以充分发挥画师的实力，这点相当不错。（2）迷宫基本上和闪轨的没什么区别，都是3D地图探索，接触敌人、物品等触发QUEST。（3）战斗的系统设定也是和闪轨相同，SKILLS、魔法等该有的都有了，只是操作细节有小变化。
3、音乐。音乐比较一般，但也不过不失。
4、语音。STEAM上买到的是英语配音及英语语言的，单词不难，有个6级水平应该就足以流畅游玩这款游戏。英语配音水准也很高，基本上没有违和感。对于本人这种海外党来说，这是重要的加分项。
5、剧情。由于没通关，所以也不好多写，但好像有多结局。
6、操作。建议用手柄游玩，这作品的键鼠操作十分不合理，感觉就是把手柄操作强硬搬到键鼠中去。这一项对游戏体验十分不利。但考虑到这是从家用机上移植过来的，也是可以理解。
嘛，总体上不过不失，对于没有家用机的玩家来说还是值得一玩的。

Bom, um game que comprei na curiosidade após ver o GP e digo que valeu todo o dinheiro gasto (comprei na promo por R$16.79).

A arte do game é linda, o som é bem caprichado e a jogabilidade é muito intuitiva (para quem ja esta acostumado com os J-RPG).
As animações são demais!!!
O idioma é Ingles, mas nada tão dificil de se entender ja que as instruções tem imagens, o que torna mais facil para quem tem pouca familiaridade com o idioma.
Tem varias caracteristicas interessantes que ainda não tinha visto em outros games.
Há conquistas internas do games e as da Steam. As internas dão bonus ao personagem.
O sistema de batalha é tipo menu (FF, Grandia) sem tempo, cada um tem seu turno.
A possibilidade de salvar na nuvem é mais um atrativo sendo possivel jogar em qualquer lugar.
O game não é tão pesado e rodou suave (no full) na minha maquina AMD FX-4300, Radeon HD6670 e 6gb de Ram 1333.

Enfim, pode comprar que eu recomendo! 

9/10 (daria nota 10 se tivesse legendas em PT).

19219311.review:
Fairy Fencer F foi um lançamento da Compile Heart (produtora relativamente conhecida no Japão), e contava com uma equipe de peso: Yoshitaka Amano na arte conceitual, Nobuo Uematsu como co-compositor, Tsunako como character designer, Toshiki Inoue como roteirista e o time de Hyperdimension Neptunia (outra prata da casa) como parte do time de desenvolvimento.

Infelizmente, o game foi lançado em 2013 apenas para o PS3. Felizmente ele ganhou uma versão para PC, e por um preço bem atrativo na Steam. Mas e aí, vale a pena?

Fairy Fencer F está longe de ser um jogo “do Oscar”. Na verdade, ele se enquadra muito mais na categoria “prazer culpado”, com seus clichês, história e missões manjadíssimas. Mas quem se importa? Ele é um jRPG divertidíssimo, dinâmico e cheio de coisa para fazer!

Em tempo: uma continuação já foi anunciada na Tokyo Game Show deste ano, trata-se Fairy Fencer F: Advent Dark Force. Inicialmente exclusivo para o PS4, o game deverá sair ainda este ano no Japão, mas sem data para chegar na MURIKA. Comprarei com certeza!

Confira meu review completo aqui:

http://www.coconacuia.com.br/2015/09/fairy-fencer-f-review/

Very good game 8/10

18933624.review:
Great game with really nice story and interesting battle system VERY similar to Hyper Dimension Neptunia. Personally I’d say that this game is an upgrade from Neptunia (the first one at least), since the story features a much nicer progression that starts off slice of life like and turns into one that actually takes itself seriously by the end whilst still maintaining its sense of humor. My only complaint is that the game tends to be fairly easy with no difficulty settings whatsoever, especially in NG+ where you will probably OHKO or 1 combo to death everything and only presents some challenge in the extra dungeon. Hopefully this will be fixed in its continuation/reboot Fairy Fencer Advent Dark Force. 
Also I strongly recommend to avoid reading the contents of costume DLC if you are planning on buying it since it will spoil you about your party members and it IS a big deal since it HAS been a while since I last played a JRPG that maintained some mystery about your final party formation, at least comparing to some like Tales of series which spoil you straight from the game cover and Final Fantasy alike. Comparing to those I got really excited about things being a little more unpredicted.
Solid game with surprisingly good and involving story, nice Neptunia like battle system, suffering only to easy main story battles. Definitely a must buy for all Neptunia lovers and also for those who are looking for JRPGs on steam. Even if you don’t enjoy Neptunia and niche games, but love RPGs with nice story and multiple endings give this one a shot and it might just be worth your while! AVOID DLC AND PARTY SPOILERS IF YOU CAN!
FINAL SCORE: 8/10

18888376.review:
To sum up this game in a single sentence: Fairy Fencer F (FFF) is a Compile Heart RPG.

For anyone who has played Hyperdimension Neptunia (HDN) you'll know exactly what that means, and if you enjoyed those games then you will enjoy this one just as much. For those who don't like HDN there isn't anything here that will change your mind about the Compile Heart's style. The gameplay is the same, the characters are all full of tropes, the dialogue is hilarious for all the right/wrong reasons, and there's a whole lot of disjointed visual novel style scenes to go through.

Now for those who have never tried a Compile Heart game before to sum up the gameplay briefly: There's an overwold map with minor interaction where you point at the next dungeon, all dungeons are fairly short and samey, the combat system has some pretty good depth to it but due to how easy their games are any depth becomes meaningless, and most importantly you can spam jump while in dungeons.

Now speaking specifically about this game the gameplay, as mentioned above, has a serious problem in the difficulty department. There will never be a point you'll find yourself grinding for levels because the game doesn't start punishing you harshly until the enemies are basically 1.2-1.7 times your level. A cool new feature this game has is also the ability to distribute the stats into the character the way you want, AND while you perform actions with your characters they gain stats for the traits that relate (ex, jumping a bunch in the dungeon boosts agility, using magic a lot boosts SP, collecting items a lot boosts luck) unfortunately there is almost no noticeable difference because everything is just so incidental. 

That may all seem negative, because it kind of is, but for some reason none of that matters once you start getting into the gameplay. The semi-strategy RPG style layout with aoe hit zones and movement zones mixed with the turn based combat is indescribably way more satisfying than it ever should be. It's hard to explain why and can only be experienced first hand.

Moving onto the story... well. It's a JRPG and Compile Heart really likes doing the classic (you're a hero now, you need to do x, and stop y from returning and save the planet) JRPG story, but they enjoy doing it with large parties of really enjoyable characters who are all quite hilarious. Also the main character in this game is quite possibly the most unlikable likable main character to come out this year. 

Overall: While FFF might not be as good a game as HDN was it is certainly a fantastic addition to the library of any fan of JRPGs.
