17774114.review:
"Yo dude. What's happening?"
"Um...Hi."
"I have a question for you. What does the 'B' in Susan B. Anthony stand for?"
"Uhhhh"
"BOOYAH!" I pull a silver dollar out of my shirt pocket and present it and my car keys to the confused valet.
"Take good care of it and I'll throw in another Susanna." I remark with a chuckle. My name's PepsimanVsJoe and apparently I'm supposed to write a review for Fairy Fencer F. The problem is-
"The problem is you just gave your keys away!" My partner cuts in. 
"Huh? That was the valet."
"Have you ever heard of a Taco Bell having valet parking?!" He looks at me like I'm an idiot. "God you're dumb. Yet somehow you can manage to put two words together. I mean for crying out loud you don't even play videogames. I don't even play videogames! I hate them!" He sighs, cracks his knuckles for an eternity, and continues. "Luckily for us, there are three people that enjoyed playing Fairy Fencer F, and they're interested in talking about it."
"Really? Wow. I'd love to hear from them."

"...They're right over here." He leads me to a booth near the back of the high-class restaurant.
A young man extends a hand, which I promptly shake. "Hi PepsimanVsJoe! My name is Piven. My favorite games include Halo, Call of Duty, and Gears of War." 
"And you like Fairy Fencer F? Really?"
"Yes...well okay yeah it sounds strange when you think about it. Fairy Fencer F is an anime RPG about fairies and crap, but I think it's a well-done game. It reminds me of...well...Taco Bell. It's comfort food, the kind you never really get tired of. Playing online multiplayer gets pretty stressful, so it's nice having something I can chill with. The protagonist, Fang, is an interesting guy. He talks about eating and sleeping a lot, but he also has a strong sense of justice."

"I stopped listening after you compared the game to Taco Bell." said a voice hiding behind a Playstation Vita. Ignoring my meager attempts at a handshake, he introduces himself: "The name is Joss. I play all of the RPGs. I'm an RPG sponge." 
"What would you say is Fairy Fencer F's most admirable quality?" I ask.
"Piven merely glossed over the storyline, which is actually pretty well done. It shows a surprising amount of ambition, even if it can be uneven at times. Thankfully the well-written characters make the far-fetched aspects of the plot easier to swallow. Also, unlike the Neptunia series, Compile Heart's bread & butter, this game isn't as light-hearted, which makes for a good change of pace."
"Yeah, The Neptunia games are pretty cool." Piven cuts in. "But you missed the reason why someone would prefer Fairy Fencer F."

"Oh really?" Joss frowns. Actually I'm just guessing he's frowning. It's hard to tell since he hasn't moved his face from behind that Vita.
"Playing FFF really highlights the pacing issues the Neptunia games can sometimes have. In those games you can spend a lot of time repeating certain dungeons, or going to multiple locations just to view more cut-scenes. Sometimes I just want to play the game, or at least get some new characters and have them stick around for more than a dungeon or two."
"...You have a point, FFF does seem a bit fresher, despite sharing many of the same qualities as the Neptunia series. However, FFF lacks the unique personality of the Gamindustri's culture and lore. That's not even considering the complete lack of amusing references and characters designed after your favorite games."
"My favorite games? Last I checked. Most of the NPCs in Neptunia are Merio, Looigi, and a bunch of other random nonsense from Japanese magazines that I've never heard of. They don't have anything to say, but I have to read every ridiculous comment that flies way over my head, just so I don't miss a plan or whatever else I need to 100% complete the game. At least Fairy Fencer F keeps everything focused. It tells a story I can relate to...at least as far as fairies transforming into weapons that are pulled out of the ground will allow." Before Joss can argue, he's cut off by -

"Name's Pam. I like 2D shooters, anything with a lot of action, and I'm weak for MMOs and Diablo-clones. You two fail to realize - or are completely ignoring -  the real problem with Fairy Fencer F: It's too easy! Sure, I can't go into these games expecting a level of depth comparable to hardcore dungeon-crawlers like Wizardry, but FFF is less challenging than the Neptunia games. At least those titles have the neat combo-systems, the three kinds of attacks, and so on. All I did in this game was mash buttons. The only fights I lost were when I was severely underleveled, and that was the DLC."
I cut in "You said you liked the game...didn't you?"
"Of course I did! Compile Heart doesn't create challenging RPGs, but they deserve all the love in the world for making it so effortless to get through battles quickly. I can watch the flashy special moves, then just skip through everything for the real content: the characters and story."
"I agree." Piven speaks up. "Compile Heart knows how to cater to its fans. They've captured an audience that ignores Visual Novels...by creating Visual Novels with RPG elements."
"Hate to say it, but I agree with dudebro." Joss admits. "What makes this game enjoyable is that it allows the player to enjoy as much - or as little - of an RPG they want. They can avoid grinding and focus on equipment as well as tactics, or simply focus on what matters to them. Overall, I think we all just wanted a relaxing game, that didn't demand a lot from us."

"Psh...Grinding." Pam grumbles. "The grind in this game is the worst. I think it's a law somewhere that Compile Heart has to include a couple ridiculous achievements that take forever. I think they do it just to sell DLC. Also this game has a plethora of minor cheevos. They're the kind where you get a little stat boost if you jump a thousand times or get the first strike in however many battles. It just seems like content for the sake of it, but at this point I'm just nitpicking."
"Hold up. Did I just admit to playing a Visual Novel?" Piven looks like he wants to lie down and cry. 
My partner, lulled to sleep by this incredibly fascinating dialogue, suddenly snaps awake. "Well. There you have it PepsimanVsJoe. That was Piven, Joss, and Pam with their thoughts on the game. I expect a full write-up by tomorrow morning."
"I have the concluding paragraph already in my head." I tell him as I wave goodbye to everyone else. "Thanks Mr. E"

Fairy Fencer F is a polished and enjoyable adventure. For those who don't make it a point to challenge themselves, this RPG won't offer much in the way of depth. However, you will be too busy being charmed by its characters, art, decent storyline, and superb music to notice. Though it's also fair to say that non-fans of Neptunia, probably won't appreciate what this game brings to the table. The more traditional Western Fantasy might also be too much to bear for gamers expecting hi-tech futuristic worlds influenced entirely by videogames (not to mention the discouraging lack of Nep-Nep). Still, as somebody who is frequently swamped by hardcore dungeon-crawlers, complex and difficult 2D shooters, and the frustrating & fruitless endeavor that is raising my k/d ratio; I will always welcome Compile Heart. 

Overcome with the satisfaction that my brilliance brings, I don't even notice the valet running into me with my car.

"Ugh.." My head is killing me. I slink out of my bed and nearly trip on a plastic cup. "The hell? Oh right...the weeknight special." I say to myself. Sometimes after work I'll grab a super mega-64 oz gulpathon from the nearest gas station. Whatever I drink from that cup is then replaced with rum, vodka, scotch, whatever is on hand really.  Needless to say, having one of these every night probably isn't the greatest life choice. Neither is writing reviews either but...well...Hopefully I didn't write something ridiculously pretentious last night.

17724965.review:
-SHORT SPOILER FREE REVIEW-

Before receiving this game from a friend, I was already aware that the developer of the game was the infamous 'compile heart', renowned for their 'waifu simulator neptunia' series. So going into Fairy Fencer F, I was expecting a game with a half-arsed story, terrible game mechanics and a million anime girls. Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the Male-to-Female character ratio is, rather than 100% female, closer to 1-1. There is almost an equal number. So the game delivers in providing a diversity of characters. tl;dr FFF character design > HDN

Fairy Fencer F is rich with dialogue, dialogue which comes in all forms. So far in fact, that as you collect 'furies' throughout the game and the corresponding fairies to each fury that are displayed in your inventory, each will have something to say on every topic in the game, it's endless fun to sit and browse through your fairies and learn each fairy's individual thoughts and point of view. The comedic value of the game is significant, I was provided with a significant portion of laughter. There are feels, and the soundtrack matches the artwork and tone of the game almost spot on.

A significant flaw in FFF is the difficulty level, this game is far too easy, it doesn't take a lot of skill to play, which is fine for the most part with JRPGs since they are mostly story-driven (You only have to look at final fantasy to see that). However, it wouldn't hurt to throw in an actual challenge once in a while.

All in all the game was pretty good, I grew attached to some of the characters, I was pleasantly surprised by FFF, I was going into this game expecting to be utterly disappointed by a subpar game, drenched in 'waifus'. HOWEVER, as was made clear in my review, this game was far from that.

Gameplay - 7.5/10
Character design / development - 8/10
Story - 8/10
Soundtrack - 9/10
Artwork - 9.5/10

Room for improvement, but a fantastic game!

17680806.review:
So first things first, if you like the gameplay of Neptunia Re;Birth 1 and 2, you're probably going to like it here, 'cause it's pretty much the same. I have no problem with that because frankly I adore this battle system. Rather than just picking an enemy (or several enemies) like a typical JRPG, you move around a limited area on your turn and pick enemies then, sometimes with a box or something for which enemies you're going to hit. It adds a little extra element to it, in my opinion. Unlike Neptunia, basic attacks use a selection rather than an aiming box, so you can only attack one enemy at a time.

Personally I quite liked the story aswell, and as expected from Compile Heart (or at least, coming from Neptunia) I especially liked the characters. Except the ones I wasn't meant to like. There are only very few characters I don't find myself caring about, and they were either generic NPCs or showed up for only a short time. I do like how each o the fairies you collect has their own personlity in the menu, though.

In terms of being a port, it seems to be rather good. It's not once ran slowly for me, and in fact the framerate appears to be an improvement from the 30 that the PS3 original apparently had. I've only found one minor glitch so no problems there either. I don't know how well Keyboard and Mouse control, but it seems to have keyboard icons for menus which is a step up from Neptunia also.

All in all, I liked it. Whether you're going to like it, well, that's up to your opinon, but if you can't find anything about it you mind then I say give it a shot.

17675189.review:
Another game from IF. I must say I was a little worried when I got sent back in time. I thought the game "Yeah, you got sent back in time and you gotta do everything over again so you get girl." And boy, was I wrong. I mean the general idea is still revive the Goddess but with the way the story was written, it seems like it's actually sub-plot. That said this is the story of a lazy boy named Fang who prefers slack off in bed or eating Bahus' cooking and he is roped into reviving the Goddess by circumstance (and lots of peer pressure). And that's basically the gist of it.

Onto gameplay. At first glance I thought this game would live up to the brutal difficulty of Re;Birth but it sadly didn't. However, I later realized that the game was designed to be played a certain way. And that is by stabbing furies various place in the world map and making use of what is called "world shaping". Let me give you the quick rundown. World shaping is an ability that fairies use when they are stabbed on the ground. They have a certain radius that are dictated by their level. Let's say that a fairy has a world shaping ability of -10% P.DEF and +10% M.ATK. This means that every creature in that dungeon (including you) have their physical defense decreased by 10% while all magical attacks are 10% stronger. There are various world shaping effects that help increase damage (taken and delivered), boost WP, experience, and even seal off skills which is accessable through Godly Revival provided you have the necessary fairies.

Overall, I really love the amount detail put in the making of this game. Both story and gameplay wise. All characters have these quirks that make them stand out and provide an entertaining experience. There are some sexual innuendos, as well. Only one actually. It's a case of take 'em or leave 'em.

I don't like saying that "If you like anime, you will like this game." I don't like being that person. it's simply unintelligent. You may like anime but you may outright hate turn-based games. But if you do, it will add to your experience.

17670521.review:
This was the best game I played this year, hands down. Unlike the NepNep games, I actually hadn't played FFF when it originally came out. So, where to start...

For starters - if you like anime - this is probably more up your alley than NepNep. It has a much more serious tone yet still retains that sense of humor. It reads well. The plot is (mostly) solid. All-in-all, it was enjoyable.

I like all the characters. Fang shows character development. Something which is largely absent from NepNep. Tiara and Eyrn do as well. Actually, all of them show character development. I guess that's part of what I liked too. Fang goes from a lazy bum who just wants to eat shit to a guy who gets shit done. As far as characters go - my favorite list goes something like Ethel, Eyrn, Tiara, Fang, Harley, Pippin...

This game leaves quite a bit unanswered. If you're an inquisitive sort, this game will wreck you. I find myself wanting to know some details which just weren't explained. Which is to say, most things don't leave me wanting answers. I'm hoping the sequel sheds some light on these.

There are some negatives. No game is perfect, of course.

Some battles felt forced and lacked sense. I'm largely referring to the forced losses, which I feel it would be better if they just did story segments for some of them. With FFF, half the time I destroyed my MP meter only to get obliterated next phase when I actually *can* win the fight and it isn't a forced loss. It's too hard to tell the impossible battles from non-impossible. For example, [spoiler]before the final battle, the Marianne fight. During forced loss, she has three dots. You get her down to one, and then it RESTARTS, and she has six dots on her meter and it's Fang only. Seriously. Kinda unfair.[/spoiler]

TL;DR - Best thing I played this year, but does have some flaws. Oh, and Ethel is the best. Also, [spoiler]Pippin = Excalibur[/spoiler]

Note - I'm a Linux user, and I maintain the AppDB page for FFF on WineHQ. This game doesn't work perfectly on Wine at the moment. If you have a Windows computer, just do yourself a favor and buy it. It'll work well on Wine sooner than later, and you shouldn't skip this.

17661909.review:
I don't do many of these, and I don't really intend to do many more, mostly because I usually don't care enough for the games to do a review about them. 
As you can see, i still haven't played this game for that long but I think i can already write something about it.
This is a fun game. It's not amazing, it's not the best thing ever, it's simply what a game should be, fun and entretaining. It doesn't try to go beyond and break any new barriers, but it also isn't lazy or badly done.

The story is not really that special, but it keeps you engaged enough to keep on wanting to know what's going to happen. Not going to give any details because that would take forever.


The characters are stereotypes that anyone is used to see in any anime. Though the main character is by far the most entretaining character because he really does not seem to care for the main quest, not even for the other characters... to a certain extent. But his interaction with Eryn, and the rest of the group do make them more interesting then what they are in their roots.


The gameplay is redundant. It's always the same thing over and over again. Usualy this is a problem, except for the fact that the gameplay is rather fun, so it doesn't really matter. The special attacks feature some nice animations and the transformations get you really pumped expecially when you are fighting a boss.

The music complements the game nicely and the world in itself is rather charming.

Overall this is a really nice game that will make you want to play it for hours and hours. There is alot of stuff to do like side quests and other fairies to find, skills to upgrade, etc, so you will always have something to do.

If i had to rate, i would give it an 8/10.

17660601.review:
Step in the shoes of Fang, a lazy young man who, through the miracle workings of destiny, becomes a fencer, charged with gathering furies and removing the seals of the Goddess, who has been at war with the Vile God for centuries, both of which are now sealed away in another world. 

Fairy Fencer F is a typical JRPG, that means there’s quite a bit of talk, and a bit of grind. It’s also a console port, and as such, it has some peculiarities. 

Fairy Fencer F is basically a turn-based RPG with beautiful anime-styled art. When you’re not dungeon-crawling, you have a view of static maps and Visual Novel styled conversations with other characters. When you are dungeon crawling you get those same anime characters in 3D view. You only see the party leader until you enter a battle, and you can only choose so many of your friends to battle with you. 
Battles are turn based, but not static. You can move freely around a predesigned circular area of reach (and sometimes enemies will be outside this area), which gives you a sense of freedom despite the limitation, something move-by-places or only-x-steps type of turn based games don’t give you. 

The sound and voices are very nice and very fitting to the whole anime/fantasy theme, and I’m particularly fond of the song used when you use “fairize”; it reminds me lots of the songs in Persona 3 and 4. By the way, did I mention you can choose between English and Japanese voices? Because you totally can. It had my heart right then and there.

Now, I’ll try to explain this as best I can. Basically you play as Fang, a Fencer, that is: a person who can wield Furies, which are weapons that contain fairies that add powers to the weapon/wielder. Your job is to go out and search for more furies - each one you get will grant you a new fairy. You can add these to your own weapon as “resonance” to make it stronger and give you some extra stats. The fairies you’re currently using gain experience along with you and level up. Fairies are also ranked - the rank is used to remove the seals (swords) on the Goddess/God. While the story tells you to remove the Goddesses’ seals, after the tutorial you can choose to remove the Vile God’s seals as well, which is a neat touch! Each seal removed successfully adds different boosts/stats to the fairy used to remove it, which in turn adds it to you if it’s the one you’re using as resonance. Fairies that aren’t currently being used in your weapons can be stabbed as their fury forms on the world map in order to provide various boosts, buffs and debuffs in the nearby dungeons (for instance, earn more exp, or gold, or drop rate… ). Since you can stab more than one fury into the ground, you can get quite a few boosts while on a single dungeon. 

You have combos for physical attacks which you can customize, and you can at a fly switch between three different ones while attacking by simply pressing one key instead of another, all comfortably close by. Because you have so many ways to affect stats and boosts, the system ends up being quite flexible and enjoyable to play with.
It’s a very interesting concept and I feel like I don’t do it justice explaining it thus briefly. 

Saving is done through specific spots while inside a dungeon, or at any time within the world/city maps. While in the city you get to speak with a lot of characters and take up quests that can give you some prizes and can also be repeated (indefinitely, as it seems). The quests are fairly typical, but quick to get done, and go along with what rank you are. You can also craft some items to help on your journey. There is some romance in this game.

Because this was a console port, the controls at first can be a bit awkward (for instance, you can’t use esc to exit menus, you must use backspace; you can use the mouse too, but it’s really more of a hassle than using only the keyboard); however, once I grew used to them they were actually very sensibly placed and quite comfortable to use. I ended up using just the keyboard all the time. 

I do wish the game was free-roaming rather than turn based, and the fights do get a tad repetitive after a while, making the fighting aspect of the game feel a tad like a grind. However, the story is nice and full of funny moments and the characters are cute and extremely likeable, all of them with their own personalities, doubts and insecurities.

The game really makes you want to collect all the fairies and remove the seals to see what will happen, keeping you hooked with the story. It also offers a New Game Plus + mode upon completion, which I always love but haven’t yet reached. Fairy Fencer F is a delightfully long game (with 30+ hours if you’re playing through just the main storyline, and over a 100 if you’re going for completion), but from what I’ve seen so far I’m confident in recommending this game to everyone who is into JRPGs.

17643696.review:
Чем-то игра похожа на Нептунию, однако во многом отличается - начиная от боёвки и заканчивая прокачкой персонажей, ибо прокачки в Непе не было как таковой.
Если сравнивать эти две игры, то получится что Нептуния это чисто комедия, а Фенсер трагикомедия, в которой комедия всё же занимает планку первенства, правда только в первой половине игры. После того как повстречал чёрта, который устраивал турниры на смерть между родственниками, кто победил - тот и свободен, сразу стало понятно, что мир и сюжет тут значительно суровее.

Сам сюжет несколько раз не давал себя предсказать. То есть всё шло как и думал, а потом опа, неожиданный поворот и сидишь хлопаешь глазами, мол как же так-то, всё не так должно было развиваться! Повествование линейное, но концовки 3 штуки. Понять где начинается разветвление не так уж и просто, так что придётся постараться. Ну или заглянуть в гайд.
Хотя пафоса в некоторых диалогах хоть отбавляй. Ну другого от ЖРПГ и не ждал, в общем-то.

Графоний, музыка, озвучка - годнота. Особенно музяка после трансформации в бою, прям задаёт тон. 
Прыжок, кстати, дан тут не просто так. Построение некоторых данжей такое, что иногда приходится играть в платформер.
Ещё ништяк затесался в виде внутриигровых ачивментов. Их реально много. Хоть достижения между персонажами не отличаются, но они не просто так, типа выполонил и молодец. За них дают не большую прибавку к статам. И за прыжки тоже поощряют!
Всяких примочек, в виде кастомизации персонажей хватает. Если забуриться в это дело, то под конец игры можно насобирать просто уйму декоративных одёжек и аксессуаров.

Персонажей не так много, но все они хорошо проработаны. Каждый кто вступит в команду рано или поздно расскажет: как он стал Фенсером, чем занимался, и какие цели преследует от всего этого. Причём, опять же, всех персонажей не удалось прочитать. Кое-кто очень сильно смог удивить и не один раз. Главное что не сделали гаремник - к ГГ не липнут все девахи из команды, и это радует.
Да и чего уж там, личностью обладают даже феи, которых собираешь по ходу сюжета. Забавно что все они озвучены, кроме ДЛСшных, и по поводу сложившейся ситуации имеют мнение.


Ну а от хорошего к плохому, пожалуй. Единственные серьёзные минусы - это сложность и длина игры.

Заострю внимание на сложности. Мобы отлично себя ведут: обходят за спины, меняют позицию так, чтоб жахнуть АоЕшным скиллом по всей команде, короче заставляют следить за полем боя. Однако! Мобам не хватает мощи. Сложности почти нет. Серьёзно, напряжно было всего несколько раз. Финальный босс скопытился крайне быстро.
Прокачивать основной состав пришлось только один раз, когда в команду подкинули бойца с 35 лвлом, при среднем уровне персонажей в 22~ лвла. Как-то не комфортно было, да и чувство посетило, что слишком быстро прохожу.
Сложность выбирать не дают, она одна. Не использовал ни одного ДЛС: ни феек, ни шмотки. Просто пёр по сюжету, в своём стиле, один раз отвлёкшись на квесты. В общем те, кто проходил Нептунию или Агарест без ДЛС ни каких сложностей не встретят - слишком слабые противники.

Ну и игруля крайне короткая, 25 часов, из которых 3-4 часа потрачено на чепуху, очень и очень мало. Конечно можно ещё проходить на другие концовки, но сложность ни кто поменять не даст. И это печально.

В целом игра хороша. Хардкора, конечно, не хватает. Но игра оставила приятные впечатление, как от сюжета, так и от игрового процесса. 
И под конец не спойлерный совет: в первую очередь персонажам не участвующим в битве прокачивайте умение Learning - в будущем сильно поможет, да и нервы сохранит.

17635239.review:
I'll start by reaffirming what others have said, if you enjoyed Neptunia then you will enjoy this game. I'm almost at the end so I may change some things upon completion but I'll just note how I feel so far.

Story: It's nothing to write home about, the plot twists and the like are really obvious. That being said, just like in Neptunia it is really the characters that make the story enjoyable. The humor is good, and unlike some Rebirth 2, it doesn't really use whole lot of memes. The character interactions are fun and Tsunako is responsible for their designs which is always great in my opinion.

Gameplay: Again, see Neptunia. There can be a lot of grind depending on what you're trying to do but if you just play through you should have no trouble. In fact, the only time I felt there was a difficulty spike was on certain side missions when attempting to get extra furies. You have your level ups, increasing the strength of each character but beyond that there is the Weapon Points system, which allows you to choose extra stat bonuses as well as customize progression through choices in combo moves, as well as extending both combos and weapon range. The fury system serves the duel purpose of prividing both character boosts through stat upgrades as well as allowing you to change each area in subtle but noticable ways. You could increase both the weapons points gained while at the same time doubling the damage BOTH you and your enemies put out. Depending on how you use them, you can speed up some of the grind in game.

Controls: I mainly played with an Xbox 360 controller. Despite this the controls were very repsonsive. I only add this because I recently went through the PS3 version of Neptunia Victory and found the controls to be somehat lagging in comparison. I breifly used KB+M to get a feel in that regard, and for the short time I used them if felt just as good.

Music: Enjoyable, like most jrpg's if you like em the music is usually good, and Compile Heart always does well in that regard. 

If you typically enjoy a lot of the jrpg's that have been coming out lately, you'll no doubt find this a charming and enjoyable game. I've still yet to beat it so I can't say much for replay value, but judging from what I've played it doesn't seem like there could be much, at least until more of the DLC is released. It's worth the time and for those still on the fence, if you catch it on sale like I did, it is more than worth the money. Between the characters, story, and gameplay, you'll find a very comfy rpg.

17613105.review:
After spending about 16 hours completing the game i have finally decided to make a review of this game. This at the moment is by far one of the best JRPGs/Singleplayer hybrids which has ever came out. The story is very good and detailed which also contains a lot of humour to make sure that the person playing it doesn't get too bored with the seriousness of it or just get fed up that the game is just filled with jokes ruining the feel of the game. The gameplay is also very good however the map design feels very repetetive which doesn't really ruin the game but it's just something they could of improved on. The combat is very good with the unique abilities everyone gets as well as the special element people are given, whether that be fire, earth, water etc. The DLC as well is very non important so it isn't one of those games which says that is compulsary that you should buy DLCs in order to proceed to the next part of the story.
All together i would rate this game a 9/10. It would be a 10/10 if the story was a bit longer and if when you complete the game it doesn't reset like it does in fallouts. Apart from that it is a very good game and i would reccomend it to anyone who is a fan of anime, rpg, bullshit (high level people = bullshit battles in a good way) and i guess people who just in general likes JPRGs.

17596241.review:
If:

* You loved Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1
* You bought Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2 immediately afterwards, and loved that one too
* You failed to sign up for the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 3 closed beta by mere minutes
* You watched the first few episodes of the anime to make up for it, but you can't go any further because of spoilers
* You watched the full longplay of the PS3 Hyperdimension Neptunia game (and you were glad that you didn't play that version)
* You still want more of the same, and you want it now
* You are okay with the fact that every single time you activate HD--- I mean, "fairize," whatever encounter music is playing is replaced by the same cheesy engrish song
* You are okay with the stares oblique stares about becoming THAT kind of person who plays THAT kind of games
* You are okay with your favourite Steam tags cementing forever to "RPG", "Anime", "JRPG" and "Cute" (but not with "Female Lead")
* You hated hunting for hidden items in the Neptunia games, especially Re;birth 2
* You are okay with a somewhat more clunky interface
* You are okay with giving up on all the strategy involving guard points and hurtboxes
* You are okay with giving up on the HDD Drive meter carrying over between battles, so there's not really a reason not to rush straight for the end of each level
* You are okay with having to unlock each tier of combo attacks with a hard-to-come-by resource (you need 1,000 "weapon points" to unlock the fourth normal attacks in a turn; the final boss is worth 6 WP).
* You were annoyed by the forced losses in Rebirth 1 and instead prefer being yanked out of a perfectly winnable fight only to be treated to a cutscene where your party immediately gives up
* You are okay with bosses announcing their final super-special ultra awesome attack... only to see they usually do two-digit damage.

...then congratulations: Fairy Fencer F is more of the same stuff you liked, and you can stand its most glaring issues. I did, however, appreciate seeing chirprers being replaced by actual short cutscenes: the more character interaction the merrier.

All in all I really didn't care too much for the changes in actual gameplay and the way plans work in this game is somehow even more infuriating than Hyp-Dim-Nep-Reb (you can't see plans if you don't have any ingredients for it).

Here's a weak "no" from me.

17574325.review:
A great game with nice gameplay mechanics, a great storyline buildup, a lot of moving moments, an amazing climax AAAAAND...

... the lamest endings in the history of the RPG genre.

Seriously, I wouldn't even bother trying to replay the lengthy sections you have to replay in order to get all of them unless you're in it for the achievements ([spoiler]there's a breakpoint in the story where you get to choose what ending you'll get through a single decision, so you can save before that point and choose your route[/spoiler]). All you'll get is a static background image for each ending, which will contain like five unique dialogue lines, completely unsatisfactory and bland compared to what the story was being so far. Get one and watch the other two on YouTube, there are plenty of non-commentary gameplays showing only the endings in Auto mode.

Despite my tremendous disappointment with the ending, the game is solid and worth replaying at least once, [spoiler]since NG+ isn't exactly the same as the first playthrough, there are a couple of surprises in there[/spoiler]. I recommend it, especially if you're a grinding maniac who wants to get to level 999 and collect every item, you'll get a lot of hours of entertainment for the price while rarely getting bored.

8/10

17571391.review:
Bon J-RPG, les personnages sont attachants et l'histoire est simple mais empreint d'humour. Le système de combat rappellera celui des autres jeux Compile Heart (Hyperdimension Neptunia) mais avec quelques particularités notament la présence de "fairies". On regrettera la facilité des combats et les donjons toujours aussi linéaires et répétitifs.

Points positifs:
-Personnages charismatiques, mes préférés étant Ethel, Tiara et Harley.
-Une histoire qui se laisse suivre avec beaucoup d'humour.
-Jeu plutot bien optimisé comparé aux Neptunia a leurs sorties.
-Gameplay interessant et simple a prendre en main, comme Hyperdimension Nep. 1 mais en mieux.
-La musique est bonne, certains morceaux sont excellents.
-Présence d'un NG+, grind de lvl pas trop chiant, 3 fins possibles.


Points négatifs:
-Certains bruitages notament lors des attaques sont pas terribles et manquent d'impacts. De plus j'ai l'impression qu'il manquait des sons lors des scènes de cinématiques avec le moteur du jeu.
-Le côté grind de certaines quêtes, loot aléatoire avec des emplacements aléatoires.
-Le launcher(arme) complétement pété comparé aux autres armes, sa tape fort et de nombreuses fois (20 fois pour le dernier combo débloquable ...) du coup la jauge de Fairize se remplit en un tour de combos et les autres armes sont inutiles.
-Changements des musiques de combats définitif a un moment du jeu, impossible de réentendre les anciennes :/
-Les challenges sont abusés, sa demandent trop de grind. Ils auraient du les mettre commun a tous les personnages car oui c'est individuel la plupart du temps !
-On retrouve les défauts des autres jeux de Compile Heart : donjons couloirs et répétitifs.
-Les combats sont limités a 3 personnages, 4 auraient été mieux !
-Le craft a été laissé de côté et ne sert qu'a certaines quêtes.
-Trois personnages qu'on débloque vers la fin du jeu :/. De plus le jeu est assez facile.

17564954.review:
Un Jrpg très agréable à jouer, voilà ce qu'est Fairy Fencer F :

L'histoire fait très Shonen, & c'est probablement voulu. C'est agréable à suivre, les personnages étant tous assez réussis (hormis Sherman & Pippin) : le seul bémol de ce coté là, c'est que les méchants sont sous exploité tout le long du jeux...

Les combats sont très réussis, & très classique (perso j'aime bien). C'est du tour par tour, sauf qu'on peut mouvoir son perso pendant le combat pour bien porté ces skills (qui ont une zone d'effet). En parlant de Skills, ils ont une mise en scéne très shonen/japanime, ce qui n'est pas pour me déplaire! (en gros, c'est la classe^^).

Une fois la jauge de Fairyse remplie, on peut faire une symbiose avec notre arme, ce qui augmente nos dégats considérablement & nous donne une apparence très classe (pour les 3/4 des personnages en tout cas lol).

La durée de vie ne dépasse pas les 20h. Pour ma part, je trouve ça suffisant & je ne me suis pas ennuyé une seule seconde!

La soundtrack est varié, il y a de belles pistes mais mes préférés restent les insert song pendant la symbiose en combat, ça claque bien (il y a 2 pistes pour ça, la 2ème arrive vers le milieu du jeux).

Bref, j'ai passé un très bon moment avec Fairy Fencer. De +, à sa sortie steam il était à -50% : à ce prix là, le rapport qualité/prix est bel est bien présent!

17564287.review:
Just finished this game recently, all i need to do now :

 GRINDING for 100 million GOLD that is .. Easy achievement, just need some hardwork.

Now let me review things up.

PROS :
1. Battles are very similiar to your typical Idea Factory game such as Neptunia, which is easy for me to understand.

2. The WP Systems are unique since you don't need to bother ur equipment such as changing it (Armor and acc''re exceptional). You get to choose how the character would be, like if you improve their P-ATK, they'll be hitting as hard as they could and vice versa with the other attributes.

3. Some of you might not know about this, but I found this interesting recently. If you change the voice from English to Japanese, you get to hear your fairy's voice act whenever u open the Fairies tab, since it didn't worked that way on English VA.

4. Stories are good. Each protagonist have their own problem and are pretty interesting to talk with.
Game itself is fun, since it pretty much have a fun dialogues.

CONS :
1. It's getting pretty easy on 2/3rd playthrough, since everything are much easier without handicap. (Handicap : Like add monster lvl to increased its HP, DMG, DEF, exp and gold or sth).

2. The DLCs (except the costumes) are ruining the fun of this game. Told you, this game is ALREADY easy as it is without DLC, so don't bother to buy the Ultimate Weapon pack and others, unless you don't want to waste your time for 50 hours ++ grinding for 100% Steam Achievements. (44hrs gameplay and 86% achievement)

3. Maps are pretty much the same, developer only change your spawn point, which is lame IMO, LMAO. But it was something to be expected since this is an IDEA FACTORY game (I've played many of IF's games on console)

My conclusion : 
8.5/10
If you like Anime style JRPG, with a rich story you should consider on buying this.
Don't buy this game if you don't care about the story, cause that's pretty much what makes the game INTERESTING in my opinion.

17548454.review:
If you're going to read this, then focus. Put a couple of minutes aside. Pay full attention to me, because this isn't just a review. I'm going to pour my heart into this because I feel that's what this game deserves. This isn't just something you can score. 

At first, this game's story is exactly like your standard anime, but it very quickly becomes something far greater. In my 32 hour campaign, there wasn't a single second in which I wasn't enjoying the absolute hell out of everything the game had to offer me. The adorable characters, the amazing story, the graphics of all of the spells...there wasn't a single second where I wasn't entertained. 

It got to the point where once I reached the end of the game, I wasn't crying just because of the way the story ended, but also because of the very [i]fact[/i] that the game is over now. Sure I knew I could do a new game plus, but something about finishing the game was just so heart wrenching. I can't even remember the last time I shed a tear, and I am a rather stoic man, so it symbolizes a lot that this amazingly emotional game managed to make me cry in different ways at the same time.

Somehow, the repetitive combat isn't a bad thing. The spell effects of each and every spell are entertaining and beautiful enough to keep you interested in seeing them forever. Getting experience and skill points is fun no matter what, to the point where even the slightly-mandatory grinding is even fun. That's saying so much.

Perhaps the most touching, is that it's a [i]fully[/i] realized PC port. A game built with a JRPG engine has full mouse and keyboard support. Sure it seems like it would be standard for PC ports to have such things, but seeing a lack of mouse control in recent PC ports like DMC: Special Edition, it's hard not to feel grateful that the developers worked so hard to make mouse and keyboard work everywhere in this game. The amount of love they must have for this game must rival mine. And it does not surprise me, because it's extremely easy to fall in love with this game. You will have to practice the keyboard controls a bit (it took me a little bit to find out that Page Up and Page Down helps you aim your spells in combat, and Page Up re-centers your camera when exploring dungeons) but it won't take long, and the game's turn-based nature is very conducive with this control scheme, ensuring you have as much time as you need to figure out how, and where, to aim your spells. Give it a while, and you won't notice any difference in speed from casting a spell at the right position using a keyboard or a controller.

And to top it all off; my girlfriend gifted me this game <3 and all of its dlc's. Even if it wasn't such an amazing game, it would be worth appreciating simply because she got it for me. But it turned out to be my personal game of the year. Deandra, I love you, and I can't thank you enough for giving me this art, and I can't thank Compile Heart and Idea Factory enough for creating it.

17542145.review:
I have recently completed this game so i can say this

Pro's --
-Good fast paced turn based battle system (Comparable to FFX's battle system)
-Fun memorable characters and interesting story
-Lengthy story line with multiple choices and sub missions
-In depth character customization with custom move sets / combos 
-Multiple characters and costumes 
-Great voice acting, consistent throughout the entirety of the game!
-Has a new game+ with multiple side quests!
-Controller + Keyboard and mouse friendly with re-mapable keys

Con's --
-Alot of 2D custscenes, not so many 3D Cutscenes (This may come down to preferance)
-It seems the abilites become useless late game as your combos rack up way more damage so you'll find yourself spamming the A button alot
-Recolored enemies, they seem to reuse alot of the enemy models in the game
-Repetitive battle cutscenes (watching the fairization animation 272 times per playthrough becomes a bit annoying)

All in all i rate this a 7.8/10 It's a solid RPG and has some great replay value

17541322.review:
For people who liked Hyper Dimension Neptunia, this is a must buy . To be fair, I've had my playthroughs of final fantasy and other rpgs, so to me, this turned to be more interactive and strategic than most . There's plenty I like about the game, but a few others I dislike. I'll start with what I like :D

Positive
- Funny, not too many games that introduce a humorous cast of characters actually make me smile and laugh. 
- Beautiful art style and anime, characters look and act how they were made
- Easy combat system, items, attack, combos and spells pretty generic but very satisfying to see those combo strings and multiple damage hits
- Basic but fair storyline, very generic and simplistic story to follow and understand

Negatives
- Rushed, many of the characters are thrown into your way and then into your party about 2 minutes after you meet them without even really understanding why or who the hell they are
- Repetative; its a very simple system: go to town, events, buy info, free swords, go into dungeon, grind/complete quests (repeat) the side quests and events are really the only thing besides the storyline you can do
- Very short dungeons (also a pro) The dungeons are usually consisted of less than 5 areas, you can complete the main quest in a matter of minutes
- Protagonist (also a pro) I may get anime people jumping on back for this lol: the protagonist made me laugh and he does grow and develop throughout the game, but its just a hero I cannot get behind and makes me strongly dislike him later in the story. The early part had me laughing, but later on had me facepalming, honestly I wished  Sherman was the main protagonist, thats my opinion though lol.
- Brief tutorials, while most people generically know what their doing; its a little bit of a slap in the face that Eryn's tutorials pop up for like 3 screens going ," yeah this is how you do this and this, good luck finding  these matierals yada yada. " The game doesn't tell you where you can get specific items or materials. 

I still play the game and I still haven't finished the main story, so I'm no expert whatsoever; however this is a very fun game to play and kill time. The art style, the graphics and the gameplay are very fun . I'd play this when you get a lot of time and feel for a simplistic set back style game.

17537235.review:
The combat mechanics have a bunch of aspects and styles you could work toward, but most of them aren’t needed or worth it: a bunch of underpowered magic you’ll never need, a bunch of fury power-ups you’ll never use, extra weapon styles you don’t need, quest leveling for money you don’t need, synthesizing crap equipment and armour upgrades you don’t need. So many extra things, but in reality, the normal weapon+combos+atk and a few mid-range special moves are everything you need.

I only leveled to mid-30s, but the last bosses were probably slightly too easy, so don’t level past there if you want to keep it challenging. If you complete the furies you’ll be way over-powered!

But I was glad I didn’t have to grind much. There are mechanisms to add abilities to gain exp out of party and more rapidly, so I didn’t find myself grinding for exp or gold. You’ll go to a new area and almost immediately gain 4 levels by the time you reach the boss just fighting the normal spawned monsters. I did have to grind a little for WP (power ups) in an area that gave more of it, but I ended up wasting it on character magic or moves that were more under-powered than what they already had..

Overall a fun and short JRPG. My only gripe would be the crap dialogue. It’s full of trite cursing that detracted from the overall story. It’s pretty hard to root for the protagonist when he’s calling women a b**** in every other scene—this is not an exaggeration. I don’t mind language, but it doesn’t even flow, like a child who just discovered a new /bad word/. Eventually I got the feeling the game developers are clueless how to write diaglogue—you can hire specific people to do that BTW. By Act II it’s much better, but it’s worth mentioning if you have children playing the game. The diaglogue exchanges would probably cause PTA moms to Fairize.

It can be funny at parts.

Way too many tutorials be poppin' up all the time.

Good voice acting.

Fast battles.

Seemed like every boss battle was interrupted halfway through, and the characters would be all out of breath, like "Oh my god, we're losing so bad, we can't possibly win this." Even though most of the time, the boss would have done little to no damage to my characters at that point.

That one chick has nice boobs.

I read somewhere that the music was great, but, really it's just... there. Not exceptionally good, or bad, or memorable.
All the dungeons I played were pretty bland, and you could just run right through 'em.

It's heavily visual novel, there were like... two scenes with actual moving characters doing stuff, but it's mostly just characters reacting to things we never see happening. If you just like boobs and anime, but you DO like watching stuff happen... You might not like it. I don't like it.

17523464.review:
I will keep this short because I don't want to spoil too much of the story and it should be pretty obvious what kind of game this is, otherwise look it up on YouTube.

The game is part visual novel, part walking around dungeons and battling and part doing side quests. The battle system is somewhat similar to the Hyperdimension Neptunia series, and there are lots and lots of skills and battle points and other elements that you can advance in to get stronger in the way you like. Depending on the play style, it might be necessary to grind a few times, but nothing to write home about.

I had so much fun with this title, it is unreal. I loved the art, I loved the characters and their dialogues. The battle system is fun, but it shouldn't be the only thing to care about. I was mostly interested in advancing the story and enjoying all the adventures and dialogues between the characters. They weren't always in agreement but as the story progresses you don't want to ever lose any of them, even those who may have tried to kill you before.

All in all, especially if you like JRPGs or Anime, I would recommend Fairy Fencer F from the bottom of my heart ♥

17511438.review:
Before people start giving me crap for the negative review, I would like to say that these are opinions based solely on my own experience with the game. [b][u]I don't hate this game[/u][/b], I'm just very disappointed in my experience with it. If anything, I want to like this game more than I actually do. With that said, onto the review.

TL;DR version: A pretty bland game with bland characters, a bland story and bland combat. It's not worth nearly 30€ for this. If you plan to get it, get it while it's at least 50% off.

I came into this game from Idea Factory's Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 and 2, expecting it to be a somewhat more serious but still a lighthearted JRPG. For the most part, I got that. However, as I dug deeper into the game, there were so many different things that got to me that didn't really make my experience any more enjoyable.

My first problem is with the characters. They're not all that interesting, good character development happens mostly for 3 characters only (out of a possible 14) and I found none of the characters to be anything special. For example, Fang is a selfish guy who just wants to live his life the way he wants but eventually has to mature up to be a hero-type, Tiara is a noble-like character who seems to have a fetish for being verbally degenerated (I'm not kidding, she seems to get these moments of euphoria every time she's called the b-word), Pippin is a walking talking cat pillow that's supposed to resemble something of a veteran noble or something... Then there's Harley... [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=498766987]I'll let you guess what she's all about with the help of this link[/url]. In short, none of the characters have anything that makes them especially interesting (other than a few small quirks), which makes them kind of bland in my eyes.

Without spoiling the game, the plot doesn't really hold water for me either. The objective is stated at the very start of the game: "Collect furies, revive the Goddess, you win". Pretty much towards the end of the game the objective stays the same, until some small changes happen here or there. The story itself isn't so bad that it's hateable, but when you're finished with the game you'll be left with several plot holes that you don't really get an answer to. In addition, not many moments really stuck with me as I progressed through the game. I guess the word that describes the plot is bland. In addition, there are some plot related things that left me with more questions than answers. Those would fall under spoilers, however, so I won't talk about them.

How about character levelling and combat? Well, coming from the HDN games, they're definitely different. The game uses a system called "Weapon Boost" to make your character better. Through combat you gain WP, which you will use to level up character stats as well as to learn skills, magic, abilities and new combo techniques. It's a rather simple system, but it might require the player to grind a bit to unlock some of the stuff he or she wants but overall, I like it. The combat still seems to come short of being interesting though. Comparing it to the HDN combat system, I feel it's easier to navigate menus and harder to make silly mistakes like cancelling your own turn because you accidentally pressed the cancel button twice when trying to leave the item menu. That's definitely improved, but at the same time the fighting itself is made slightly more boring than in the HDN games. Bosses and enemies no longer seem to heal themselves or their allies, which gives you less of a reason to prioritize different targets or strategize using more hard-hitting skills. Just gather enough adrenaline, put on your serious face, activate Fairize and whack the crap out of the boss and hope he doesn't deactivate your Fairize before you kill him. In the end, the experience left me with a rather bland taste in my mouth.

You might be noticing a pattern in my review. I keep using the word "bland" a lot, but that's about all I can say about this game. It's bland. Really bland. Coming in from HDN, I expected funny, quirky characters; I got boring, uninspired people I didn't much care for. I expected an enjoyable plot: I was left with more questions than answers. I expected a bland combat system to be remastered into something better; I got the same one with a few differences here and there. I want to like this game, but having experienced all of this just makes it very hard for me to call it a sufficiently enjoyable experience. Toward the end I just wanted the game to be over so I can move on to other games that I've wanted to play for a while now. Now that I've finished the game once already, I'll do just that. I'm definitely coming back to this later to play NewGame+ and hopefully get a different ending. And when that time comes, I hope I'll see the game in a new light and I might be able to rewrite this review and be more positive about the game itself.

But until that day, I'll stand by these words and say the game is, at the very least, not worth full price. If you have to get it, get it while it's on sale for at least 50%.

17505825.review:
I found this game to be interesting to say the least. Once one figures out how to skip around the majority of useless talking then it's not half bad. 
There are several key point which should be made however, key among them is the rather lacking travel system and places to explore. City navigation was reduced to a menu rather than walking around a city or town itself. The dungeons were repetative and by most game standards highly incomplete. I would even go as far as to say that the game itself is incomplete. There are many, many opportunities to miss things which one would think would be required to actually complete the game. This also doesn't even factor into account that your main goal is to pull all of the swords out of this goddess, of which you can't even achieve on the first play through. There is no real rpg aspect to the game as you do not have any real choices to make, you cannot influence the real out come of the game. The ending is set, though they did offer three different ones based on one conversation only (which means, you either talked to this person or that, not giving you a choice in any conversations is what this game is all about it seems). 
There are only two ways to make playing and fighting in this game slightly enjoyable and relaxing. The first is to cheat with some form of hex editor and modify your xp and skill points. The second is to spend hours upon hours of grinding. The story line is a B at best, maybe a C+, it's nothing short of what a middle school student could have written for a short story. 
The fighting system was passable, but left no room for diversity or customization of characters. The best thing about this game was the few tid bits of costume which you could place on different characters. 

For my rating I will give the following on a 1-5 scale, 1 being the worst:
Graphics 3
Game play ease 4
Rpg / options 1
Story line 2
Replayability 1
Diversity 2
Over all 2

If you want some thing quick and lacking thinking then this is right up your alley. It requires no brain power or creativity what so ever.

17499641.review:
Have you played the Neptunia remakes? This game is similar except instead of jokes on video games, the industry with silly fanservice, it's silly JRPG story spoof with puns on that and ...more fanservice. 

It's very very similar to Neptunia, characters you get have combos you develop over time and they can transform to gain abilities and perks. The game feels like it had a much, much fatter budget however. Supported by the fact they have some Squaresoft employees doing things like music and art. Animations seem better done, there's less stuff re-used (though I've already run into a enemy that was in Neptunia so, there's that to think about) more enemy variety, ally variety etc.

The convo's with the animated sprites are better done than Neptunia as well, they have different poses, more of them, more on screen happen and they're more lively. 

The game is more grounded than Neptunia however, it's less off the wall and ...more 'normal' but it's still insane. It has more depth to it in it's gameplay overall and larger dungeons ...they're still nothing wildly complex but they're serviceable. Characters are more customizable with how you develop them by way of fairies being linked to them and where you put points into their stats. 

Don't expect deep complex story telling here, it's light hearted, silly and ...well one of the screenshots has a wierd green bear character, so c'mon. (haven't gotten that far yet) What I do like is, everything moves fast, or is skippable, so you don't get stuck watching an overly complex move for the 5th time, just hit LT/L2 and you're onto the next thing. Even convos can be skipped so you don't have to sit through plot you may already have.

It's good, certainly a fun game so far in my opinion.

17498690.review:
This game is pretty disappointing in every way you can imagine.
Lackluster dungeons with the most simplified designs possible, it’s not even an issue of the graphics being dated, that’s understandable. The issue is that they drew up these maps in about 30 seconds and said “we’re good to go!”   By the way I just checked and this game came out originally in 2013! WTF! Xenoblade Chronicles came out in 2010 and for an inferior console and it looks about a billion times better than this!
-
Extremely simplified turn based combat, it’s all about keeping healthy and doing more damage, no crazy strategies here. If the game wants to give you a tougher boss they don’t actually come up with an interesting boss that will keep you guessing, instead they just do more damage and take less damage, quite simple and uninspiring. 
-
A story that on paper seems like they could have done something good with it but in reality there is no story here, just an intro, and a bunch of clichéd fan service crap and cookie cutter bad guys.
-
Oh, btw, there’s no walking into towns, digesting beautiful sceneries, exploring and adventuring, etc.  Oh no, this game was made in power point, it’s just slides of text after slides of text with anime girls in questionable outfits and when you think you are done and you can go out and explore the world, all there is for you is a menu and several options to choose from before going to your next lame dungeon, there’s not even a real world map. There is but you can’t walk around it and fight monsters in it, it’s just a screen where you move a cursor to pick which dungeon to go into.
-
There is one thing that does make this game playable (barely) and that is the dialogue. 99% of the dialogue in this game is excrement but that 1% can be hilarious in ways you haven’t laughed in a game for a long long time.

My recommendation is don’t buy this horrible excuse for a JRPG and buy The Legend of Heroes Trails in The Sky instead (it’s on steam and it’s an incredible, incredible game)
But if you must play it, do yourself a favor and buy the armor pack DLC that costs less than a dollar, that way you can breeze through bosses and finish this game as quickly as possible so you don’t keep hurting yourself.

OH, and a very important thing. If you are like me, married with family and happen to play your videogames at night when the wife sleeps, on the big screen TV with headphones, make sure she is very deeply asleep because my wife wakes up in the middle of the night and sees the tv and goes “oh, playing the witcher? Cool, have fun!” and goes back to sleep. 
It’s not cool when she wakes up and sees cartoon gigantic boob dangling around the screen.
Scratch that… 13 year old gigantic boobs and then looks at you with a “did I marry a serial killer rapist pederast Hitler?!?!?”


AVOID PAIN, AVOID THIS GAME.

17495294.review:
When I started to play with this game my first impression was along the lines of:
God These characters are annoying! 
The main character Fang acted like a lazy asshole who cares about nothing but food. The main heroine and the face of the game Tiara acted like a giant SOB. The other heroine and the partner of Fang Eryn always seemed to have a few bad words for him.
Though to be fair Eryn did have a reason to act the way she did. Just imagine you wait (for only God knows how much) for a lifetime partner to finally show up. And then when he finally arrives the only thing you get from him is verbal abuse, unwillingness and constant complaining about food. You wouldn’t be happy about it either would you?
And then I kept on playing and the magic happened. When the characters started to really interact with each other and solving the problems life gave to them they turned out to be really well thought out and lovable.
I would say the main strength of the game is it’s brilliant writing. The plot is the average the bad boys wants to resurrect the bad God the good boys wants to resurrect the good God but fortunately it’s written in an entertaining way. The characters are not only good but they keep on developing and they get rid of their initial annoying quirks. The story itself is not ground-breaking but has it’s nice touches and has a plot-twist around the middle I DID NOT SEE COMING!
For the actual gameplay:
If you played Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 or Re;Birth 2 then all I say it’s exactly the same.
You enter dungeons from the main map. Inside them you control your assigned leader in the map picking up treasures and avoiding or hitting enemies. The actual battle system is turn based so when you are hit by one of them a battle sequence is initiated where your party fights against the monsters. When the battle is won you get back to the dungeon.
Interesting take that you can’t change weapons since each character has to fight with the fairy he or she has a contract with. In exchange you have a weapon upgrade system where you can raise your characters stats, teach them new abilities and moves, skills and magic trough Weapon Point earned by battling. However thank to this system your usual equipment are close to useless and the mostly serve as fanservice. In the game you will gather fairies you cannot equip as weapons but they can grant buffs and add dungeon effects using a system called world shaping. With them you can make the game a little bit harder or easier depending on you.
I think the biggest flaw of this battle system is that you became overpowered very very quick. After that battles are a chore instead of a challenge and the game becomes rather boring. The other downside is the quest system which requires extreme levels of grinding.
There are 3 endings available but there is little difference between them. One for Tiara one for Eryn and a normal ending if you chose neither. Tiara’s ending takes priority so avoid scenes with her if you want Eryn’s. You should chose Eryn by the way.^^
The game offers a new game+ too. Many content is unavailable in your first playtrough raising the replay value of the game even harder. If you are interested in missable content then there is two playable characters who cannot be recruited unless certain conditions are met and a bunch of time limited sub-events.
All in all I recommend this game for everyone who loves jrpgs and doesn’t mind grinding.

17494798.review:
While this game suffers from a good amount of flaws (see below for details), it still manages to be an enjoyable experience.
I'll be speaking numbers and mechanics so you get to know exactly what to expect from this product, and whether it's for you or not.
If you've played other games from this developer (like the Neptunia series), you can expect lots of similar aspects.



[b][h1]The good points :[/h1][/b]
- Fairy Fencer F takes about 25 hours to complete, and about 60 hours to get all achievements (I'm nearly there, so it's an estimate). This is a decent amount of time for an RPG, and at this price point, it's quite reasonable.

- While the story is kind of a classic (hero must defeat an evil god), the narrative makes it enjoyable. A few plot twists here and there, with some of them being predictable, and some others not (which is the good part). The main protagonist doesn't have your typical "hero" personnality, which is refreshing. Interactions between characters are good enough, and you can get attached to some of them. This is a good sign, because if you can't feel anything for any character, that means the story and dialogues are bland and pretty much suck.

- Good graphics, and runs on a solid 60FPS at 1080p without problems. I honestly don't care about 30 or 60 FPS, but some do so I'll write it down just in case.

- Not a lot of grinding to do, except for achievements (the 100M gold is a bad joke, since you barely need money in this game at all).

- Combat mechanics are turn-based, and you can transform ("fairize") your characters during combat to give them extra power.  Classic, but always works.

- Good soundtrack and voice acting (Japanese, of course). With Japs, you know you can expect quality on these aspects, and this game is no exception.

- World shaping. Basically, you can use special, reusable items to give special effects to a dungeon you are about to enter (increased/decreased xp/damage, etc).



[b][h1]The flaws :[/h1][/b]

Now, I'm gonna spend a lot more time on this part, because some stuff definitely can't be overlooked, and needs to be explained properly.
> If you're a veteran RPG player like I am, there are other, more subtle aspects of an RPG that you have high expectations for.
> If you're a casual RPG player, and are not too picky, these flaws won't probably mean much to you.

- First and foremost, this game suffers from the "Mash the attack button and that's pretty much it" syndrome. I literally (and I'm not kidding) did the whole game without using AND learning a single combat ability or combo. I just pressed the attack button continuously, and used potions to heal myself from time to time. The only thing I did was pay a passive skill to increase my EXP and gold earned (mid-way through the game, because it costs a ton to learn), and everything else was put into basic stat increase (power, defense, etc).
• In this game, you can learn magic and cast spells, but enemies/bosses are not proving very challenging so it just feels like a waste of time. Magic that increases a stat (speed, power, defense, magic, etc) are only single-target based, and last so few turns that by the time you've cast a boost on all of your party, it'll soon be gone from your first target.
• If anything, making a "mage" is more about fun rather than a necessity. All characters, as you recruit them, come as versatile, and you end up prefering physical attacks because it makes things faster (going in menus is a pain after a while, no surprise there). Basic stat increase is also pretty much a joke, because it will make too little of a difference to your character anyway, except for special stats like the attack range and the number of combos.
• Weaknesses to elements like fire, ice, etc, have barely been exploited, just like status debuffs, so you end up not even bothering about them.
• Overall, the majority of the battle system & mechanics are completely useless.

- The game also suffers from the "Idea Factory loves reusing stuff" syndrome (Idea Factory is the developer, mind you). If you've played the Neptunia series, you know what I'm talking about. The game reuses a lof of textures for monsters and environments, and you'll definitely find stuff, albeit with some slightly different colors, looking very similar to other stuff you've already seen before. Halfway through the game, something happens and this flaw becomes extremely accentuated, which I didn't appreciate at all. More effort was needed.

- Some achievements are only there to annoy you. If you're not a completionist then it's all good, but putting a 100M Gold achievement when you barely need gold the whole game doesn't make any sense.

- Lack of character customization. Not a lot of armors, weapons have a fixed sprite most of the time, and there are too few armors that change your characters' visual appearance as well. The Neptunia series had a lot more visual variety, so I got a bit dissapointed here. Good amount of visual accessories, but many of them are reused between characters.

- A menu to customize your battle formation? The game is unfortunately not challenging enough (even for a newbie player) for it to have any usefulness.

- The game does have a new game+ feature, but it doesn't bring a lot of extra content, unfortunately. It's more about a few features to get all the achievements, or to see another possible ending route (3 possible), rather than anything else.



[b][h1]Closing words :[/h1][/b]

There are some stuff that I didn't mention, like the crafting or the collection of items called "Furies" which can be leveled up to give you special stats. I usually skip stuff that isn't important to the review (though it doesn't mean that these are bad).

Overall, I'd say :
- If you're a casual RPG player, and if you're looking at the story first and then the gameplay, then you'll definitely have a good time. The story is decent, the characters are likable, the dialogues are fun, and the battle mechanics are what you'd expect from a typical RPG.
- If you're a seasoned RPG player looking first and foremost for difficulty and challenge, then you're likely to be dissapointed. All the game mechanics pretty much act as a "wrapper" for the story.

From my personal standpoint, I buy Idea Factory games because I enjoy the colorful art, the nice looking anime-esque characters, the cool Japanese voice acting, and the story. I definitely do not buy them for their difficulty or game mechanics. If you know where your priorities are, you know where to set your expectations (especially with Idea Factory games).

[b]Verdict :[/b] "Yes, but."
Albeit a few flaws, Fairy Fencer F is a good RPG that will most likely leave a positive impression on you.
Oh, and it has nekomimis, I forgot to mention that. Very important.

Have a great day,

Zanameth

17490801.review:
While I appreciate that there's a drought of good jRPGs on PC, you have to understand - this game has EXTREMELY low production values. I haven't played the game to completion and I don't plan to. Maybe it gets better later, but I doubt it.

You know how most jRPGs feature towns that you can run around and talk to the denizens? Nope. None of that here. Here the town (the only town as far as I can tell after what I played) is basically a menu.

You know how most jRPGs feature either cutscenes or in-engine scenes for important events? Nope. None of that here. You just get VN-style talking heads.

You know how in most jRPGs dungeons feature gameplay other than random battles, such as solving puzzles and discovering interesting lore and useful items? Nope. Dungeons are extremely bland here. At least not as far as I got, which may not be a lot, but it's the point where most other games in the genre have opened up a bit.

You know how RPGs are defined y the characters you meet, and so most strive to have good ones? Nope. So far all the characters have been so incredibly onedimensional, it's almost criminal.

You know how the plot is *the* most important thing in an RPG? Noooope. No plot here. At least so far. Move along.

All in all, buy something else.

17467575.review:
In the end, it's a mediocre JRPG, but it's still pretty fun. I'd recommend picking it up at 50-75% off, as you'll have a good time.

The battle system is pretty fun, but it lacks strategy. Just buy lots of SP healing items, spam your most powerful attacks and you're good to go.
Don't forget to buy the new attacks on the "Weapons Boost" tab. Only realized you could do that in the second half of the game.

The story is enjoyable, with a cast of likable casts and fun interactions between them.
But the actual plot is kinda awful. It just keeps jumping between plot points and never develops any of them. Doesn't help that this game loves to introduce antagonists just to kill them right after.

The worst thing about this game is that, in the first half of the game, the main character and his fairy partner are going to travel back in time, and they have to do everything again. Familiars with the Neptunia games should known that those games loves to reuse dungeons over and over again, so this is kinda of a "clever" way to do it. I still hated it.

Really solid PC port; worked great on my machine, and it even has an option for borderless windowed mode, which is nice.

Right down to it.
Similarity: Neptunia series, same control methods, same combat style, slightly more costumization because of the furies.

-Overall Rating: 6/10
-Completed the story ~lvl 45 with all characters, took about 10 hours, even spent some time running every single zone both standarized and with "enemies changed" to see different monster types and Item drops.
-Story is average, I like the fact that the Main character is a bit obnoxius compared to other Jrpg's.
-slightly less nudity which is subjective, but I prefer less in general, so that's a plus for me.
-[spoiler]When the main character's sword changed appearence I was excited and hoped it would be a longer developing process and it wouldn't only happen, just once. but ...[/spoiler]
-Lack of interaction between the sub characters annoyed me slightly, combat wise. Avalance effect didn't cut it enough for me, I'd hoped for more in the style of Agarest Generations.


The World shaping is a bit dull and slow, especially because you can't stack effects. (at least it's not of my knowledge or experience that you can, it didn't work when I tried even though the affect radius of Swords varied.)
- Corrected by Wua88e9r, you can infact stack the effects, thank you for providing a screenshot!

And last but not the least, I missed visual changes when equipping new items, small things but it really adds to the "wow" effect when picking up an upgrade.

I bought the game and I've not regret it, I had my fun and with 1$ per Dlc I find that you can get more than 10 hours out of it.

First review I've written, hope it helps out in your decision of purchasing this game.

17460937.review:
This is the perfect amalgam of a high quality visual novel and modern jrpg form.
It has moe fairies and lolli's, sometimes even moe fairy lolli's...
you need to have a particular love for modern anime humour i think, in order to truly enjoy this game, or even just a love for the standard format of modern jrpgs...or not, i don't know.
the battles are fast-paced, simple and enjoyable.
the writing is standardized at best and the characters are nothing if not isotropic, but that's not a bad thing.
i usually like this kind of thing, and the game has made me giggle a few times allready, and i've only played through the prologue.
the characters are standard anime, but in a good way. you have the foul mouthed, bedroom eyed alpha male protagonist. the cute and temperamental super kawaii girl sidekick, and the slightly masochistic lolita maid...take from this what you will, but i really like it.
it has some big names attatched to it also. Nobou uematsu of FF fame composed the music with his band the earthbound papas, so that should satisfy and intice some of you, it has yoshitaka amano working as an illustrator, but this is mostly a gimmick and pr stunt, i think, as none of his work can be seen in the game, i think it was mostly promotional work and limited edition stuff he did, maby a poster...the character portraits seem very much alive when you enter into the standard visual novel portions of the game, wich has become a standard for idea factory. everything is very crisp.
the graphics are also standard for this type of genre, if you are into this culture of video games this should come as no surprise, but rather comfort you. it's a ps3 port, and i must say that it's a very good port. everything is super responsive, 60+ fps and it shows. fast paced anime fun. it's addictive to fight, and you need to fight a lot.

definitely give this a try, even if you are not a fan, this might just change your jaded mind.

17458631.review:
Very good game. Overall good port from console, even if you want to play with mouse/keyboard (needs a little remapping, but not that much).

Story-wise, this game is a typical J-RPG : the main part of the narration are the relations between the main characters, which have various personnalities. The story/universe is original enough to keep us interested, but not used to its full potential. Instead, it's used to bring more dialogs and character-development. Like most J-RPG. You like it or you don't, it's just a matter of taste. But if you like J-RPG, you'll probably like it. 
Like usual : you play western RPG for the world, eastern RPG for the characters.

Now the graphics : pretty good. Full 3D anime-style with VN-like dialogs. The FPS are steady everywhere, the loadings are fast. You never really wait while playing this game.

Gameplay-wise, it's a mix between action-RPG and turn-based RPG. Mostly turn-based. But it's complex enough to allow strategy during the battles. Not that much as a full T-RPG. If you like T-RPG, but don't want to think to much or like the visuals of action-RPG, then this battle system is for you.
However, battles can become a bit boring when you travel across a dungeon filled with weak enemies. But since we can avoid most battles, it's not that bad.

Balancing : I haven't reached the end-game yet, but I can already see it coming. The main character is just a beast. Unlock the right skill (I don't remember which, but it's fairly fast to unlock), and spam it against medium-strong enemies. Money is not a problem after like 2-3 hours, so you can buy lots of TP potions and spam your skills. So, the strategy is : buff your main character, use him to focus on the DPS (don't waste damage on near-dead enemies unless you really need to lower their number), and finish the crumbs with the other characters. The support character can deal some damage, but not enough to really match the dps of the main character. I find this kinda sad : all other strategies make the battles a lot longer, and thus bring boringness.

Last words : worth buying, worth playng, if you like J-RPG. You probably won't play it for 10 hours straight (it's not the kind of game that makes forget the flow of time), but you'll have no problem playing it like 2-3 hours a day everyday until you finish the game once or twice, since it's very enjoyable.
